    • Answer: No. In a distributed system, network partitions will happen. So you really choose between CP (Consistency + Partition Tolerance) and AP (Availability + Partition Tolerance) when a partition occurs.

docs.title: 3. What is the difference between Row-Oriented and Column-Oriented storage?
docs.text:
• Row-Oriented (e.g., Postgres, MySQL): Stores data row by row. Efficient for writing data and fetching entire rows (OLTP).
  • Column-Oriented (e.g., Redshift, Snowflake, Parquet): Stores data column by column. Efficient for reading specific columns and aggregations (OLAP).
graph TD
    subgraph "Row Store"
        R1[ID:1, Name:Alice, Age:30]
        R2[ID:2, Name:Bob, Age:25]
    end
    subgraph "Column Store"
        C1[ID: 1, 2]
        C2[Name: Alice, Bob]
        C3[Age: 30, 25]
    end

docs.title: 4. What is ACID compliance?
docs.text:
• Atomicity: All or nothing.
  • Consistency: Valid state to valid state.
  • Isolation: Transactions do not interfere.
  • Durability: Committed data is saved permanently.

docs.title: 5. What is BASE?
docs.text:
• Basically Available: The system guarantees availability.
  • Soft state: The state of the system may change over time, even without input.
  • Eventual consistency: The system will eventually become consistent once it stops receiving input.

docs.title: 6. What is the difference between a Data Lake and a Data Warehouse?
docs.text: Feature Data Lake Data Warehouse Data Structure Raw, unstructured, semi-structured Processed, structured, schema-on-write Purpose Data science, ML, exploration BI, Reporting, Analytics Storage S3, HDFS, GCS Snowflake, Redshift, BigQuery Cost Low High

docs.title: 7. What is a Data Lakehouse?
docs.text: A hybrid architecture that combines the low-cost storage and flexibility of a Data Lake with the management and ACID features of a Data Warehouse. * Key Tech: Delta Lake, Apache Iceberg, Apache Hudi.

docs.title: 8. Explain Consistent Hashing.
docs.text: A technique used in distributed systems to distribute data across nodes. It maps both data and nodes to a circle. When a node is added/removed, only k/n keys need to be remapped (where k is total keys, n is nodes), unlike traditional mod n hashing which requires remapping nearly all keys.

docs.title: 9. What is Replication Factor?
docs.text: The number of times a piece of data is copied across different nodes to ensure durability and availability. * Standard: Often 3 (1 original + 2 copies).

docs.title: 10. What is Sharding?
docs.text: Partitioning a database horizontally into smaller chunks (shards) spread across multiple servers. * Sharding Key: The field used to determine which shard data belongs to (e.g., user_id).

docs.title: 11. What is the "Hot Partition" problem?
docs.text: When the sharding key is unevenly distributed (e.g., sharding by "country" and 90% of users are in the US), one shard receives most of the traffic, becoming a bottleneck. * Fix: Choose a better sharding key or use salt.

docs.title: 12. Explain the difference between DELETE and COMPACTION in Log-Structured Merge (LSM) trees (like Cassandra/RocksDB).
docs.text:
• Delete: A "Tombstone" marker is written to indicate the record is deleted. The data is not immediately removed.
  • Compaction: A background process that merges SSTables, discarding obsolete data (overwritten values) and tombstones, reclaiming space.

docs.title: 13. What is Bloom Filter?
docs.text: A probabilistic data structure used to test whether an element is a member of a set. * Returns "Possibly in set" or "Definitely not in set". * Used in databases (Cassandra, HBase) to avoid expensive disk lookups for non-existent rows.

docs.title: 14. What is CDC (Change Data Capture)?
docs.text: A pattern to identify and track changes to data in a database and deliver them to downstream systems (like a Data Warehouse or Cache) in real-time. * Tools: Debezium, AWS DMS.

docs.title: 15. What is partitioning in Hive/Iceberg?
docs.text: Organizing data into subdirectories based on column values (e.g., date=2023-01-01). This allows the query engine to skip reading files that don't match the query filter (Partition Pruning).

docs.title: 16. What is the difference between Star Schema and Snowflake Schema?
docs.text:
• Star Schema: One fact table, denormalized dimension tables. Faster queries (fewer joins).
  • Snowflake Schema: Dimensions are normalized. Saves space, but slower (more joins).

docs.title: 17. What is an Inverted Index?
docs.text: A data structure used in Search Engines (Elasticsearch, Solr). It maps content (words) to their location in a document/database. * Example: "Apple" -> Doc1, Doc5, Doc8.

docs.title: 18. Why use Parquet format?
docs.text:
• Columnar Storage: Only read needed columns.
  • Compression: Efficient encoding (Run-Length, Dictionary) due to similar data types in columns.
  • Schema Evolution: Supports adding columns.
  • Predicate Pushdown: Statistics (min/max) in file metadata allow skipping blocks.

docs.title: 19. What is Object Storage (S3) vs Block Storage (EBS)?
docs.text:
• Object (S3): Flat address space, HTTP API access, high latency, immutable objects, cheap. Good for Data Lakes.
  • Block (EBS): mounted volume, low latency, file system interface. Good for Database OS/Storage.

docs.title: 20. What is Time-Series Database (TSDB)?
docs.text: Optimized for handling time-stamped data (metrics, IoT). * Optimizations: High write throughput, efficient time-range queries, downsampling/rollups. * Examples: InfluxDB, Prometheus, TimescaleDB.

docs.title: 21. Explain the MapReduce paradigm.
docs.text:
1. Map: Process input key/value pairs to generate intermediate key/value pairs.
  2. Shuffle/Sort: Group intermediate data by key.
  3. Reduce: Aggregate values for each key.

docs.title: 22. What is the difference between Spark and Hadoop MapReduce?
docs.text: Feature Hadoop MapReduce Apache Spark Processing Disk-based (writes to HDFS between steps) In-memory (DAG execution) Speed Slower 10-100x Faster API Verbose Java Concise Python/Scala/SQL Workloads Batch only Batch, Streaming, ML, Graph

docs.title: 23. What are Spark RDDs?
docs.text: Resilient Distributed Datasets. * Immutable collection of objects. * Distributed across cluster. * Lazily evaluated. * Fault-tolerant (recomputes partitions on failure using lineage).

docs.title: 24. RDD vs DataFrame vs Dataset in Spark?
docs.text:
• RDD: Low-level, type-safe (Java/Scala), no optimization engine.
  • DataFrame: RDD + Schema. Optimized by Catalyst Optimizer. Untyped (Row objects).
  • Dataset: Type-safe DataFrame (Scala/Java). Best of both worlds.

docs.title: 25. Explain Spark Lazy Evaluation.
docs.text: Spark does not execute transformations (map, filter) immediately. It builds a DAG (Directed Acyclic Graph) of instructions. Execution only starts when an Action (count, collect, save) is called. This allows optimization (pipeline fusion).

docs.title: 26. Transformation vs Action in Spark?
docs.text:
• Transformation (Lazy): map, filter, groupBy, join. Returns a new DataFrame/RDD.
  • Action (Eager): count, show, write, collect. Triggers computation.

docs.title: 27. What is a Shuffle in Spark?
docs.text: Redistributing data across partitions (and nodes). Occurs during groupBy, join, repartition. * Impact: Expensive (Disk I/O, Network I/O, Serialization).

docs.title: 28. What is Broadcast Join?
docs.text: Optimization where the smaller table is sent (broadcast) to all worker nodes. This avoids shuffling the large table. * Condition: Small table must fit in memory.

docs.title: 29. What is Data Skew?
docs.text: When data is unevenly distributed across partitions. One task takes much longer than others, delaying the entire job. * Fix: Salting keys, broadcast join, increasing parallelism.

docs.title: 30. Coalesce vs Repartition in Spark?
docs.text:
• Repartition: Full shuffle. Can increase or decrease partitions. Balances data.
  • Coalesce: No shuffle (merges local partitions). Only decreases partitions. Faster.

docs.title: 31. What is the Catalyst Optimizer?
docs.text: Spark's internal engine that optimizes DataFrames/SQL. 1. Analysis (Resolve refs). 2. Logical Optimization (Predicate pushdown, constant folding). 3. Physical Planning (Choose join strategies). 4. Code Generation (Java bytecode).

docs.title: 32. What is Tungsten Execution Engine?
docs.text: Spark's backend that optimizes memory and CPU. * Manages memory explicitly (off-heap) to avoid GC pauses. * Uses cache-aware computation.

docs.title: 33. Explain "Predicate Pushdown".
docs.text: Pushing filtering logic (WHERE clause) as close to the data source as possible. * Example: Instead of reading a whole Parquet file and filtering in Spark, Spark tells the Parquet reader to only return rows matching the filter.

docs.title: 34. What is Vectorized Execution?
docs.text: Processing data in batches (vectors) of rows (columnar format) rather than row-by-row. Reduces CPU overhead (virtual function calls).

docs.title: 35. Batch vs Stream Processing?
docs.text:
• Batch: Process finite data. High latency, high throughput. (Historical analysis).
  • Stream: Process infinite data. Low latency. (Real-time alerting).

docs.title: 36. What is Windowing in Streaming?
docs.text: Grouping events by time. * Tumbling Window: Non-overlapping (00:00-00:05, 00:05-00:10). * Sliding Window: Overlapping (00:00-00:05, 00:01-00:06). * Session Window: Based on activity gaps.

docs.title: 37. Event Time vs Processing Time?
docs.text:
• Event Time: When the event actually happened (timestamp in payload).
  • Processing Time: When the system received the event.
  • Challenge: Late arriving data.

docs.title: 38. What is Watermarking?
docs.text: A threshold to handle late data in event-time processing. "I will wait 10 minutes for late events, then drop them/process them separately."

docs.title: 39. Exactly-Once Semantics (EOS)?
docs.text: Ensuring each message is processed exactly once, even if failures occur. * Spark Structured Streaming: Uses Checkpoints + Idempotent Sinks. * Flink: Uses Chandy-Lamport (Distributed Snapshots).

docs.title: 40. What is Backpressure?
docs.text: When the consumer is slower than the producer. The system must slow down the producer or buffer data to prevent crashing.

docs.title: 41. What is Dimensional Modeling?
docs.text: A design technique for data warehouses (Ralph Kimball) optimized for query performance. * Facts: Measurements (Sales Amount). * Dimensions: Context (Product, Date, Customer).

docs.title: 42. Fact vs Dimension Table?
docs.text:
• Fact: Long and narrow. Frequent updates (appends). Numeric metrics. Foreign keys.
  • Dimension: Short and wide. Descriptive text. Primary keys.

docs.title: 43. Types of Fact Tables?
docs.text:
1. Transaction: One row per event.
  2. Periodic Snapshot: One row per period (e.g., daily balance).
  3. Accumulating Snapshot: One row per lifecycle (e.g., Order placed -> shipped -> delivered).

docs.title: 44. Slowly Changing Dimensions (SCD)?
docs.text: How to handle changes in dimension attributes (e.g., Customer moves address). * Type 0: No change allowed. * Type 1: Overwrite (History lost). * Type 2: Add new row with version/dates (History preserved). * Type 3: Add new column (Current vs Previous).

docs.title: 45. What is a Surrogate Key?
docs.text: An artificial primary key (usually integer) added to a dimension table, independent of the business/source system key. * Why? Source keys might change or be reused. Faster joins (int vs string).

docs.title: 46. What is the Grain of a table?
docs.text: The level of detail represented by a single row. * Example: "Line Item per Order" vs "One row per Order".

docs.title: 47. Explain 3NF vs Star Schema.
docs.text:
• 3NF (Inmon): Minimize redundancy. Good for consistency and storage. Harder to query (many joins).
  • Star Schema (Kimball): Denormalized. Redundant data. Optimized for fast read queries.

docs.title: 48. What is OBT (One Big Table)?
docs.text: Denormalizing everything into a single massive table. * Pros: No joins, very fast for columnar stores (BigQuery/Snowflake). * Cons: Data duplication, update anomalies.

docs.title: 49. What is a Semantic Layer?
docs.text: An abstraction layer between raw data and BI tools. It defines business logic (metrics like "Churn Rate") in code (e.g., LookML, dbt metrics) so all tools use the same definition.

docs.title: 50. Explain dbt (data build tool).
docs.text:
A tool that allows data analysts to transform data in their warehouse using SQL SELECT statements. It handles dependency management, testing, and documentation (T in ELT).

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate focuses on "View vs Table".

    • Follow-up: "How does dbt decide whether to materialize a model as a view or a table?"
    • Answer: It is configured in the dbt_project.yml or the model config block (e.g., {{ config(materialized='table') }}).

  • Path B: Candidate mentions Jinja.

    • Follow-up: "What is the benefit of using Jinja in SQL?"
    • Answer: It allows control structures (loops, if/else) and environment variables to be injected into standard SQL, enabling dynamic query generation.

docs.title: 51. ETL vs ELT?
docs.text:
• ETL (Extract, Transform, Load): Transform before loading. Legacy (expensive on-prem hardware).
  • ELT (Extract, Load, Transform): Load raw data first, then transform in the warehouse. Modern (scalable cloud compute).

docs.title: 52. What is Data Governance?
docs.text: Policies and procedures to ensure data availability, usability, integrity, and security. (Who owns this data? Is it PII? Is it correct?)

docs.title: 53. What is Data Lineage?
docs.text: Tracking the flow of data from origin to destination. Helps debugging ("Why is this report wrong?" -> trace back upstream).

docs.title: 54. What is a Data Mesh?
docs.text: A socio-technical architecture where data is treated as a product and owned by domain teams (not a central data team). Decentralized.

docs.title: 55. What is a Data Fabric?
docs.text: A centralized architecture that uses metadata and automation to weave together data from disparate sources.

docs.title: 56. Handling PII (Personally Identifiable Information)?
docs.text:
• Encryption: At rest and in transit.
  • Masking/Tokenization: Hiding real values in non-production.
  • Access Control: RBAC/Row-level security.

docs.title: 57. What is Data Quality?
docs.text: Dimensions: 1. Accuracy: Reality match. 2. Completeness: No missing values. 3. Consistency: Same across systems. 4. Timeliness: Available when needed.

docs.title: 58. How to test data?
docs.text:
• Schema Tests: Null checks, unique keys.
  • Business Logic Tests: order_date <= ship_date.
  • Volume Tests: Row count drops by 50%.
  • Tools: Great Expectations, dbt tests.

docs.title: 59. What is Idempotency in Data Pipelines?
docs.text: Running the same pipeline multiple times produces the same result. * Essential for: Backfills and retries. * Implementation: INSERT OVERWRITE partition, MERGE statements.

docs.title: 60. What is "Schema on Read" vs "Schema on Write"?
docs.text:
• Schema on Write (RDBMS): Define structure before inserting.
  • Schema on Read (Hadoop/Lake): Store raw files, define structure when querying.

docs.title: 61. What is Apache Kafka?
docs.text: A distributed event streaming platform. It acts as a high-throughput, low-latency, fault-tolerant message bus.

docs.title: 62. Explain Kafka Architecture.
docs.text:
• Producer: Sends messages.
  • Broker: Server storing data.
  • Topic: Category for messages.
  • Partition: Shard of a topic (unit of parallelism).
  • Consumer: Reads messages.
  • Consumer Group: Set of consumers sharing work.
graph LR
    P[Producer] --> T[Topic]
    subgraph Kafka Cluster
      T --> Part1[Partition 1]
      T --> Part2[Partition 2]
    end
    Part1 --> C1[Consumer 1]
    Part2 --> C2[Consumer 2]
    subgraph Consumer Group
      C1
      C2
    end

docs.title: 63. How does Kafka guarantee order?
docs.text: Order is guaranteed only within a partition. There is no global order across a topic.

docs.title: 64. What is a Kafka Offset?
docs.text: A unique integer ID assigned to each message in a partition. Consumers track their progress by committing offsets.

docs.title: 65. What is Log Compaction in Kafka?
docs.text: Ensures that Kafka retains at least the last known value for each message key within the log of data for a single topic partition. Good for restoring state.

docs.title: 66. Kafka vs RabbitMQ?
docs.text:
• Kafka: Log-based. "Dumb" broker, "Smart" consumer. High throughput. Data persistence (replayable).
  • RabbitMQ: Queue-based. "Smart" broker (routing logic). Low latency. Messages removed after consumption.

docs.title: 67. Pull vs Push model?
docs.text:
• Kafka (Pull): Consumer requests data. Better flow control (prevents overwhelming consumer).
  • Push: Broker sends data immediately. Lower latency, but risk of flooding consumer.

docs.title: 68. What is a Dead Letter Queue (DLQ)?
docs.text: A queue where messages that fail processing (e.g., malformed JSON) are sent, so they don't block the main pipeline.

docs.title: 69. SerDe (Serializer/Deserializer)?
docs.text: Converting objects to bytes (Serialize) for network/disk and back (Deserialize). * Formats: Avro, Protobuf, JSON.

docs.title: 70. Why use Avro with Kafka?
docs.text:
• Schema Evolution: Handles adding/removing fields.
  • Compact: Binary format, stores schema separately (Schema Registry).

docs.title: 71. What is Schema Registry?
docs.text: A central server that stores schemas (Avro/Protobuf) for Kafka topics. Producers check compatibility before sending. Consumers download schema to deserialize.

docs.title: 72. At-Most-Once vs At-Least-Once delivery?
docs.text:
• At-Most-Once: Fire and forget. Message might be lost, but never duplicated.
  • At-Least-Once: Retry until ack. No loss, but duplicates possible. (Standard for Kafka).

docs.title: 73. What is ISR (In-Sync Replicas)?
docs.text: Replicas that are fully caught up with the leader. Only ISRs are eligible to become new leaders if the current leader fails.

docs.title: 74. Consumer Lag?
docs.text: Difference between the latest offset produced and the latest offset committed by the consumer. High lag = System falling behind.

docs.title: 75. Kafka Connect?
docs.text: Framework for connecting Kafka with external systems. * Source Connector: DB -> Kafka. * Sink Connector: Kafka -> S3/Snowflake.

docs.title: 76. Lambda Architecture?
docs.text: Hybrid approach handling batch and stream. * Batch Layer: Master dataset (accurate, historical). * Speed Layer: Real-time (approximate, recent). * Serving Layer: Merges results. * Cons: Maintaining two codebases.

docs.title: 77. Kappa Architecture?
docs.text: Simplify Lambda. Everything is a stream. * Real-time processing handles new data. * Reprocessing history = Replaying the stream. * Pros: One codebase.

docs.title: 78. What is Pulsar?
docs.text: Alternative to Kafka. * Separates Compute (Brokers) from Storage (BookKeeper). * Better support for multi-tenancy and geo-replication.

docs.title: 79. Kinesis vs Kafka?
docs.text:
• Kinesis: AWS Managed. Easy to setup. Pay per shard. Hard limits (1MB/sec write per shard).
  • Kafka: Self-hosted (or MSK/Confluent). Infinite scaling. Operational overhead.

docs.title: 80. Flink State Management?
docs.text:
Flink stores state (e.g., current sum) locally in memory/RocksDB. Periodically checkpoints state to remote storage (S3) for fault tolerance.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions Checkpoints.
    • Follow-up: "What happens if you don't enable checkpointing?"
    • Answer: If the job fails, it restarts from the beginning (or loses state), effectively providing 'at-most-once' semantics instead of 'exactly-once'.

docs.title: 81. What is Apache Airflow?
docs.text: A platform to programmatically author, schedule, and monitor workflows (DAGs). "Workflow as Code".

docs.title: 82. Airflow DAG (Directed Acyclic Graph)?
docs.text: Collection of tasks with dependencies. * Rule: No loops allowed.

docs.title: 83. Airflow Operator vs Sensor?
docs.text:
• Operator: Performs a task (BashOperator, PythonOperator).
  • Sensor: Waits for an external event (S3KeySensor, HttpSensor).

docs.title: 84. Airflow Scheduler?
docs.text: Monitors DAGs and tasks, triggers task instances whose dependencies have been met.

docs.title: 85. Airflow Executor?
docs.text: Decides where to run tasks. * Sequential: Local, debug only. * Celery: Distributed workers (Redis/RabbitMQ). * Kubernetes: One pod per task.

docs.title: 86. What is Backfilling in Airflow?
docs.text: Running a DAG for a past time period (e.g., re-running last month's data with new logic).

docs.title: 87. XComs (Cross-Communication)?
docs.text: Mechanism for Airflow tasks to exchange small amounts of data (metadata). Stored in Airflow DB. Do not use for large dataframes!

docs.title: 88. Dagster vs Airflow?
docs.text:
• Airflow: Task-based. Focus on execution order.
  • Dagster: Asset-based (Software-Defined Assets). Focus on the data produced. "I need table X, build whatever is needed."

docs.title: 89. Infrastructure as Code (IaC)?
docs.text: Managing infrastructure (Servers, DBs, Buckets) via code files (Terraform, CloudFormation) rather than manual GUI clicks. * Benefits: Version control, reproducibility.

docs.title: 90. Terraform State?
docs.text: A file (terraform.tfstate) that maps real-world resources to your configuration, keeps track of metadata, and improves performance for large infrastructures.

docs.title: 91. Immutable Infrastructure?
docs.text: Servers are never modified after deployment. If you need to update, you replace the entire server with a new one. (e.g., Docker containers).

docs.title: 92. Docker vs Virtual Machine?
docs.text:
• VM: Virtualizes hardware. Has full OS. Heavy.
  • Docker: Virtualizes OS (Kernel). Shared kernel. Lightweight.

docs.title: 93. Kubernetes (K8s)?
docs.text: Orchestration system for containers. Handles deployment, scaling, and management. * Pod: Smallest unit (one or more containers). * Service: Network abstraction.

docs.title: 94. Helm Charts?
docs.text: Package manager for Kubernetes. Templatized YAML files to deploy complex apps.

docs.title: 95. CI/CD in Data?
docs.text:
• CI (Continuous Integration): Lint SQL, test Python models, validate DAGs on commit.
  • CD (Continuous Deployment): Auto-deploy changes to Staging/Prod.

docs.title: 96. Blue/Green Deployment?
docs.text: Two identical environments. * Blue: Live. * Green: New version. * Switch traffic Blue -> Green. Easy rollback.

docs.title: 97. Canary Deployment?
docs.text: Roll out change to a small subset of users/servers. Monitor metrics. If good, roll out to rest.

docs.title: 98. Observability in Data?
docs.text:
• Metrics: Latency, row counts. (Prometheus/Grafana).
  • Logs: Error messages. (ELK/Splunk).
  • Traces: Distributed request path. (OpenTelemetry).
  • Data Reliability: Freshness, distribution. (Monte Carlo).

docs.title: 99. FinOps in Cloud Data?
docs.text: Managing cloud costs. * Strategies: Spot instances, auto-scaling, lifecycle policies (S3 IA/Glacier), tagging resources.

docs.title: 100. Serverless Data Architecture?
docs.text:
Using managed services where you don't manage servers. * Examples: AWS Lambda, Fargate, Glue, Athena, BigQuery. * Pros: Zero maintenance, scale to zero cost. * Cons: Cold starts, execution limits.

End of Questions

docs.title: Data Science Interview Questions & Answers (100+)
docs.text: This guide contains 100+ Data Science interview questions, ranging from statistics and machine learning to SQL and model deployment. Each question includes a model answer, visual aids, and potential follow-up paths based on the candidate's response.

docs.title: 1. Explain the Central Limit Theorem (CLT).
docs.text:
The Central Limit Theorem states that the sampling distribution of the sample mean approaches a Normal Distribution as the sample size gets larger, regardless of the shape of the population distribution, provided the samples are independent and identically distributed (i.i.d).

Key Condition: Sample size $n \geq 30$ is often used as a rule of thumb.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions "Sample Mean".
    • Follow-up: "Does CLT apply if the population distribution is highly skewed?"
    • Answer: Yes, but it may require a larger sample size ($n > 30$) to converge to normality.
  • Path B: Candidate focuses on "Normal Distribution".
    • Follow-up: "Why is this important for hypothesis testing?"
    • Answer: It justifies the use of parametric tests (Z-test, t-test) even when the underlying data isn't perfectly normal.

docs.title: 2. What is a P-value?
docs.text:
The P-value is the probability of observing test results at least as extreme as the results actually observed, assuming that the Null Hypothesis ($H_0$) is true.

  • Low P-value ($\leq 0.05$): Reject $H_0$ (Statistically Significant).
  • High P-value ($> 0.05$): Fail to reject $H_0$.

Diagram: P-value Visualization

graph TD
    Data[Observed Data] --> Calculate[Calculate Test Statistic]
    Calculate --> Compare[Compare to Null Distribution]
    Compare --> Prob{Probability}
    Prob -- "Very Low (e.g., 0.01)" --> Reject[Reject Null Hypothesis]
    Prob -- "High (e.g., 0.20)" --> Fail[Fail to Reject]

docs.title: 3. Type I vs Type II Error?
docs.text:
Error Type Definition Symbol Also Known As Type I Rejecting $H_0$ when it is True $\alpha$ False Positive Type II Failing to reject $H_0$ when it is False $\beta$ False Negative

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate confuses them.
    • Follow-up: "Think of a fire alarm. What is a Type I error?"
    • Answer: The alarm goes off (Reject Null) but there is no fire (Null is True) = False Alarm.

docs.title: 4. What is Power of a Test?
docs.text:
Power ($1 - \beta$) is the probability of correctly rejecting the Null Hypothesis when it is false. It represents the test's ability to detect an effect if one actually exists.

Factors increasing Power: 1. Larger Sample Size. 2. Larger Effect Size. 3. Higher Significance Level ($\alpha$).

docs.title: 5. Explain Bias vs Variance.
docs.text:
• Bias: Error from erroneous assumptions in the learning algorithm. High bias causes Underfitting.
  • Variance: Error from sensitivity to small fluctuations in the training set. High variance causes Overfitting.

Diagram: Bias-Variance Tradeoff

graph LR
    ModelComplex[Model Complexity]
    Error[Total Error]
    Bias[Bias^2]
    Var[Variance]

    ModelComplex -- Increases --> Var
    ModelComplex -- Decreases --> Bias
    Bias & Var --> Error

docs.title: 6. What is the difference between Covariance and Correlation?
docs.text:
• Covariance: Measures the direction of the linear relationship between two variables. Range: $(-\infty, \infty)$.
  • Correlation (Pearson): Normalized version of covariance. Measures both strength and direction. Range: $[-1, 1]$.

$$ Correlation(X, Y) = \frac{Covariance(X, Y)}{\sigma_X \sigma_Y} $$

docs.title: 7. What is Bayes' Theorem?
docs.text:
Describes the probability of an event, based on prior knowledge of conditions that might be related to the event.

$$ P(A|B) = \frac{P(B|A) \cdot P(A)}{P(B)} $$

  • $P(A|B)$: Posterior
  • $P(B|A)$: Likelihood
  • $P(A)$: Prior
  • $P(B)$: Evidence

docs.title: 8. What is A/B Testing?
docs.text:
A randomized control experiment to compare two versions (A and B) of a single variable to determine which one performs better.

Steps: 1. Define Metric (e.g., Conversion Rate). 2. Split Traffic Randomly. 3. Run Test. 4. Analyze Results (Z-test/t-test).

docs.title: 9. When should you use a t-test vs a Z-test?
docs.text:
• Z-test: Population variance ($\sigma^2$) is known OR Sample size is large ($n > 30$).
  • t-test: Population variance is unknown AND Sample size is small ($n < 30$).

docs.title: 10. What is R-squared ($R^2$)?
docs.text:
The proportion of the variance in the dependent variable that is predictable from the independent variable(s). * $R^2 = 1$: Perfect fit. * $R^2 = 0$: Model explains none of the variability.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate praises high $R^2$.
    • Follow-up: "Does a high $R^2$ imply causation or a good model?"
    • Answer: No. It could be overfitting, or a spurious correlation. Adjusted $R^2$ is often better as it penalizes adding useless predictors.

docs.title: 11. What is the Law of Large Numbers?
docs.text: As a sample size grows, its mean gets closer to the average of the whole population.

docs.title: 12. Explain Poisson Distribution.
docs.text: Models the number of events occurring within a fixed interval of time or space. * Example: Number of emails received per hour. * Parameter: $\lambda$ (average rate).

docs.title: 13. What is Sampling Bias?
docs.text: Occurs when the sample is not representative of the population (e.g., surveying only landline users for a tech product).

docs.title: 14. Mean vs Median?
docs.text:
• Mean: Average. Sensitive to outliers.
  • Median: Middle value. Robust to outliers.
  • Use Median for skewed distributions (e.g., Income).

docs.title: 15. What is Standard Deviation?
docs.text: Measure of the amount of variation or dispersion of a set of values. Square root of Variance.

docs.title: 16. What is Confidence Interval?
docs.text: A range of values so defined that there is a specified probability that the value of a parameter lies within it. "We are 95% confident that the true mean lies between X and Y."

docs.title: 17. Geometric vs Arithmetic Mean?
docs.text:
• Arithmetic: $(a+b)/2$. Used for sums/counts.
  • Geometric: $\sqrt{a \cdot b}$. Used for growth rates/percentages.

docs.title: 18. What is Prior and Posterior Probability?
docs.text:
• Prior: Probability distribution before seeing data.
  • Posterior: Conditional probability distribution after seeing data.

docs.title: 19. Explain Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE).
docs.text: A method for estimating the parameters of a probability distribution by maximizing a likelihood function, so that under the assumed statistical model, the observed data is most probable.

docs.title: 20. Parametric vs Non-Parametric Tests?
docs.text:
• Parametric: Assume underlying distribution (e.g., Normal). More powerful if assumptions hold. (t-test, ANOVA).
  • Non-Parametric: No distributional assumptions. (Mann-Whitney U, Kruskal-Wallis).

docs.title: 21. Supervised vs Unsupervised Learning?
docs.text: Feature Supervised Unsupervised Data Labeled (Input-Output pairs) Unlabeled (Input only) Goal Prediction / Classification Pattern Discovery / Clustering Examples Regression, SVM, Random Forest K-Means, PCA, Apriori

docs.title: 22. What is Linear Regression?
docs.text: Models the relationship between two variables by fitting a linear equation ($Y = mX + b$) to observed data. Assumptions: Linearity, Independence, Homoscedasticity, Normality of residuals.

docs.title: 23. What is Logistic Regression?
docs.text:
Used for binary classification. Estimates the probability that an instance belongs to a particular class using the Sigmoid function.

$$ \sigma(z) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-z}} $$

docs.title: 24. Explain Decision Trees.
docs.text:
A flowchart-like structure where an internal node represents a "test" on an attribute (e.g., is Age > 18?), each branch represents the outcome of the test, and each leaf node represents a class label.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions Splitting Criteria.
    • Follow-up: "What metrics are used to split?"
    • Answer: Gini Impurity (CART) or Information Gain/Entropy (ID3).

docs.title: 25. What is Random Forest?
docs.text: An ensemble method that operates by constructing a multitude of decision trees at training time. * Bagging: Uses Bootstrap Aggregating (random samples with replacement). * Feature Randomness: Each split considers only a random subset of features.

docs.title: 26. What is the Curse of Dimensionality?
docs.text: As the number of features (dimensions) increases, the amount of data needed to generalize accurately grows exponentially. Data becomes sparse, and distance metrics (like Euclidean) become less meaningful.

docs.title: 27. Explain K-Means Clustering.
docs.text:
1. Initialize $K$ centroids randomly.
  2. Assign each point to the nearest centroid.
  3. Recompute centroids (mean of points).
  4. Repeat until convergence.

docs.title: 28. What is the Elbow Method?
docs.text: Used to determine the optimal number of clusters ($K$) in K-Means. Plot Sum of Squared Errors (SSE) vs $K$. The "elbow" point represents the best trade-off between error and complexity.

docs.title: 29. What is SVM (Support Vector Machine)?
docs.text: Finds the hyperplane that best separates the classes with the maximum margin. * Support Vectors: The data points closest to the hyperplane. * Kernel Trick: Projects data into higher dimensions to separate non-linear data.

docs.title: 30. Explain Gradient Descent.
docs.text:
Optimization algorithm to minimize a cost function. Iteratively moves in the direction of steepest descent (negative gradient).

Types: * Batch: Uses all data per step (Slow, stable). * Stochastic (SGD): Uses 1 sample per step (Fast, noisy). * Mini-Batch: Uses $n$ samples (Balance).

docs.title: 31. What is XGBoost?
docs.text: Extreme Gradient Boosting. An optimized distributed gradient boosting library. * Pros: High speed, performance, regularization ($L1$/$L2$), handles missing values.

docs.title: 32. L1 vs L2 Regularization?
docs.text: Feature L1 (Lasso) L2 (Ridge) Penalty Absolute value of magnitude Square of magnitude Effect Can shrink coefficients to Zero (Feature Selection) Shrinks to near zero (prevents large weights) Use Case Sparse data, feature selection Multicollinearity prevention

docs.title: 33. What is PCA (Principal Component Analysis)?
docs.text: Dimensionality reduction technique. Projects data onto orthogonal vectors (Principal Components) that maximize variance.

docs.title: 34. What is Cross-Validation?
docs.text: Partitioning the data into subsets to evaluate the model. K-Fold CV: Split into $K$ folds. Train on $K-1$, test on 1. Repeat $K$ times. Average the score.

docs.title: 35. Explain Naive Bayes.
docs.text: Probabilistic classifier based on Bayes' Theorem with the "naive" assumption of independence between features. Very fast, good for text classification.

docs.title: 36. What is KNN (K-Nearest Neighbors)?
docs.text: Instance-based learning. Classifies a new point based on the majority class of its $K$ nearest neighbors. * Non-parametric. * Lazy learner (no training phase).

docs.title: 37. What is Ensemble Learning?
docs.text: Combining multiple models to improve performance. * Bagging: Parallel models (Random Forest). * Boosting: Sequential models (AdaBoost, XGBoost). * Stacking: Meta-model learns from base models.

docs.title: 38. How to handle Imbalanced Datasets?
docs.text:
1. Resampling: Oversample minority (SMOTE) or Undersample majority.
  2. Metric Choice: Use F1-Score, AUC-ROC instead of Accuracy.
  3. Algorithmic: Class weights (penalize errors on minority class).

docs.title: 39. What is Homoscedasticity?
docs.text: Assumption in linear regression that the variance of error terms (residuals) is constant across all values of the independent variables. (Opposite: Heteroscedasticity).

docs.title: 40. Linear Regression vs Logistic Regression?
docs.text:
• Linear: Continuous target. minimizes Mean Squared Error.
  • Logistic: Categorical/Probability target. Maximizes Likelihood (minimizes Log Loss).

docs.title: 41. What is a Perceptron?
docs.text: The simplest neural network unit. $Output = Activation(\sum (Weight \cdot Input) + Bias)$

docs.title: 42. Explain Activation Functions.
docs.text: Function Range Pros Cons Sigmoid $(0, 1)$ Probability output Vanishing gradient ReLU $[0, \infty)$ Fast, solves vanishing grad Dead ReLU (negative inputs die) Tanh $(-1, 1)$ Zero-centered Vanishing gradient Softmax $(0, 1)$ Multi-class probs Computationally expensive

docs.title: 43. What is Backpropagation?
docs.text: Algorithm to train neural networks. Calculates the gradient of the loss function with respect to weights using the Chain Rule, moving backward from output to input layer.

docs.title: 44. Explain CNN (Convolutional Neural Network).
docs.text: Specialized for Grid data (Images). * Convolution Layer: Detects features (edges, textures) using filters. * Pooling Layer: Reduces dimensionality (Max Pooling). * Fully Connected Layer: Classification.

docs.title: 45. What is Dropout?
docs.text: Regularization technique. Randomly sets a fraction of input units to 0 at each update during training to prevent overfitting.

docs.title: 46. What is RNN (Recurrent Neural Network)?
docs.text: Designed for sequential data (Time series, Text). Output from the previous step is fed as input to the current step. * Issue: Vanishing Gradient problem for long sequences.

docs.title: 47. LSTM vs GRU?
docs.text:
• LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory): Has 3 gates (Input, Forget, Output). Maintains a cell state to remember long-term dependencies.
  • GRU (Gated Recurrent Unit): Simplified LSTM with 2 gates (Update, Reset). Faster, often comparable performance.

docs.title: 48. What is a Transformer?
docs.text:
Architecture based entirely on Self-Attention mechanisms, discarding RNNs. Allows parallelization. (Basis for BERT, GPT).

Diagram: Transformer Block

graph TD
    Input --> Embed[Embedding + Positional Encoding]
    Embed --> Attn[Multi-Head Attention]
    Attn --> Norm1[Add & Norm]
    Norm1 --> FF[Feed Forward]
    FF --> Norm2[Add & Norm]
    Norm2 --> Output

docs.title: 49. What is BERT?
docs.text: Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers. * Pre-trained on Masked LM and Next Sentence Prediction. * Contextual embeddings (reads left-to-right and right-to-left simultaneously).

docs.title: 50. Tokenization in NLP?
docs.text: Splitting text into smaller units (tokens). * Word-level: "Hello", "World". * Subword-level (BPE/WordPiece): "un", "friend", "ly". Handles out-of-vocabulary words better.

docs.title: 51. What is Word2Vec?
docs.text: Technique to map words to vectors of real numbers. * CBOW: Predict word from context. * Skip-gram: Predict context from word.

docs.title: 52. What is TF-IDF?
docs.text: Term Frequency - Inverse Document Frequency. Reflects how important a word is to a document in a collection. * Increases with count in document. * Decreases if word is common in all documents (e.g., "the").

docs.title: 53. Explain Vanishing Gradient Problem.
docs.text: In deep networks with sigmoid/tanh, gradients become very small during backprop, causing early layers to stop learning. Solution: ReLU, Residual Connections (ResNet), Batch Normalization.

docs.title: 54. What is Batch Normalization?
docs.text: Normalizes the inputs of each layer to have mean 0 and variance 1. Stabilizes learning and allows higher learning rates.

docs.title: 55. What is an Autoencoder?
docs.text: Unsupervised NN that learns to compress input into a latent-space representation (Encoder) and reconstruct it (Decoder). Used for dimensionality reduction and denoising.

docs.title: 56. What is GAN (Generative Adversarial Network)?
docs.text: Two networks competing: 1. Generator: Creates fake data. 2. Discriminator: Tries to distinguish fake from real. Result: Generator creates realistic data.

docs.title: 57. What is Transfer Learning?
docs.text: Taking a pre-trained model (e.g., ResNet trained on ImageNet) and fine-tuning it for a specific task with less data.

docs.title: 58. Stemming vs Lemmatization?
docs.text:
• Stemming: Heuristic chopping of ends (running -> run, ponies -> poni). Fast, crude.
  • Lemmatization: Uses vocabulary/morphology to return base root (ponies -> pony, better -> good). Accurate, slower.

docs.title: 59. What is Attention Mechanism?
docs.text: Allows the model to focus on specific parts of the input sequence when generating output, rather than relying on a fixed-length vector.

docs.title: 60. What is Explainable AI (XAI)?
docs.text: Techniques to interpret ML models. * SHAP (Shapley Additive Explanations): Game theoretic approach. * LIME: Local approximation.

docs.title: 61. Order of Execution in SQL?
docs.text:
1. FROM / JOIN
  2. WHERE
  3. GROUP BY
  4. HAVING
  5. SELECT
  6. ORDER BY
  7. LIMIT

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions SELECT first.
    • Follow-up: "If SELECT is first, can I use an alias defined in SELECT inside the WHERE clause?"
    • Answer: No, because WHERE executes before SELECT.

docs.title: 62. Inner vs Left vs Full Join?
docs.text: Join Type Result Inner Matching rows in both tables Left All rows from Left, matches from Right (NULL if no match) Right All rows from Right, matches from Left Full Outer All rows when there is a match in either

docs.title: 63. What are Window Functions?
docs.text:
Perform calculations across a set of table rows that are somehow related to the current row. Unlike GROUP BY, they do not collapse rows. * RANK(), LEAD(), LAG(), ROW_NUMBER().

SELECT name, salary,
       RANK() OVER (ORDER BY salary DESC) as rank
FROM employees;

docs.title: 64. WHERE vs HAVING?
docs.text:
• WHERE: Filters rows before grouping.
  • HAVING: Filters groups after grouping (used with aggregates).

docs.title: 65. UNION vs UNION ALL?
docs.text:
• UNION: Removes duplicates. Slower.
  • UNION ALL: Keeps duplicates. Faster.

docs.title: 66. How to find the second highest salary?
docs.text:
Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Subquery. 
    SELECT MAX(salary) FROM emp WHERE salary < (SELECT MAX(salary) FROM emp)
  • Path B: LIMIT/OFFSET. 
    SELECT salary FROM emp ORDER BY salary DESC LIMIT 1 OFFSET 1
  • Path C: Dense Rank (Best for ties). 
    SELECT * FROM (
    SELECT salary, DENSE_RANK() OVER(ORDER BY salary DESC) as rnk FROM emp
) WHERE rnk = 2

docs.title: 67. Explain Normalization.
docs.text: Organizing data to reduce redundancy. * 1NF: Atomic values. * 2NF: 1NF + No partial dependency. * 3NF: 2NF + No transitive dependency.

docs.title: 68. What is a Primary Key vs Foreign Key?
docs.text:
• Primary Key: Unique identifier for a record. Cannot be NULL.
  • Foreign Key: Field that links to the Primary Key of another table.

docs.title: 69. Pandas: loc vs iloc?
docs.text:
• loc: Label-based indexing (df.loc['row_name', 'col_name']).
  • iloc: Integer-position based indexing (df.iloc[0, 1]).

docs.title: 70. How to handle missing values in Pandas?
docs.text:
• df.dropna(): Drop rows/cols.
  • df.fillna(value): Fill with constant or mean/median.
  • df.interpolate(): Linear interpolation.

docs.title: 71. merge vs concat in Pandas?
docs.text:
• merge: Join based on keys (like SQL JOIN).
  • concat: Stack dataframes vertically or horizontally (like SQL UNION).

docs.title: 72. What is One-Hot Encoding?
docs.text: Converting categorical variables into binary columns (0/1). "Red, Green, Blue" -> [1,0,0], [0,1,0], [0,0,1]. * Note: Use drop_first=True to avoid Dummy Variable Trap (Multicollinearity).

docs.title: 73. apply() vs map() vs applymap()?
docs.text:
• map(): Series element-wise (dict or function).
  • apply(): DataFrame axis-wise (row/col) or Series element-wise.
  • applymap(): DataFrame element-wise.

docs.title: 74. What is GroupBy in Pandas?
docs.text: Split-Apply-Combine strategy. 1. Split data into groups based on criteria. 2. Apply function (sum, mean) to each group. 3. Combine results.

docs.title: 75. Difference between DELETE, TRUNCATE, DROP?
docs.text:
• DELETE: DML. Deletes rows. Can use WHERE. Rollback possible.
  • TRUNCATE: DDL. Resets table. Faster. No WHERE. Cannot rollback (usually).
  • DROP: DDL. Removes table schema and data entirely.

docs.title: 76. What is an Index in SQL?
docs.text: Data structure (B-Tree) that improves speed of data retrieval operations at the cost of slower writes/updates and storage space.

docs.title: 77. How to optimize a slow query?
docs.text:
1. Check EXPLAIN plan.
  2. Add Indexes on join/filter columns.
  3. Avoid SELECT *.
  4. Remove functions on indexed columns in WHERE clause.

docs.title: 78. Pandas: Deep vs Shallow Copy?
docs.text: Same as Python lists. df2 = df is a reference. df2 = df.copy() is a deep copy (data is duplicated).

docs.title: 79. What is a CTE (Common Table Expression)?
docs.text: Temporary result set defined within the execution scope of a single statement. WITH cte AS (...). Readable alternative to subqueries.

docs.title: 80. ACID properties?
docs.text:
• Atomicity: All or nothing.
  • Consistency: DB remains in valid state.
  • Isolation: Transactions don't interfere.
  • Durability: Saved permanently.

docs.title: 81. Precision vs Recall?
docs.text: Metric Formula Focus Use Case Precision $TP / (TP + FP)$ Accuracy of positive predictions Spam Filter (Don't block good mail) Recall $TP / (TP + FN)$ Coverage of actual positives Cancer Detection (Don't miss a case)

docs.title: 82. What is the F1-Score?
docs.text: Harmonic mean of Precision and Recall. $$ F1 = 2 \cdot \frac{Precision \cdot Recall}{Precision + Recall} $$ Used when you need a balance between Precision and Recall.

docs.title: 83. Explain Confusion Matrix.
docs.text:
Diagram: Confusion Matrix

Predicted Positive Predicted Negative Actual Positive True Positive (TP) False Negative (FN) Type II Actual Negative False Positive (FP) Type I True Negative (TN)

docs.title: 84. What is ROC-AUC?
docs.text:
• ROC Curve: Plot of TPR (Recall) vs FPR (1-Specificity) at various thresholds.
  • AUC: Area Under Curve. Represents probability that the model ranks a random positive example higher than a random negative one. 0.5 = Random, 1.0 = Perfect.

docs.title: 85. Accuracy Paradox?
docs.text: In imbalanced datasets (e.g., 99% benign, 1% fraud), a model predicting "All Benign" has 99% accuracy but is useless. This is why we use F1 or AUC.

docs.title: 86. MSE vs MAE?
docs.text:
• MSE (Mean Squared Error): Penalizes large errors heavily (Square). Differentiable.
  • MAE (Mean Absolute Error): Linear penalty. More robust to outliers.

docs.title: 87. What is R-Squared vs Adjusted R-Squared?
docs.text:
• $R^2$ increases with every new feature added.
  • Adjusted $R^2$ penalizes adding non-significant features.

docs.title: 88. Explain Log Loss (Binary Cross-Entropy).
docs.text: Measures the performance of a classification model where the prediction input is a probability value between 0 and 1. Heavily penalizes confident wrong predictions.

docs.title: 89. What is Specificity?
docs.text: True Negative Rate. $TN / (TN + FP)$. Ability to find all the negative samples.

docs.title: 90. Evaluation for Clustering?
docs.text:
• Silhouette Score: How similar an object is to its own cluster (cohesion) compared to other clusters (separation). Range $[-1, 1]$.
  • Davies-Bouldin Index: Lower is better.

docs.title: 91. What is A/B Testing Significance Level?
docs.text: Usually $\alpha = 0.05$. It means we accept a 5% risk of concluding a difference exists when there is no actual difference.

docs.title: 92. Lift Chart / Gain Chart?
docs.text: Measures how much better the model is at predicting positives than a random guess. Used in marketing.

docs.title: 93. What is Root Mean Squared Log Error (RMSLE)?
docs.text: Used when target variable spans a wide range (e.g., house prices). Penalizes under-prediction more than over-prediction.

docs.title: 94. How to detect Data Drift?
docs.text: Monitoring the statistical properties of input data over time. If the distribution changes ($P(X)$ changes), the model may degrade. * Solution: Retrain model.

docs.title: 95. Model Deployment Strategies?
docs.text:
• Shadow Mode: Run new model alongside old, but don't serve predictions. Compare.
  • Canary Deployment: Roll out to small % of users.
  • Blue/Green: Switch traffic from old (Blue) to new (Green) environment.

docs.title: 96. What is a Pickled Model?
docs.text: Serialized version of a trained model object (e.g., sklearn model). Saved to file for loading in production.

docs.title: 97. What is the difference between Model Parameters and Hyperparameters?
docs.text:
• Parameters: Learned internal variables (Weights, Biases).
  • Hyperparameters: External configurations set before training (Learning Rate, K in KNN, Depth of Tree).

docs.title: 98. Grid Search vs Random Search?
docs.text:
• Grid Search: Exhuastive search over specified parameter values. Slow.
  • Random Search: Randomly samples parameter space. Often finds good models faster.

docs.title: 99. What is K-Fold Cross Validation?
docs.text: Splitting data into K parts. Training on K-1, testing on 1. Rotating until all parts have been used as test set. Reduces variance in performance estimate.

docs.title: 100. How do you explain a complex model to a non-technical stakeholder?
docs.text:
• Focus on Input -> Output.
  • Use analogies (e.g., "Think of the model as a committee of experts" for Random Forest).
  • Focus on Business Impact (ROI, Efficiency) rather than AUC/LogLoss.

End of Interview Questions

docs.title: Golang Interview Questions & Answers (100+)
docs.text: This guide contains 100+ Go (Golang) interview questions, ranging from basic syntax to advanced concurrency and runtime internals. Each question includes a model answer and potential follow-up paths based on the candidate's response.

docs.title: 1. What is Go and what are its main characteristics?
docs.text:
Go is an open-source programming language created at Google. It is statically typed, compiled, and designed for simplicity, concurrency, and performance.

Key Characteristics: * Simple Syntax: Easy to learn and read. * Static Typing: Catches errors at compile time. * Concurrency Primitives: Built-in support for concurrent execution (Goroutines, Channels). * Garbage Collection: Automatic memory management. * Fast Compilation: Fast build times.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions 'Object-Oriented'.
    • Follow-up: "Is Go an Object-Oriented language?"
    • Answer: Go has some OO features (methods, interfaces), but it lacks inheritance and type hierarchy. It prefers composition over inheritance.

docs.title: 2. What is the difference between GOPATH and Go Modules?
docs.text:
• GOPATH: The legacy way of managing workspace. Code must live inside $GOPATH/src. No built-in versioning.
  • Go Modules (go.mod): The modern dependency management system (introduced in Go 1.11). Allows code to live anywhere. Supports semantic versioning.

Chart: Comparison

Feature GOPATH Go Modules Workspace Strict ($GOPATH/src) Flexible (Anywhere) Versioning No (relied on master) Yes (Semantic Versioning) Dependency Loc Global ($GOPATH/pkg) Local cache + go.sum verification

docs.title: 3. How do you define public (exported) vs private (unexported) symbols?
docs.text: In Go, visibility is controlled by the case of the first letter of the identifier. * Uppercase (e.g., User): Public/Exported. Visible to other packages. * Lowercase (e.g., user): Private/Unexported. Visible only within the same package.

docs.title: 4. What are the basic data types in Go?
docs.text:
• Boolean: bool
  • Numeric: int, int8, int16, int32, int64, uint, float32, float64, complex64, complex128.
  • String: string (immutable).
  • Byte: byte (alias for uint8).
  • Rune: rune (alias for int32, represents a Unicode code point).

docs.title: 5. What are pointers in Go?
docs.text:
A pointer holds the memory address of a value. * & operator generates a pointer to its operand. * * operator dereferences a pointer (accesses the value).

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Comparison with C.
    • Follow-up: "Does Go support pointer arithmetic?"
    • Answer: No, Go does not support pointer arithmetic (like ptr++) by default, to ensure safety. You can use unsafe package if absolutely necessary.

docs.title: 6. Explain the difference between Arrays and Slices.
docs.text:
Feature Array Slice Size Fixed length ([5]int) Dynamic length ([]int) Value/Ref Value type (copying copies whole array) Reference type (points to underlying array) Flexibility Rigid Flexible

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Slice internals.
    • Follow-up: "What are the three components of a slice?"
    • Answer: Pointer to underlying array, Length (len), and Capacity (cap).

docs.title: 7. What is a Map?
docs.text: A built-in data structure that associates keys with values (Hash Table). * Syntax: map[KeyType]ValueType. * KeyType must be comparable (supports ==).

docs.title: 8. What is a Struct?
docs.text:
A typed collection of fields. It is the closest thing to a "class" in Go, used to group data.

type Person struct {
    Name string
    Age  int
}

docs.title: 9. Difference between Functions and Methods?
docs.text:
• Function: Standalone code block. func Add(a, b int) int.
  • Method: A function attached to a specific type (receiver). func (p Person) Greet().

docs.title: 10. What is defer?
docs.text:
A keyword used to schedule a function call to be run after the function completes. Commonly used for cleanup (closing files, unlocking mutexes). Executed in LIFO (Last-In-First-Out) order.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Evaluation time.
    • Follow-up: "When are the arguments to a deferred function evaluated?"
    • Answer: They are evaluated immediately when the defer statement is executed, not when the function runs.

docs.title: 11. What is panic and recover?
docs.text:
• Panic: Stops normal execution. Similar to throwing an exception.
  • Recover: Used inside a deferred function to regain control of a panicking goroutine.

docs.title: 12. Difference between make and new?
docs.text:
• new(T): Allocates zeroed storage for a new item of type T and returns its address *T. Used for all types.
  • make(T, args): Creates slices, maps, and channels only. Returns an initialized T (not a pointer).

docs.title: 13. What is the init() function?
docs.text: A special function that executes before main(). It is used for package initialization. * Can have multiple init() functions per package (and per file). * Cannot be called explicitly.

docs.title: 14. What is the Blank Identifier _?
docs.text: It is a write-only variable used to discard values. Example: _, err := os.Open("file.txt") (if you don't care about the file handle).

docs.title: 15. What are Type Assertions?
docs.text:
Used to extract the underlying value of a specific type from an interface.

var i interface{} = "hello"
s := i.(string) // panic if not string
s, ok := i.(string) // safe check

docs.title: 16. What is a Type Switch?
docs.text:
A switch statement that compares types rather than values.

switch v := i.(type) {
case int:
    fmt.Println("Integer")
case string:
    fmt.Println("String")
}

docs.title: 17. How do Constants work (iota)?
docs.text:
Constants are immutable values known at compile time. iota is a counter used to create enumerated constants.

const (
    Red = iota // 0
    Blue       // 1
    Green      // 2
)

docs.title: 18. Is Go pass-by-value or pass-by-reference?
docs.text: Go is strictly pass-by-value. When passing a pointer, a copy of the pointer address is passed. When passing a slice, a copy of the slice header (ptr, len, cap) is passed, so modifications to elements affect the original array, but append might not.

docs.title: 19. How are Strings handled in Go?
docs.text: Strings are immutable sequences of bytes (UTF-8 encoded). * Backticks (`) create raw string literals (multiline). * Double quotes ("") create interpreted string literals.

docs.title: 20. Explain the for loop variations.
docs.text:
Go has only one looping keyword: for.

  1. C-style: for i := 0; i < 10; i++ {}
  2. While-style: for i < 10 {}
  3. Infinite: for {}
  4. Range: for index, value := range slice {}

docs.title: 21. What is a Goroutine?
docs.text: A goroutine is a lightweight thread of execution managed by the Go runtime. * Started with the go keyword. * Very cheap start-up cost (few KB of stack).

docs.title: 22. How do Goroutines differ from OS threads?
docs.text: Feature Goroutine OS Thread Stack Size Growable (starts ~2KB) Fixed (usually ~1MB) Scheduling M:N Model (Go Runtime) Kernel Managed Switch Cost Low (user space) High (kernel context switch)

docs.title: 23. What is a Channel?
docs.text: A typed conduit through which goroutines communicate and synchronize. * Send: ch <- v * Receive: v := <-ch

docs.title: 24. Difference between Buffered and Unbuffered Channels?
docs.text:
• Unbuffered: make(chan int). Sender blocks until receiver is ready. Guarantees synchronization.
  • Buffered: make(chan int, 5). Sender only blocks if buffer is full. Receiver blocks if buffer is empty.

docs.title: 25. What happens if you send to a closed channel?
docs.text: It causes a panic.

docs.title: 26. What happens if you read from a closed channel?
docs.text:
• It returns the zero value of the channel's type immediately (does not block).
  • The second return value (boolean) indicates if the channel is open: val, ok := <-ch. ok will be false.

docs.title: 27. What is the select statement?
docs.text:
The select statement lets a goroutine wait on multiple communication operations. It blocks until one of its cases can run, then it executes that case. If multiple are ready, it chooses one at random.

select {
case msg1 := <-c1:
    fmt.Println("received", msg1)
case msg2 := <-c2:
    fmt.Println("received", msg2)
default:
    fmt.Println("no message received") // Non-blocking
}

docs.title: 28. What is sync.WaitGroup?
docs.text: It waits for a collection of goroutines to finish. * Add(n): Increases counter. * Done(): Decrements counter. * Wait(): Blocks until counter is 0.

docs.title: 29. What is sync.Mutex?
docs.text: A mutual exclusion lock. Used to protect shared memory (critical sections) from concurrent access. * Lock() * Unlock()

docs.title: 30. Difference between Mutex and RWMutex?
docs.text:
• Mutex: Exclusive lock. Only one goroutine can read or write at a time.
  • RWMutex: Reader/Writer lock. Allows multiple readers (shared lock) OR one writer (exclusive lock). Better performance for read-heavy workloads.

docs.title: 31. What is a Data Race?
docs.text:
When two goroutines access the same variable concurrently, and at least one of the accesses is a write.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Undefined behavior.
    • Follow-up: "What happens to the program during a data race?"
    • Answer: The behavior is undefined. It might crash, corrupt data, or act unpredictably.

docs.title: 32. How to detect data races in Go?
docs.text: Use the built-in race detector: go run -race main.go or go test -race ./...

docs.title: 33. What is a Deadlock?
docs.text: A state where a group of goroutines are waiting for each other to release resources, and none can proceed. Common case: Channel full and sender blocks, but receiver is waiting on something else.

docs.title: 34. Explain the "Fan-in" pattern.
docs.text:
Merging multiple input channels into a single output channel.

graph LR
    A[Source 1] -->|Chan A| M(Merge)
    B[Source 2] -->|Chan B| M
    M -->|Chan Out| C[Consumer]

docs.title: 35. What is the context package used for?
docs.text: It carries deadlines, cancellation signals, and request-scoped values across API boundaries and between goroutines.

docs.title: 36. Difference between context.Background() and context.TODO()?
docs.text:
• Background(): Standard root context. Used in main, init, and tests.
  • TODO(): Placeholder when you intend to use a context but haven't structured the code yet. (Functionally identical to Background).

docs.title: 37. How to stop a goroutine (cancellation)?
docs.text:
You cannot "kill" a goroutine from the outside. You must signal it to stop using a Context or a Done Channel.

ctx, cancel := context.WithCancel(context.Background())
go func() {
    select {
    case <-ctx.Done():
        return // Return to exit
    }
}()
cancel() // Send signal

docs.title: 38. What is sync.Once?
docs.text: It ensures that a piece of code is executed exactly once, regardless of how many goroutines call it. Commonly used for singleton initialization.

docs.title: 39. What is sync.Pool?
docs.text: A set of temporary objects that may be individually saved and retrieved. * Used to reduce GC pressure by reusing allocated objects (e.g., buffers). * Items in the pool can be removed by GC at any time.

docs.title: 40. What is sync.Map?
docs.text: A concurrent-safe map implementation. * Unlike map + Mutex, sync.Map is optimized for cases where keys are only written once but read many times (e.g., caches). * Methods: Load, Store, LoadOrStore, Delete.

docs.title: 41. What is an Interface in Go?
docs.text: An interface is a type that defines a set of method signatures. * Implicit Implementation: A type implements an interface by implementing its methods. No implements keyword. * Enables polymorphism.

docs.title: 42. What is the Empty Interface interface{}?
docs.text: An interface with zero methods. * Every type satisfies the empty interface. * Used to handle values of unknown type (similar to Object in Java/C#, or any in TS). * Go 1.18+ introduced the alias any for interface{}.

docs.title: 43. Explain Struct Embedding (Composition).
docs.text:
Go allows you to embed one struct into another. The inner struct's fields and methods are promoted to the outer struct.

type Base struct {
    ID int
}
type User struct {
    Base // Embedding
    Name string
}
// u.ID is accessible directly

docs.title: 44. How does Go implement interfaces implicitly?
docs.text: If a concrete type has all the methods that an interface requires, it automatically implements that interface. This decouples the definition of the interface from the implementation.

docs.title: 45. Explain the internals of a Slice: len vs cap.
docs.text:
• Length (len): The number of elements referred to by the slice.
  • Capacity (cap): The number of elements in the underlying array (beginning at the element referred to by the slice pointer).
  • append doubles capacity when full (up to a certain threshold), then grows by a smaller factor.

docs.title: 46. What are common "Slice Tricks"?
docs.text:
• Copy: b = make([]T, len(a)); copy(b, a)
  • Cut: a = append(a[:i], a[j:]...)
  • Delete: a = append(a[:i], a[i+1:]...)
  • Pop: x, a = a[len(a)-1], a[:len(a)-1]

docs.title: 47. How do Maps work internally?
docs.text: Go maps are implemented as Hash Tables. * They use buckets to store key/value pairs. * Collision resolution is done via chaining (overflow buckets). * Access time is O(1) on average.

docs.title: 48. What are Struct Tags?
docs.text:
Metadata attached to struct fields. * Accessed via Reflection (reflect package). * Commonly used for JSON serialization, ORM mapping, and validation.

type User struct {
    Name string `json:"name" validate:"required"`
}

docs.title: 49. How does JSON Marshaling work?
docs.text: The encoding/json package uses reflection to inspect struct fields and map them to JSON keys. * Only exported (public) fields are marshaled. * Fields with json:"-" are ignored.

docs.title: 50. What types are Comparable?
docs.text:
• Comparable: Booleans, Numbers, Strings, Pointers, Channels, Interfaces (if dynamic type is comparable), Structs/Arrays (if all fields/elements are comparable).
  • Not Comparable: Slices, Maps, Functions.

docs.title: 51. Explain the "Interface nil" vs "Typed nil" gotcha.
docs.text:
An interface value is nil only if both its value and concrete type are nil. If an interface holds a nil pointer of a concrete type, the interface itself is not nil.

var p *int = nil
var i interface{} = p
fmt.Println(i == nil) // False!

docs.title: 52. What is the Functional Options Pattern?
docs.text:
A design pattern for constructing complex structs with optional parameters.

func NewServer(addr string, opts ...Option) *Server { ... }

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Builder Pattern.
    • Follow-up: "Why choose Functional Options over the Builder Pattern?"
    • Answer: Functional options are often more idiomatic in Go and don't require a separate Builder struct.

docs.title: 53. How do Generics work in Go (Type Parameters)?
docs.text:
Introduced in Go 1.18. Allows writing functions and data structures that work with any type.

func Map[T any, R any](s []T, f func(T) R) []R { ... }

docs.title: 54. What is the comparable constraint?
docs.text: A pre-declared identifier in generics constraints that denotes the set of all types that can be compared using == and !=. Required for map keys.

docs.title: 55. What are Slice Expressions?
docs.text: Constructing a new slice from an existing slice/array. * a[low : high] * a[low : high : max] (Controls capacity)

docs.title: 56. What does the copy function do?
docs.text: Copies elements from a source slice into a destination slice. * Returns the number of elements copied (min of len(src) and len(dst)). * Handles overlapping slices correctly.

docs.title: 57. Are Maps safe for concurrent use?
docs.text: No. Maps are not thread-safe. Concurrent reads are safe. Concurrent read/write or write/write causes a fatal error. Use sync.RWMutex or sync.Map.

docs.title: 58. Explain Method Sets (Pointer vs Value Receivers).
docs.text:
• Value Receiver (func (t T)): Can be called on both value and pointer. Operates on a copy.
  • Pointer Receiver (func (t *T)): Can be called on both value (if addressable) and pointer. Can modify the original struct.
  • Rule: If you want to modify the receiver, or if the struct is large, use a pointer receiver.

Table: Interface Implementation

Method Receiver Interface requires Implemented by (t T) (t T) T and *T (t *T) (t *T) *T only

docs.title: 59. What is Interface Composition?
docs.text:
Embedding interfaces within other interfaces.

type Reader interface { Read(p []byte) (n int, err error) }
type Writer interface { Write(p []byte) (n int, err error) }
type ReadWriter interface {
    Reader
    Writer
}

docs.title: 60. Difference between Type Definition and Type Alias?
docs.text:
• Type Definition: type MyInt int. Creates a new type. MyInt and int are distinct.
  • Type Alias: type MyInt = int. MyInt and int are the same type. Used for refactoring/compatibility.

docs.title: 61. How does Go handle errors?
docs.text:
Go treats errors as values. Functions return an error interface as the last return value. There are no exceptions (in the traditional sense).

f, err := os.Open("filename.ext")
if err != nil {
    log.Fatal(err)
}

docs.title: 62. How do you define a custom error type?
docs.text:
Any type that implements the Error() string method satisfies the error interface.

type MyError struct {
    Msg string
    Code int
}
func (e *MyError) Error() string {
    return fmt.Sprintf("%d: %s", e.Code, e.Msg)
}

docs.title: 63. What is Error Wrapping (Go 1.13+)?
docs.text: Wrapping an error with additional context while preserving the original error for inspection. * Use %w verb in fmt.Errorf. * fmt.Errorf("access denied: %w", err)

docs.title: 64. What are errors.Is and errors.As?
docs.text:
• errors.Is(err, target): Checks if an error (or any error in its chain) matches a specific sentinel error value.
  • errors.As(err, &target): Checks if an error (or any error in its chain) matches a specific type, and if so, assigns it to the target.

docs.title: 65. How do you run tests in Go?
docs.text: Using the go test command. It looks for files ending in _test.go and executes functions starting with Test.

docs.title: 66. What is Table-Driven Testing?
docs.text:
A pattern where test inputs and expected outputs are defined in a slice of structs (the "table"), and a single test loop iterates over them.

Name Input Expected "Positive" 2 true "Negative" -1 false

docs.title: 67. How do you write a Benchmark?
docs.text:
• Function signature: func BenchmarkName(b *testing.B)
  • Loop b.N times.
  • Run with go test -bench .
func BenchmarkRand(b *testing.B) {
    for i := 0; i < b.N; i++ {
        rand.Int()
    }
}

docs.title: 68. What are Testable Examples?
docs.text:
Functions starting with Example in test files. They serve as documentation and tests. The output is verified against a comment at the end of the function.

func ExampleHello() {
    fmt.Println("Hello")
    // Output: Hello
}

docs.title: 69. What is Fuzzing (Go 1.18+)?
docs.text: Automated testing that provides random invalid/unexpected inputs to find bugs/crashes. * func FuzzName(f *testing.F)

docs.title: 70. What is TestMain?
docs.text: A function that allows setup and teardown code to run before and after all tests in a package. Must call m.Run() to execute tests.

docs.title: 71. How do you run subtests?
docs.text: Using t.Run("name", func(t *testing.T) { ... }). Allows hierarchical test reporting and specific filtering.

docs.title: 72. How do you run tests in parallel?
docs.text: Call t.Parallel() inside the test function (and subtests).

docs.title: 73. Difference between Mocks and Stubs?
docs.text:
• Stub: Returns hardcoded data.
  • Mock: Verifies behavior (e.g., "was this method called X times with Y arguments?").
  • Go has no built-in mocking framework, but interfaces make it easy to write manual mocks or use tools like gomock.

docs.title: 74. How to handle Dependency Injection in Go?
docs.text:
Pass dependencies (usually interfaces) to the constructor or method.

type Service struct {
    db Database // interface
}
func NewService(db Database) *Service {
    return &Service{db: db}
}

docs.title: 75. How do you check test coverage?
docs.text: go test -coverprofile=coverage.out go tool cover -html=coverage.out (Visualizes coverage)

docs.title: 76. What is the Race Detector?
docs.text: (Covered in Part 2, but relevant here). It detects concurrent access to shared memory. Always run CI with -race.

docs.title: 77. What is go vet?
docs.text: A static analysis tool that examines Go source code and reports suspicious constructs (e.g., printf arguments mismatch, unreachable code).

docs.title: 78. When should you panic instead of returning an error?
docs.text: Only for unrecoverable errors that indicate a programmer error (e.g., nil pointer dereference, index out of bounds) or during initialization (init()) if the app cannot start (e.g., bad config). For all other cases, return error.

docs.title: 79. Log package vs Structured Logging?
docs.text:
• Standard log: Simple text output. Hard to parse by machines.
  • Structured Logging (slog - Go 1.21+): Outputs logs as JSON/Key-Value pairs. Better for observability stacks (ELK, Datadog).

docs.title: 80. How to handle HTTP errors?
docs.text: Check the status code. * resp, err := client.Get(url) checks connection errors. * if resp.StatusCode != http.StatusOK checks application errors.

docs.title: 81. How does the Garbage Collector work in Go?
docs.text: Go uses a Concurrent Mark-and-Sweep (CMS) garbage collector (Tri-color marking). * Concurrent: Runs alongside the application code. * Low Latency: Designed to minimize "Stop the World" (STW) pauses. * Write Barrier: Ensures data consistency during concurrent marking.

docs.title: 82. What is Escape Analysis?
docs.text: A compiler optimization technique that determines whether a variable can be allocated on the stack or must "escape" to the heap. * Stack: Fast, automatic cleanup. * Heap: Slower, requires GC. * Command: go build -gcflags="-m"

docs.title: 83. What is Inlining?
docs.text: The compiler replaces a function call with the function body itself to save the overhead of the function call (stack setup, jumps). * Only small, simple functions are inlined.

docs.title: 84. What is pprof?
docs.text: A tool for visualization and analysis of profiling data. * CPU Profile: Where CPU time is spent. * Memory Profile: Heap allocations. * Block Profile: Blocking on synchronization primitives.

docs.title: 85. What is go tool trace?
docs.text: A tool to visualize the execution trace of the Go runtime. * Shows goroutine scheduling, GC pauses, and network blocking events over time.

docs.title: 86. What are Build Tags?
docs.text: Comments that control which files are included in the build. * //go:build linux * // +build linux (Legacy) * Used for platform-specific code or integration tests.

docs.title: 87. What is CGo?
docs.text: A mechanism that allows Go packages to call C code. * Uses import "C". * Performance cost: High overhead due to stack switching (Goroutine stack vs C stack). * Drawback: Makes cross-compilation harder and disables some Go tools.

docs.title: 88. Explain the Memory Layout (Stack vs Heap).
docs.text:
• Stack: Per-goroutine. LIFO. Stores local variables, arguments. Grows dynamically.
  • Heap: Global. Stores objects referenced across boundaries, large objects, or those that outlive the function scope (determined by Escape Analysis).

docs.title: 89. What is GOMAXPROCS?
docs.text: An environment variable (and runtime function) that limits the number of operating system threads that can execute user-level Go code simultaneously. * Default: Number of CPU cores.

docs.title: 90. How does Reflection work in Go?
docs.text: The reflect package allows inspecting type and value information at runtime. * reflect.TypeOf() * reflect.ValueOf() * Cons: Slower than direct access, not type-safe at compile time.

docs.title: 91. What is the unsafe package?
docs.text: Bypasses Go's type safety and memory security. * Allows pointer arithmetic. * Allows converting between arbitrary types. * Risk: Can cause crashes and memory corruption.

docs.title: 92. What are Go Plugins?
docs.text: Allows loading shared libraries (.so files) at runtime. * Limited support (Linux/macOS primarily). * Strict versioning requirements between main app and plugin.

docs.title: 93. What is the vendor directory?
docs.text: A directory that contains copies of all dependency packages. * Ensures reproducible builds without relying on external sources. * go mod vendor creates it.

docs.title: 94. What is the Go 1 Compatibility Guarantee?
docs.text: A promise that code written for Go 1.0 will continue to compile and run with all future Go 1.x versions. (Exceptions: Security fixes, undefined behaviors).

docs.title: 95. What are Internal Packages?
docs.text: Packages inside a directory named internal. * They can only be imported by the direct parent package and its subdirectories. * Enforces encapsulation at the module level.

docs.title: 96. Common go mod commands?
docs.text:
• go mod init: Initialize module.
  • go mod tidy: Add missing and remove unused dependencies.
  • go mod download: Download dependencies to cache.
  • go mod graph: Print module requirement graph.

docs.title: 97. How do you Cross-Compile in Go?
docs.text: Set GOOS and GOARCH environment variables. * GOOS=linux GOARCH=arm64 go build main.go * Go makes this incredibly easy compared to C/C++.

docs.title: 98. What is the embed package (Go 1.16+)?
docs.text:
Allows embedding static files (HTML, images, config) directly into the compiled Go binary.

//go:embed static/*
var content embed.FS

docs.title: 99. Implement Singleton Pattern in Go.
docs.text:
var (
    instance *Singleton
    once     sync.Once
)
func GetInstance() *Singleton {
    once.Do(func() {
        instance = &Singleton{}
    })
    return instance
}

docs.title: 100. Implement Factory Pattern in Go.
docs.text:
type Animal interface { Speak() string }
type Dog struct{}
func (d Dog) Speak() string { return "Woof" }

func NewAnimal(type string) Animal {
    if type == "dog" { return Dog{} }
    return nil
}

End of Interview Questions

docs.title: Java Interview Questions & Answers (100+)
docs.text: This guide contains 100+ Java interview questions, ranging from core concepts to advanced concurrency and performance tuning. Each question includes a model answer and potential follow-up paths based on the candidate's response.

docs.title: 1. What is the difference between JDK, JRE, and JVM?
docs.text:
Component Full Form Description Contains JVM Java Virtual Machine The abstract machine that executes Java bytecode. Just the execution engine. JRE Java Runtime Environment The environment required to run Java applications. JVM + Class Libraries. JDK Java Development Kit The kit required to develop and compile Java applications. JRE + Development Tools (javac, jdb, etc). 
graph TD
    subgraph JDK
        subgraph JRE
            JVM
            Libraries[Class Libraries]
        end
        Tools[Dev Tools: javac, debugger]
    end

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate focuses on definitions.
    • Follow-up: "Can I run a Java program with just the JVM installed?"
    • Answer: No, you need the JRE which includes the libraries and the JVM.
  • Path B: Candidate mentions platform independence.
    • Follow-up: "Is the JVM itself platform-independent?"
    • Answer: No, the JVM is platform-dependent (there are specific JVMs for Windows, Linux, Mac), but it makes Java programs platform-independent.

docs.title: 2. Explain the difference between == and equals().
docs.text:
• ==: Operator that checks for reference equality (memory address) for objects, and value equality for primitives.
  • equals(): Method in the Object class that checks for content equality (logical equality).

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions overriding.
    • Follow-up: "What happens if I don't override equals() in my custom class?"
    • Answer: It defaults to the implementation in the Object class, which uses == (reference equality).
  • Path B: Candidate mentions String pool.
    • Follow-up: "Why does "abc" == "abc" return true?"
    • Answer: Because of String Interning/String Pool, both literals point to the same object.

docs.title: 3. What are the 4 pillars of Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)?
docs.text:
1. Encapsulation: Wrapping data (variables) and code (methods) together as a single unit (Class). Hiding internal details (private).
  2. Inheritance: Mechanism where one class acquires the properties and behaviors of another class.
  3. Polymorphism: The ability to perform a single action in different ways (Overloading & Overriding).
  4. Abstraction: Hiding implementation details and showing only functionality to the user (Interfaces & Abstract Classes).

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Real-world examples.
    • Follow-up: "Give me a real-world example of Polymorphism."
    • Answer: A Shape interface with a draw() method. Circle and Square implement it differently. The caller just calls draw() without knowing the specific shape.

docs.title: 4. Why is Java not considered "pure" object-oriented?
docs.text:
Because it supports Primitive Types (int, char, boolean, etc.) which are not objects.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions 'static'.
    • Follow-up: "How does the static keyword violate pure OOP?"
    • Answer: Static methods/variables belong to the class, not an instance. Pure OOP suggests everything is an object interaction.

docs.title: 5. What is the difference between an Abstract Class and an Interface?
docs.text:
Feature Abstract Class Interface (Java 8+) Methods Can have abstract and concrete methods. Can have abstract, default, and static methods. Variables Can have final, non-final, static, non-static. All variables are public static final (constants). Inheritance A class can extend only one class. A class can implement multiple interfaces. Constructor Can have constructors. Cannot have constructors.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Design choice.
    • Follow-up: "When would you choose an Abstract Class over an Interface?"
    • Answer: When you want to share code (state/implementation) among closely related classes, or require non-static / non-final fields.

docs.title: 6. What is the difference between Method Overloading and Method Overriding?
