docs.text: Feature Overloading Overriding Definition Same method name, different parameter list (signature). Same method name and signature in child class. Scope Within the same class. Inheritance (Parent vs Child). Binding Static/Compile-time polymorphism. Dynamic/Runtime polymorphism.

docs.title: 7. What is the static keyword?
docs.text:
It means the member belongs to the type (class) itself, rather than to an instance of that type. * Static Variable: Shared among all instances. * Static Method: Can be called without creating an object. Cannot access instance variables. * Static Block: Executed once when the class is loaded.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Memory management.
    • Follow-up: "Where are static variables stored?"
    • Answer: In the Metaspace (previously PermGen), specifically in the Class definitions.

docs.title: 8. Can we override a static method?
docs.text: No. If you define a static method with the same signature in the child class, it is called Method Hiding, not overriding. The method called depends on the type of the reference, not the object.

docs.title: 9. What is the difference between final, finally, and finalize?
docs.text:
• final: Keyword to apply restrictions.
    • Variable: Constant.
    • Method: Cannot be overridden.
    • Class: Cannot be inherited (e.g., String).
  • finally: Block used in Exception Handling. Executes always (with rare exceptions).
  • finalize: Method used for Garbage Collection cleanup (Deprecated in Java 9).

docs.title: 10. Why is String immutable in Java?
docs.text:
1. Security: Used for network connections, database URLs, usernames/passwords.
  2. Synchronization: Automatically thread-safe.
  3. Caching: String Pool requires immutability to ensure one reference doesn't change the value for others.
  4. Hashcode Caching: The hashcode is calculated once and cached, making it a great key for Maps.

docs.title: 11. String vs StringBuilder vs StringBuffer?
docs.text:
Class Mutable? Thread-Safe? Performance String No Yes (Immutable) Slow (creates new objects) StringBuilder Yes No Fast StringBuffer Yes Yes (Synchronized) Slower than Builder

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Usage context.
    • Follow-up: "When would you use StringBuffer?"
    • Answer: Only in multi-threaded environments where a shared mutable string is being modified. Otherwise, StringBuilder is preferred.

docs.title: 12. Explain the difference between Checked and Unchecked Exceptions.
docs.text:
• Checked Exceptions: Checked at compile-time. Must be handled (try-catch) or declared (throws).
    • Examples: IOException, SQLException.
  • Unchecked Exceptions: Runtime Exceptions. Compiler does not force handling.
    • Examples: NullPointerException, ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Design philosophy.
    • Follow-up: "When creating a custom exception, which one should you extend?"
    • Answer: Generally RuntimeException (Unchecked) if the client cannot recover from it. Exception (Checked) if you expect the client to recover.

docs.title: 13. What is the try-with-resources statement?
docs.text:
Introduced in Java 7, it allows declaring resources (that implement AutoCloseable) inside the try(...) parenthesis. It ensures that the resources are closed automatically at the end of the block, replacing the verbose finally block pattern.

try (BufferedReader br = new BufferedReader(new FileReader(path))) {
    return br.readLine();
} // br is closed here automatically

docs.title: 14. Does the finally block always execute?
docs.text: Yes, except in these cases: 1. System.exit() is called. 2. The thread is killed. 3. JVM crashes / Power failure.

docs.title: 15. What are Wrapper Classes?
docs.text:
Classes that wrap primitive data types into objects. * int -> Integer * char -> Character * double -> Double

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Autoboxing.
    • Follow-up: "What is Autoboxing and Unboxing?"
    • Answer: Automatic conversion between primitives and wrappers by the compiler.
    • Follow-up: "What is the danger of Unboxing?"
    • Answer: NullPointerException if the wrapper is null.

docs.title: 16. What is a Marker Interface?
docs.text: An interface with no methods or fields. It provides run-time type information about objects so the JVM or compiler can take some special action. * Examples: Serializable, Cloneable, Remote. * Modern Alternative: Annotations.

docs.title: 17. Explain public static void main(String[] args).
docs.text:
• public: Access modifier, JVM can call it from outside.
  • static: No object needed to call it.
  • void: Returns nothing.
  • main: Identifier name the JVM looks for.
  • String[] args: Command line arguments.

docs.title: 18. Can we execute a program without main method?
docs.text: Prior to Java 7, yes, using a static block. In modern Java versions (JDK 7+), No. The JVM explicitly looks for the main method before initializing the class.

docs.title: 19. What is "Pass by Value" vs "Pass by Reference"?
docs.text:
Java is strictly Pass by Value. * For primitives, the actual value is copied. * For objects, the value of the reference (memory address) is copied. The object itself is not copied, but the new reference points to the same object.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Confusion.
    • Follow-up: "If I pass an object to a method and modify its field, does the original object change?"
    • Answer: Yes, because the copy of the reference points to the same heap object.
    • Follow-up: "If I reassign the object parameter to a new Object() inside the method, does the original reference change?"
    • Answer: No. You only changed the local copy of the reference.

docs.title: 20. What is the super keyword?
docs.text: A reference variable used to refer to the immediate parent class object. 1. Call parent constructor: super(). 2. Call parent method: super.method(). 3. Access parent field: super.field.

docs.title: 21. What is the difference between Array and ArrayList?
docs.text: Feature Array ArrayList Size Fixed Dynamic (Resizes automatically) Performance Fast (Direct index access) Slightly slower (due to resizing overhead) Primitives Can store primitives (int, char). Stores only Objects (Integer, Character). Generics No Yes

docs.title: 22. Explain the hierarchy of the Collection Framework.
docs.text:
graph TD
    Iterable --> Collection
    Collection --> List
    Collection --> Set
    Collection --> Queue
    List --> ArrayList
    List --> LinkedList
    List --> Vector
    Set --> HashSet
    Set --> LinkedHashSet
    Set --> TreeSet
    Queue --> PriorityQueue
    Queue --> Deque
(Note: Map is not part of the Collection interface hierarchy, it is separate).

docs.title: 23. List vs Set vs Map?
docs.text:
• List: Ordered collection. Allows duplicates. Accessed by index.
  • Set: Unordered collection. No duplicates.
  • Map: Key-Value pairs. Unique keys.

docs.title: 24. How does HashSet check for duplicates?
docs.text:
It uses hashCode() and equals(). 1. Calculates hash code of the object. 2. Checks if that hash code exists in the internal bucket. 3. If yes, it uses equals() to check if the objects are actually identical.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Internal implementation.
    • Follow-up: "What does HashSet use internally to store data?"
    • Answer: It uses a HashMap, storing the element as the Key and a dummy object (PRESENT) as the Value.

docs.title: 25. Explain the internal working of HashMap.
docs.text:
It uses an array of "Nodes" (buckets). Each node is a Linked List (or Red-Black Tree in Java 8+). 1. put(K, V) -> Hash(K) -> Index. 2. If bucket is empty, add Node. 3. If bucket is not empty (Collision), append to Linked List/Tree.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Java 8 Improvement.
    • Follow-up: "What changed in Java 8 regarding HashMap collisions?"
    • Answer: When a bucket's linked list grows beyond a threshold (8), it converts to a Balanced Tree (Red-Black Tree) to improve worst-case search from O(n) to O(log n).

docs.title: 26. ArrayList vs LinkedList?
docs.text:
• ArrayList: Uses a dynamic array.
    • Get: O(1)
    • Insert/Delete: O(n) (needs shifting).
  • LinkedList: Uses a doubly linked list.
    • Get: O(n) (needs traversal).
    • Insert/Delete: O(1) (pointer change, assuming you are at the node).

docs.title: 27. What is the difference between HashMap and Hashtable?
docs.text: Feature HashMap Hashtable Thread-Safe No Yes (Synchronized) Null Keys/Values Allows 1 null key, multiple null values. Does not allow nulls. Performance Fast Slow Legacy Modern Legacy (Vector/Stack/Hashtable)

docs.title: 28. What is ConcurrentHashMap?
docs.text: A thread-safe implementation of Map. Unlike Hashtable (which locks the entire map), ConcurrentHashMap uses Bucket-Level Locking (Segment locking in older versions, CAS + Synchronized on Node in Java 8+). It allows concurrent reads and writes.

docs.title: 29. What is the difference between Comparable and Comparator?
docs.text:
• Comparable: Natural ordering. Implemented by the class itself (implements Comparable<T>). Override compareTo().
    • Example: Collections.sort(list) uses this.
  • Comparator: Custom ordering. Implemented by a separate class (implements Comparator<T>). Override compare().
    • Example: Collections.sort(list, new MyComparator()).

docs.title: 30. What is a PriorityQueue?
docs.text: A queue where elements are ordered based on their priority (Natural ordering or Comparator), not insertion order. The head is always the least element. * Implementation: Binary Heap. * Time Complexity: Enqueue/Dequeue takes O(log n).

docs.title: 31. What is the contract between hashCode() and equals()?
docs.text:
1. If two objects are equal according to equals(), they MUST have the same hashCode().
  2. If two objects have the same hashCode(), they are NOT necessarily equal (Collision).

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Violation consequences.
    • Follow-up: "What goes wrong if I override equals but not hashCode?"
    • Answer: Collections relying on hashing (HashMap, HashSet) will fail to find the object because they look in the wrong bucket.

docs.title: 32. What is fail-fast vs fail-safe iterator?
docs.text:
• Fail-Fast: Throws ConcurrentModificationException if the collection is modified while iterating (except via iterator's own remove method).
    • Examples: ArrayList, HashMap iterators.
  • Fail-Safe: Works on a clone or snapshot of the collection. Does not throw exception.
    • Examples: CopyOnWriteArrayList, ConcurrentHashMap.

docs.title: 33. What are Generics?
docs.text:
Generics allow types (classes and interfaces) to be parameters when defining classes, interfaces, and methods. It provides Type Safety at compile time and eliminates manual casting.

List<String> list = new ArrayList<>();

docs.title: 34. What is Type Erasure?
docs.text: The process where the compiler removes all generic type information after type checking. At runtime, List<String> and List<Integer> become just List. * Why? Backward compatibility with pre-Java 5 code.

docs.title: 35. What is the difference between <? extends T> and <? super T>?
docs.text:
• <? extends T>: Upper Bound Wildcard. Accepts T or its subclasses. (Read-only mostly).
  • <? super T>: Lower Bound Wildcard. Accepts T or its superclasses. (Write-allowed).
  • PECS Rule: Producer Extends, Consumer Super.

docs.title: 36. Can you add an element to a List<?>?
docs.text: No (except null). Because the compiler doesn't know what type the list holds, it prevents adding any object to ensure type safety.

docs.title: 37. What is IdentityHashMap?
docs.text: A map that uses reference equality (==) instead of object equality (equals()) for keys. Useful for topology preservation in serialization.

docs.title: 38. What is WeakHashMap?
docs.text: A Map where keys are WeakReferences. If a key is no longer referenced elsewhere in the application, the entry is eligible for Garbage Collection. Useful for Caches.

docs.title: 39. How to make a collection Read-Only (Immutable)?
docs.text: Use Collections.unmodifiableList(list). * Note: It returns a view. If the original list changes, the view changes. For a truly immutable independent copy, use List.copyOf(list) (Java 10+).

docs.title: 40. Why doesn't Map extend Collection interface?
docs.text: Because Map is a key-value pair, while Collection is a group of individual objects. The methods add(E) or iterator() don't map directly to a Key-Value structure (which has put(K,V), keySet(), entrySet()).

docs.title: 41. What is the difference between Process and Thread?
docs.text:
• Process: An instance of a program in execution. Has its own memory space (Heap, Stack). Heavyweight.
  • Thread: A subset of a process. Share the same memory space (Heap) but have their own Stack. Lightweight.

docs.title: 42. How can we create a Thread in Java?
docs.text:
1. Extending Thread class.
  2. Implementing Runnable interface. (Preferred, as it allows extending other classes).
  3. Implementing Callable interface. (Returns a value).

docs.title: 43. What is the difference between start() and run()?
docs.text:
• start(): Creates a new thread and then calls run() internally.
  • run(): Just executes the method in the current thread (no new thread created).

docs.title: 44. Explain Thread Lifecycle (States).
docs.text:
1. New: Created but not started.
  2. Runnable: Ready to run (waiting for CPU).
  3. Running: Executing code.
  4. Blocked/Waiting: Waiting for resource or another thread.
  5. Terminated: Finished execution.
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> New
    New --> Runnable: start()
    Runnable --> Running: Scheduler
    Running --> Runnable: yield()
    Running --> Blocked: sleep()/wait()
    Blocked --> Runnable: notify()/time out
    Running --> Terminated: End

docs.title: 45. What is Synchronization?
docs.text: A mechanism to control access of multiple threads to shared resources to prevent data inconsistency (Race Conditions). * Method Synchronization: public synchronized void method() {} * Block Synchronization: synchronized(this) { ... }

docs.title: 46. What is a "Race Condition"?
docs.text: A condition where multiple threads access and modify shared data concurrently, and the final result depends on the order of execution (which is unpredictable).

docs.title: 47. What is Deadlock?
docs.text:
A situation where two or more threads are blocked forever, waiting for each other. * Conditions: Mutual Exclusion, Hold and Wait, No Preemption, Circular Wait.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Prevention.
    • Follow-up: "How can we prevent Deadlock?"
    • Answer: Eliminate Circular Wait by enforcing a strict order of acquiring locks.

docs.title: 48. wait() vs sleep()?
docs.text: Feature wait() sleep() Origin Object class Thread class Lock Releases the lock. Keeps the lock. Usage Inter-thread communication. Pausing execution.

docs.title: 49. What is the volatile keyword?
docs.text: It guarantees Visibility. * The value of a volatile variable will always be read from the main memory, not from the thread's local cache. * It also prevents instruction reordering. * Note: It does NOT guarantee Atomicity (e.g., count++ is not safe even if count is volatile).

docs.title: 50. What is ThreadLocal?
docs.text: A class that provides thread-local variables. Each thread accessing the variable has its own, independently initialized copy. * Usage: Storing User ID in a web request, Transaction context.

docs.title: 51. What is the Executor Framework?
docs.text: Introduced in Java 5 (java.util.concurrent). It separates task submission from task execution. * Interfaces: Executor, ExecutorService. * Implementations: ThreadPoolExecutor.

docs.title: 52. What is the difference between Runnable and Callable?
docs.text:
• Runnable: run() method returns void. Cannot throw checked exceptions.
  • Callable: call() method returns V (Result). Can throw checked exceptions.

docs.title: 53. What is a Future?
docs.text: Represents the result of an asynchronous computation. * get(): Retrieves the result (blocks if not ready). * isDone(): Checks if task is completed.

docs.title: 54. What is the difference between submit() and execute()?
docs.text:
• execute(Runnable): Defined in Executor. Returns void. Fire and forget.
  • submit(Callable/Runnable): Defined in ExecutorService. Returns a Future.

docs.title: 55. What is a "Thread Pool"?
docs.text: A collection of pre-created threads waiting for tasks. * Benefits: Reduces overhead of thread creation/destruction. Limits resource usage.

docs.title: 56. Types of Thread Pools in Executors class?
docs.text:
1. newFixedThreadPool(n): Fixed number of threads.
  2. newCachedThreadPool(): Creates new threads as needed, reuses idle ones.
  3. newSingleThreadExecutor(): Single worker thread.
  4. newScheduledThreadPool(n): For scheduled tasks.

docs.title: 57. What is CountDownLatch?
docs.text: A synchronizer that allows one or more threads to wait until a set of operations being performed in other threads completes. * Mechanism: Initialized with count N. await() blocks until count reaches 0. Other threads call countDown().

docs.title: 58. What is CyclicBarrier?
docs.text: A synchronizer that allows a set of threads to all wait for each other to reach a common barrier point. * Difference from CountDownLatch: CyclicBarrier can be reused (reset) after the barrier is broken.

docs.title: 59. What is AtomicInteger?
docs.text: A class in java.util.concurrent.atomic that provides atomic operations on int using CAS (Compare-And-Swap) machine instructions, without using synchronization. * Example: incrementAndGet() is atomic.

docs.title: 60. What is "CAS" (Compare-And-Swap)?
docs.text: An optimistic locking technique used in non-blocking algorithms. * Operation: "I think the value is A. If it is essentially A, change it to B. If not, tell me the real value and I'll try again." * Benefit: Much faster than locks (synchronized) for low contention.

docs.title: 61. Explain the JVM Memory Structure.
docs.text:
1. Heap Memory: Stores Objects and Class variables. Shared by all threads.
  2. Stack Memory: Stores method calls, local variables, and reference variables. Per-thread.
  3. Metaspace (formerly PermGen): Stores Class definitions, Method metadata, static variables.
  4. PC Register: Current instruction address.
  5. Native Method Stack: For native (C/C++) methods.
graph TD
    JVM[JVM Memory] --> Heap
    JVM --> Stack
    JVM --> Metaspace
    JVM --> PC[PC Register]
    JVM --> Native[Native Stack]
    Heap --> Young[Young Gen]
    Heap --> Old[Old Gen]
    Young --> Eden
    Young --> S0[Survivor 0]
    Young --> S1[Survivor 1]

docs.title: 62. What is Garbage Collection (GC)?
docs.text: The process by which the JVM automatically identifies and removes objects from memory (Heap) that are no longer reachable (referenced) by the application.

docs.title: 63. How does the JVM know an object is "garbage"?
docs.text: It uses Reachability Analysis. * GC Roots: Objects that are always accessible (e.g., Local variables in active stack, Static variables, Active threads). * Any object not reachable from a GC Root is considered garbage.

docs.title: 64. Explain the Generational Garbage Collection process.
docs.text:
1. New objects are created in Eden (Young Gen).
  2. When Eden fills, a Minor GC occurs. Alive objects move to Survivor Space (S0).
  3. Next Minor GC: Alive objects in Eden + S0 move to S1. S0 is cleared. S0 and S1 swap roles.
  4. Objects surviving multiple Minor GC cycles (threshold age) are promoted to Old Gen.
  5. When Old Gen fills, a Major GC (Full GC) occurs.

docs.title: 65. What are the different types of Garbage Collectors?
docs.text:
1. Serial GC: Single-threaded. (Small apps).
  2. Parallel GC: Multi-threaded for Minor GC. (Throughput-oriented).
  3. CMS (Concurrent Mark Sweep): Minimizes pause times (Deprecated).
  4. G1 GC (Garbage First): Splits heap into regions. Default in Java 9+. Balanced throughput/latency.
  5. ZGC: Ultra-low latency (<10ms).

docs.title: 66. What is a "Memory Leak" in Java?
docs.text:
A situation where objects are no longer used by the application but are still referenced (e.g., in a static List or Map), preventing the GC from removing them. Eventually leads to OutOfMemoryError.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Debugging.
    • Follow-up: "How do you detect a memory leak?"
    • Answer: Use a profiler (VisualVM, JProfiler) to analyze Heap Dumps. Look for objects with growing instance counts that shouldn't be growing.

docs.title: 67. What is StackOverflowError?
docs.text: Occurs when the Stack memory is exhausted. * Cause: Deep or infinite recursion.

docs.title: 68. What is OutOfMemoryError (OOM)?
docs.text: Occurs when the Heap (or Metaspace) is full and GC cannot free up enough space. * Types: Java heap space, Metaspace, GC Overhead limit exceeded.

docs.title: 69. What is Classloading?
docs.text: The process of finding and loading class files (.class) into the JVM memory at runtime.

docs.title: 70. Explain the Classloader Hierarchy.
docs.text:
1. Bootstrap Classloader: Loads core Java classes (rt.jar, java.lang.*). Native implementation.
  2. Platform/Extension Classloader: Loads extensions (lib/ext).
  3. Application/System Classloader: Loads classes from the classpath.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Delegation Model.
    • Follow-up: "How does the delegation model work?"
    • Answer: A classloader delegates the search to its parent first. Only if the parent cannot find it, does it try to load it itself.

docs.title: 71. What is JIT (Just-In-Time) Compiler?
docs.text: Part of the JVM execution engine. It compiles "hot" bytecode (frequently executed code) into native machine code at runtime for higher performance, while interpreting the rest.

docs.title: 72. What are Soft, Weak, and Phantom References?
docs.text:
• Strong Reference: Default (obj = new Object()). Never collected if reachable.
  • Soft Reference: Collected only if JVM is running out of memory. (Good for Caches).
  • Weak Reference: Collected aggressively at the next GC event. (Good for Metadata maps).
  • Phantom Reference: Collected when the object is physically removed. Used for scheduling post-mortem cleanup.

docs.title: 73. What is the difference between Heap and Stack memory?
docs.text: Feature Heap Stack Storage Objects Primitives, References, Methods Visibility Global (All threads) Local (Per thread) Size Large Small Speed Slower access Faster access

docs.title: 74. How do you tune JVM Memory?
docs.text: Using JVM flags: * -Xms: Initial Heap Size. * -Xmx: Maximum Heap Size. * -Xss: Stack Size per thread. * -XX:MaxMetaspaceSize: Max Metaspace size.

docs.title: 75. What is "String Interning"?
docs.text: The process of storing only one copy of each distinct string value, which must be immutable. String s = "hello" places "hello" in the String Constant Pool (in Heap). s.intern() forces a string object into the pool.

docs.title: 76. Why is finalize() deprecated?
docs.text:
1. Unpredictable: No guarantee when (or if) it will run.
  2. Performance: Adds overhead to object creation and destruction.
  3. Security: Vulnerable to "Finalizer attacks".
  4. Alternative: Use AutoCloseable (try-with-resources) or Cleaner API.

docs.title: 77. What happens if you run a recursive function without a base case?
docs.text: StackOverflowError. Each call adds a frame to the thread's stack until it hits the limit (-Xss).

docs.title: 78. What is the purpose of the transient keyword?
docs.text: It indicates that a field should not be serialized. When an object is deserialized, transient fields are initialized to their default values (null/0).

docs.title: 79. What is "Escape Analysis"?
docs.text: A JIT optimization. If an object is allocated inside a method and its reference never "escapes" that method (i.e., not returned or assigned to a global variable), the JVM might allocate it on the Stack instead of the Heap (Stack Allocation), or eliminate the allocation entirely (Scalar Replacement).

docs.title: 80. How does the JVM handle Integer Caching?
docs.text: The JVM caches Integer objects for values between -128 and 127. Integer a = 100; Integer b = 100; -> a == b is true. Integer x = 200; Integer y = 200; -> x == y is false (creates new objects).

docs.title: Part 5: Advanced Features, Frameworks & Design Patterns (81-100)
81. What is the Singleton Design Pattern?
docs.text:
A design pattern that ensures a class has only one instance and provides a global point of access to it.

// Thread-safe Bill Pugh Singleton
public class Singleton {
    private Singleton() {}
    private static class Holder {
        private static final Singleton INSTANCE = new Singleton();
    }
    public static Singleton getInstance() {
        return Holder.INSTANCE;
    }
}

docs.title: 82. What is the Factory Design Pattern?
docs.text: A creational pattern that provides an interface for creating objects in a superclass, but allows subclasses to alter the type of objects that will be created.

docs.title: 83. What is Dependency Injection (DI)?
docs.text: A design pattern used to implement IoC (Inversion of Control). It allows the creation of dependent objects outside of a class and provides those objects to a class through different ways (Constructor, Setter, Interface).

docs.title: 84. What is Reflection?
docs.text: An API that is used to examine or modify the behavior of methods, classes, and interfaces at runtime. * Uses: IDEs, Debuggers, Test Tools, Spring Framework (DI). * Drawbacks: Performance overhead, Security risk, Breaks encapsulation.

docs.title: 85. What are Java Annotations?
docs.text: Metadata about the program that is not part of the program itself. * Built-in: @Override, @Deprecated, @SuppressWarnings. * Custom: Created using @interface.

docs.title: 86. What is a Functional Interface?
docs.text: An interface with exactly one abstract method. * Annotation: @FunctionalInterface. * Purpose: Used as the assignment target for a Lambda Expression or Method Reference. * Examples: Runnable, Callable, Comparator, Predicate.

docs.title: 87. Explain Java 8 Stream API.
docs.text: A sequence of elements supporting sequential and parallel aggregate operations. * Intermediate Operations (Lazy): filter, map, sorted. * Terminal Operations (Eager): forEach, collect, reduce, count.

docs.title: 88. What is the difference between map() and flatMap()?
docs.text:
• map(): Transforms each element into another object. One-to-One.
    • List<String> -> List<Integer>
  • flatMap(): Transforms each element into a Stream of objects, then flattens the streams into a single Stream. One-to-Many.
    • List<List<String>> -> List<String>

docs.title: 89. What is Optional?
docs.text: A container object which may or may not contain a non-null value. It is used to avoid NullPointerException and explicit null checks. * Methods: isPresent(), ifPresent(), orElse(), orElseGet(), orElseThrow().

docs.title: 90. What are Default Methods in Interfaces?
docs.text:
Introduced in Java 8, they allow adding new methods to interfaces without breaking the existing implementation classes. * Keyword: default.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Diamond Problem.
    • Follow-up: "What happens if a class implements two interfaces with the same default method?"
    • Answer: The class fails to compile unless it overrides the method to resolve the conflict.

docs.title: 91. What are Java Modules (Project Jigsaw)?
docs.text: Introduced in Java 9. A module is a named, self-describing collection of code and data. * File: module-info.java. * Keywords: module, requires, exports. * Benefit: Better encapsulation (stronger than packages), reduced runtime image size (jlink).

docs.title: 92. What are Java Records?
docs.text:
Introduced in Java 14 (Preview) / 16 (Standard). A concise way to declare classes that are transparent holders for immutable data. * Replaces: POJOs with boilerplate getters, equals, hashCode, toString.

public record Point(int x, int y) {}

docs.title: 93. What is var in Java?
docs.text: Introduced in Java 10. Local Variable Type Inference. * Usage: var list = new ArrayList<String>(); * Constraint: Can only be used for local variables with an initializer. Cannot be used for method parameters or return types.

docs.title: 94. What is the difference between Serialization and Deserialization?
docs.text:
• Serialization: Converting an object state into a byte stream (to save to file/DB or send over network).
  • Deserialization: Recreating the object from the byte stream.

docs.title: 95. What is serialVersionUID?
docs.text: A unique identifier for each class version. It is used during deserialization to verify that the sender and receiver of a serialized object have loaded classes for that object that are compatible with respect to serialization.

docs.title: 96. What is the Observer Design Pattern?
docs.text: A behavioral design pattern where an object (Subject) maintains a list of its dependents (Observers), and notifies them automatically of any state changes. * Usage: Event handling systems (GUI), Pub-Sub systems.

docs.title: 97. What is Inversion of Control (IoC)?
docs.text: A principle where the control of objects or portions of a program is transferred to a container or framework. * Traditional: Application code calls Library. * IoC: Framework calls Application code (e.g., Spring calling your Controller methods).

docs.title: 98. What is AOP (Aspect Oriented Programming)?
docs.text: A programming paradigm that aims to increase modularity by allowing the separation of cross-cutting concerns (e.g., logging, transaction management, security) from the business logic.

docs.title: 99. Explain the "Double-Checked Locking" pattern.
docs.text: Used to reduce the overhead of acquiring a lock by first testing the locking criterion (the "lock hint") without actually acquiring the lock. Only if the check indicates that locking is required does the actual locking logic proceed. * Crucial: The variable must be volatile.

docs.title: 100. What is a Sealed Class?
docs.text:
Introduced in Java 15 (Preview) / 17 (Standard). It allows a class or interface to restrict which other classes or interfaces may extend or implement it. * Keywords: sealed, permits.

public sealed class Shape permits Circle, Square {}

End of Interview Questions

docs.title: JavaScript Interview Questions & Answers (100+)
docs.text: This guide contains 100+ JavaScript interview questions, ranging from basic to advanced. Each question includes a model answer, code snippets, and potential follow-up paths based on the candidate's response.

docs.title: 1. What are the different data types in JavaScript?
docs.text:
JavaScript has Primitive and Non-Primitive (Reference) types.

  • Primitives:
    1. String
    2. Number
    3. BigInt (ES2020)
    4. Boolean
    5. Undefined
    6. Null
    7. Symbol (ES6)
  • Non-Primitive:
    1. Object (includes Arrays, Functions, etc.)

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions null vs undefined.
    • Follow-up: "What is the result of typeof null?"
    • Answer: "object". This is a known bug in JavaScript that hasn't been fixed for legacy reasons.

docs.title: 2. What is the difference between var, let, and const?
docs.text:
Feature var let const Scope Function Scope Block Scope Block Scope Hoisting Yes (initialized undefined) Yes (TDZ) Yes (TDZ) Reassignable Yes Yes No Redeclarable Yes No No

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions TDZ (Temporal Dead Zone).
    • Follow-up: "Can you explain what the Temporal Dead Zone is?"
    • Answer: It's the period between the start of the block and the actual declaration of the variable. Accessing the variable during this time throws a ReferenceError.

docs.title: 3. What is Hoisting?
docs.text:
Hoisting is JavaScript's default behavior of moving declarations to the top of the current scope (script or function) during the compilation phase.

  • var: Hoisted and initialized with undefined.
  • Function Declarations: Fully hoisted (can call before definition).
  • let/const: Hoisted but not initialized (enter Temporal Dead Zone).

docs.title: 4. Explain == vs ===.
docs.text:
• == (Loose Equality): Performs Type Coercion before comparison.
  • === (Strict Equality): Checks both Value and Type.
0 == false   // true
0 === false  // false
'1' == 1     // true
'1' === 1    // false

docs.title: 5. What is Type Coercion?
docs.text:
The automatic or implicit conversion of values from one data type to another (e.g., string to number).

  • Implicit: 1 + '2' -> '12'
  • Explicit: Number('2')

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate discusses truthy/falsy.
    • Follow-up: "Is [] truthy or falsy?"
    • Answer: Truthy. But [] == false is true (coercion fun).

docs.title: 6. What is NaN?
docs.text:
It stands for "Not-a-Number". It is a value of the Number type. It results from invalid math operations (e.g., Math.sqrt(-1), 'a' * 1).

Properties: * NaN === NaN is false. * Use Number.isNaN(value) to check.

docs.title: 7. What are the Falsy values in JavaScript?
docs.text:
There are 6 falsy values (plus false itself): 1. false 2. 0 (and -0, 0n) 3. "" (Empty string) 4. null 5. undefined 6. NaN

Everything else is Truthy (e.g., [], {}, "0", "false").

docs.title: 8. What is the difference between null and undefined?
docs.text:
• undefined: A variable has been declared but not assigned a value. It is the default value of uninitialized variables/parameters.
  • null: Represents the intentional absence of any object value. It is an assignment value.

docs.title: 9. Explain strict mode ('use strict').
docs.text: Strict mode is a way to opt in to a restricted variant of JavaScript. Benefits: 1. Eliminates some silent errors by throwing them. 2. Fixes mistakes that make it difficult for engines to perform optimizations. 3. Prohibits some syntax likely to be defined in future versions. Example: Prevents accidental global variables (x = 3.14 throws error if x not declared).

docs.title: 10. How do you check the type of a variable?
docs.text:
Using the typeof operator.

typeof "John" // "string"
typeof 3.14   // "number"
typeof {}     // "object"
typeof []     // "object"
typeof (() => {}) // "function"

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate notes typeof array is object.
    • Follow-up: "How do you specifically check if a variable is an Array?"
    • Answer: Array.isArray(variable) or variable instanceof Array.

docs.title: 11. What is the difference between Function Declaration and Function Expression?
docs.text:
• Declaration: function foo() {}. Hoisted (can be called before defined).
  • Expression: const foo = function() {}. Not hoisted (behaves like variable).

docs.title: 12. What is an IIFE (Immediately Invoked Function Expression)?
docs.text:
A function that runs as soon as it is defined. Used to create a local scope and avoid polluting the global namespace.

(function() {
    var secret = "I am safe here";
})();

docs.title: 13. What is the difference between call, apply, and bind?
docs.text:
All three allow you to control the value of this inside a function.

Method Syntax Execution call func.call(thisObj, arg1, arg2) Immediately apply func.apply(thisObj, [argArray]) Immediately bind const newFunc = func.bind(thisObj) Returns new function

docs.title: 14. What is this keyword?
docs.text: this refers to the object that is executing the current function. * Global Context: window (browsers) or global (Node). * Object Method: The object itself. * Event Handler: The element that received the event. * Arrow Function: Lexical this (inherits from outer scope).

docs.title: 15. What are Arrow Functions?
docs.text: A concise syntax for writing function expressions. Key Differences: 1. No own this (lexical scoping). 2. No arguments object. 3. Cannot be used as constructors (new fails).

docs.title: 16. What is a Callback Function?
docs.text: A function passed into another function as an argument, which is then invoked inside the outer function to complete some kind of routine or action.

docs.title: 17. What is Scope?
docs.text: Scope determines the accessibility (visibility) of variables. 1. Global Scope: Accessible everywhere. 2. Function Scope: Accessible only within the function. 3. Block Scope: (let, const) Accessible only within the block {}.

docs.title: 18. What is a Closure?
docs.text:
A closure is the combination of a function bundled together (enclosed) with references to its surrounding state (the lexical environment). In other words, a closure gives you access to an outer function’s scope from an inner function.

function makeAdder(x) {
  return function(y) {
    return x + y;
  };
}
const add5 = makeAdder(5);
console.log(add5(2)); // 7

docs.title: 19. Explain the module pattern.
docs.text: A design pattern used to wrap a set of variables and functions together in a single scope. It is used to define private and public access levels (encapsulation) using closures (often IIFEs).

docs.title: 20. What is "Currying"?
docs.text:
Currying is the process of converting a function that takes multiple arguments into a sequence of functions that each take a single argument.

const add = a => b => a + b;
add(1)(2); // 3

docs.title: 21. What is the Prototype Chain?
docs.text: In JavaScript, objects have a special hidden property [[Prototype]] (exposed as __proto__). If you access a property that doesn't exist on the object, JS looks for it on the prototype, then the prototype's prototype, until it reaches null. This chain is used for inheritance.

docs.title: 22. What is the difference between __proto__ and prototype?
docs.text:
• __proto__: The actual object that is used in the lookup chain to resolve methods, etc. (exists on instances).
  • prototype: The object that will be used as the __proto__ of instances created when using new Constructor(). (exists on functions).

docs.title: 23. How do you create an object in JavaScript?
docs.text:
1. Object Literal: const o = {}
  2. Constructor: const o = new Object()
  3. Object.create(): const o = Object.create(proto)
  4. Class (ES6): new MyClass()

docs.title: 24. What is Object.freeze() vs Object.seal()?
docs.text:
• Object.freeze(): Totally immutable. Cannot add, remove, or modify properties.
  • Object.seal(): Cannot add or remove properties, but can modify existing property values.

docs.title: 25. How do you check if a key exists in an object?
docs.text:
1. "key" in obj (Check prototype chain too)
  2. obj.hasOwnProperty("key") (Check own properties only)
  3. Object.hasOwn(obj, "key") (Modern, safer version of hasOwnProperty)

docs.title: 26. What are the primitive wrapper objects?
docs.text: String, Number, Boolean. They allow you to access properties/methods on primitives (e.g., "hello".toUpperCase()). JS temporarily wraps the primitive in an object, calls the method, and discards the object.

docs.title: 27. What is Destructuring Assignment?
docs.text:
A syntax that makes it possible to unpack values from arrays, or properties from objects, into distinct variables.

const user = { id: 42, isVerified: true };
const { id, isVerified } = user;

docs.title: 28. What is the Spread Operator (...)?
docs.text:
It expands an iterable (like an array or string) into more elements.

const arr1 = [1, 2];
const arr2 = [...arr1, 3, 4]; // [1, 2, 3, 4]
Also used for Object spread (shallow copy/merge).

docs.title: 29. What is the Rest Parameter (...)?
docs.text:
It allows a function to accept an indefinite number of arguments as an array.

function sum(...args) {
    return args.reduce((a, b) => a + b);
}

docs.title: 30. Explain Shallow Copy vs Deep Copy.
docs.text:
• Shallow Copy: Copies the object, but nested objects are still references to the original. ({...obj}, Object.assign()).
  • Deep Copy: Recursively copies everything. (JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(obj)) or structuredClone()).

docs.title: 31. What is the difference between map and forEach?
docs.text:
• map(): Returns a new array. Used to transform data.
  • forEach(): Returns undefined. Used for side effects.

docs.title: 32. How does reduce() work?
docs.text:
Executes a reducer function on each element of the array, resulting in a single output value.

const sum = [1, 2, 3].reduce((acc, curr) => acc + curr, 0);

docs.title: 33. What is filter()?
docs.text: Creates a new array with all elements that pass the test implemented by the provided function.

docs.title: 34. What are Higher-Order Functions?
docs.text: Functions that take other functions as arguments or return functions as their result. (e.g., map, filter, setTimeout).

docs.title: 35. What is the difference between slice() and splice()?
docs.text:
• slice(start, end): Returns a new array (shallow copy). Does not modify original.
  • splice(start, count, ...items): Removes/Adds items. Modifies the original array.

docs.title: 36. What is a Set?
docs.text:
A collection of values where each value must be unique.

const unique = [...new Set([1, 2, 2, 3])]; // [1, 2, 3]

docs.title: 37. What is a Map vs Object?
docs.text: Feature Map Object Keys Any type (incl. objects) Strings & Symbols Order Insertion order Not guaranteed (historically) Size .size property Manually count Iteration Directly iterable Object.keys(), etc.

docs.title: 38. What is a WeakMap?
docs.text: A Map where keys must be objects and are held "weakly". If the key object is not referenced elsewhere, it can be garbage collected. Not iterable.

docs.title: 39. How do you sort an array of numbers?
docs.text:
[1, 10, 2].sort() sorts alphabetically by default -> [1, 10, 2]. Correct way: 

[1, 10, 2].sort((a, b) => a - b); // [1, 2, 10]

docs.title: 40. What is Array.from()?
docs.text:
Creates a new Array instance from an array-like or iterable object (e.g., NodeList, arguments, String).

Array.from('foo'); // ["f", "o", "o"]

docs.title: 41. What is the Event Loop?
docs.text:
JavaScript is single-threaded. The Event Loop monitors the Call Stack and the Callback Queue. If the Call Stack is empty, it takes the first event from the queue and pushes it to the stack.

Diagram: 

graph TD
    CallStack[Call Stack] -->|Execute| API[Web APIs]
    API -->|Callback| Queue[Callback Queue]
    Queue -->|Event Loop| CallStack

docs.title: 42. Explain Synchronous vs Asynchronous.
docs.text:
• Synchronous: Code executes line-by-line, blocking execution until completion.
  • Asynchronous: Code executes without blocking (e.g., timers, network requests), providing a callback or promise to handle the result later.

docs.title: 43. What is a Promise?
docs.text: An object representing the eventual completion (or failure) of an asynchronous operation and its resulting value. States: 1. Pending 2. Fulfilled (Resolved) 3. Rejected

docs.title: 44. What are the instance methods of a Promise?
docs.text:
1. .then(onSuccess, onFailure)
  2. .catch(onFailure)
  3. .finally(onAlways)

docs.title: 45. Explain Promise.all() vs Promise.allSettled().
docs.text:
• Promise.all(iterable): Waits for all to resolve. Rejects immediately if any promise rejects (fail-fast).
  • Promise.allSettled(iterable): Waits for all to finish (resolve or reject). Returns an array of status objects.

docs.title: 46. What is Promise.race()?
docs.text: Returns a promise that resolves or rejects as soon as one of the promises in the iterable resolves or rejects.

docs.title: 47. Explain async and await.
docs.text:
Syntactic sugar built on top of Promises to write asynchronous code that looks synchronous. * async function returns a Promise. * await pauses execution until the Promise resolves.

async function fetchData() {
    try {
        const response = await fetch('/api');
        const data = await response.json();
    } catch (error) {
        console.error(error);
    }
}

docs.title: 48. What happens if you await a non-promise?
docs.text: It is converted to a resolved Promise automatically. const x = await 5; // x is 5

docs.title: 49. Can you use await inside a loop?
docs.text: Yes. * forEach: async callbacks run in parallel (doesn't wait). * for...of: await inside pauses the loop (sequential execution).

docs.title: 50. What is a Microtask vs Macrotask?
docs.text:
• Microtasks: Promises, queueMicrotask, MutationObserver. (High priority, run immediately after current script).
  • Macrotasks: setTimeout, setInterval, setImmediate, I/O. (Run in next Event Loop tick).

Execution Order: Script -> All Microtasks -> Render -> One Macrotask.

docs.title: 51. What is the output?
docs.text:
console.log(1);
setTimeout(() => console.log(2), 0);
Promise.resolve().then(() => console.log(3));
console.log(4);
Answer: 1, 4, 3, 2 (Sync -> Sync -> Microtask -> Macrotask).

docs.title: 52. What is setTimeout?
docs.text: Schedules code to be run after a specified delay (in ms). It is not part of JS engine, but a Web API provided by the browser/Node environment.

docs.title: 53. Why is setTimeout(fn, 0) useful?
docs.text: It pushes the function to the end of the Call Stack (to the task queue), allowing the UI to update or the current execution to finish first.

docs.title: 54. What is Callback Hell?
docs.text: The situation where callbacks are nested within other callbacks several levels deep, making code difficult to read and maintain. Solution: Use Promises or Async/Await.

docs.title: 55. What is fetch API?
docs.text: A modern interface for making HTTP requests (replacement for XMLHttpRequest). It returns a Promise.

docs.title: 56. How do you cancel a fetch request?
docs.text:
Using an AbortController.

const controller = new AbortController();
fetch(url, { signal: controller.signal });
controller.abort(); // Cancels request

docs.title: 57. What is JSON.parse and JSON.stringify?
docs.text:
• JSON.parse(): Parses a JSON string to a JS object.
  • JSON.stringify(): Converts a JS object to a JSON string.

docs.title: 58. What is debouncing?
docs.text:
Ensures that a function is not called again until a certain amount of time has passed since it was last called. (e.g., search input).

function debounce(func, delay) {
    let timeout;
    return (...args) => {
        clearTimeout(timeout);
        timeout = setTimeout(() => func(...args), delay);
    };
}

docs.title: 59. What is throttling?
docs.text: Ensures that a function is called at most once in a specified time period. (e.g., window resize, scroll).

docs.title: 60. What is a Generator Function in async context?
docs.text: Generators (function*) can yield Promises. Before async/await, libraries like co used generators to mimic sync-style async code.

docs.title: 61. What is the DOM?
docs.text: Document Object Model. A tree structure representation of the HTML document. It allows JS to manipulate content, structure, and style.

docs.title: 62. How to select elements in DOM?
docs.text:
• document.getElementById('id')
  • document.getElementsByClassName('class')
  • document.getElementsByTagName('div')
  • document.querySelector('.class') (Returns first match)
  • document.querySelectorAll('.class') (Returns NodeList)

docs.title: 63. NodeList vs HTMLCollection?
docs.text:
• HTMLCollection: Live (updates automatically if DOM changes). Returned by getElementsByClassName.
  • NodeList: Static (mostly). Returned by querySelectorAll.

docs.title: 64. What is Event Bubbling?
docs.text: When an event triggers on an element, it first runs the handlers on it, then on its parent, then all the way up on other ancestors. (Bottom -> Up).

docs.title: 65. What is Event Capturing (Trickling)?
docs.text: The opposite of bubbling. The event goes down to the element. (Top -> Down). Enabled by passing { capture: true } to addEventListener.

docs.title: 66. How to stop propagation?
docs.text: event.stopPropagation() stops the event from moving to the next part of the propagation flow (bubbling or capturing).

docs.title: 67. What is event.preventDefault()?
docs.text: Prevents the browser's default behavior for the event (e.g., prevents form submission, or link navigation).

docs.title: 68. What is Event Delegation?
docs.text:
Instead of attaching event listeners to individual elements, you attach a single listener to a common parent. It utilizes event bubbling to handle events for child elements (even dynamically added ones).

document.getElementById('list').addEventListener('click', (e) => {
    if (e.target.tagName === 'LI') {
        console.log('List item clicked');
    }
});

docs.title: 69. What is the dataset property?
docs.text:
Allows access to custom data attributes (data-*) on elements.

<div id="user" data-id="123" data-role="admin"></div>
<script>
    const el = document.getElementById('user');
    console.log(el.dataset.id); // "123"
</script>

docs.title: 70. innerHTML vs innerText vs textContent?
docs.text:
• innerHTML: Parses HTML string (Security risk: XSS).
  • innerText: Visible text (aware of CSS styling like display: none).
  • textContent: All text (including hidden elements). Faster.

docs.title: 71. What is the BOM (Browser Object Model)?
docs.text: Objects provided by the browser to interact with everything outside the page content. Examples: window, navigator, location, history, screen.

docs.title: 72. How do you detect the browser name?
docs.text: navigator.userAgent. (Though feature detection is preferred over browser detection).

docs.title: 73. What is localStorage vs sessionStorage?
docs.text:
• localStorage: Data persists even after the browser is closed. (No expiration).
  • sessionStorage: Data survives page refresh but is cleared when the tab/window is closed.

docs.title: 74. What are Cookies?
docs.text: Small data stored in the browser. Sent with every HTTP request to the server. Properties: Expires, HttpOnly (secure against XSS), Secure (HTTPS only).

docs.title: 75. How to create a new DOM element?
docs.text: document.createElement('tagName').

docs.title: 76. What is a DocumentFragment?
docs.text: A lightweight, minimal document object. It has no parent. Appending to it doesn't cause reflow. Appending the fragment to DOM moves all its children. Used for performance optimization when adding multiple elements.

docs.title: 77. What is Reflow and Repaint?
docs.text:
• Reflow (Layout): Calculating positions and geometries of elements. (Expensive).
  • Repaint: Changing visibility (color, background) without changing layout.

docs.title: 78. What is Shadow DOM?
docs.text: Encapsulation mechanism. Allows a hidden DOM tree to be attached to an element. Styles inside Shadow DOM don't leak out, and global styles don't leak in. Basis of Web Components.

docs.title: 79. What is window.onload vs DOMContentLoaded?
docs.text:
• DOMContentLoaded: HTML is parsed and DOM is built. (External scripts/styles might not be loaded).
  • window.onload: Everything is loaded (images, styles, scripts).

docs.title: 80. How does defer and async work in script tags?
docs.text:
• <script>: Blocks parsing, fetches, executes.
  • <script async>: Fetches in parallel, executes as soon as fetched (pauses parsing). Order not guaranteed.
  • <script defer>: Fetches in parallel, executes after HTML parsing is complete. Order guaranteed.

docs.title: 81. What is a Class in ES6?
docs.text:
Syntactic sugar over prototype-based inheritance.

class Person {
    constructor(name) { this.name = name; }
    greet() { return `Hi, ${this.name}`; }
}

docs.title: 82. What are Modules (ESM)?
docs.text: Official standard for modules. * export (Named or Default). * import. * File-based scope. Always strict mode.

docs.title: 83. What are Template Literals?
docs.text: String literals allowing embedded expressions. Enclosed by backticks (`). Supports multi-line strings.

docs.title: 84. What is the Optional Chaining Operator (?.)?
docs.text:
Safely access nested properties. Returns undefined if reference is nullish.

const zip = user?.address?.zipCode;

docs.title: 85. What is the Nullish Coalescing Operator (??)?
docs.text:
Returns the right-hand operand when the left is null or undefined (not just falsy).

const x = 0 ?? 5; // 0
const y = 0 || 5; // 5

docs.title: 86. What is a Symbol?
docs.text: A unique and immutable primitive. Often used as object keys to create private-like properties or avoid name collisions.

docs.title: 87. What is a Proxy?
docs.text:
An object that wraps another object and intercepts operations (like read, write, function call).

const handler = {
    get: (obj, prop) => prop in obj ? obj[prop] : "Not Found"
};
const p = new Proxy({}, handler);

docs.title: 88. What is Reflect?
docs.text: A built-in object that provides methods for interceptable JavaScript operations. Complements Proxy.

docs.title: 89. What is Memory Leak in JS?
docs.text: When objects are no longer needed but are still referenced, preventing Garbage Collection. Causes: Global variables, forgotton timers, closures, detached DOM nodes.

docs.title: 90. How does Garbage Collection work?
docs.text: Mark-and-Sweep: 1. Roots (Global, Stack) are marked. 2. References are traversed and marked. 3. Unmarked objects (unreachable) are swept (deleted).

docs.title: 91. What is BigInt?
docs.text: A primitive for integers larger than 2^53 - 1. Created by appending n. const huge = 1234567890123456789012345678901234567890n;

docs.title: 92. What is globalThis?
docs.text: A standard way to access the global object across environments (window, self, global).

docs.title: 93. What is Currying vs Partial Application?
docs.text:
• Currying: f(a, b, c) -> f(a)(b)(c).
  • Partial App: f(a, b, c) -> g(b, c) (where a is fixed).

docs.title: 94. What is Memoization?
docs.text: Optimization technique. Caching the result of an expensive function call based on arguments and returning the cached result when the same inputs occur again.

docs.title: 95. What is the difference between for...in and for...of?
docs.text:
• for...in: Iterates over keys (enumerable properties). (Works on Objects).
  • for...of: Iterates over values. (Works on Iterables: Array, Map, Set, String).

docs.title: 96. What is TCO (Tail Call Optimization)?
docs.text: An optimization where a recursive function call is the last action in the function. The engine reuses the stack frame. (Supported in Safari, theoretically in ES6 spec).

docs.title: 97. What is a Polyfill?
docs.text: Code that implements a feature on web browsers that do not support the feature.

docs.title: 98. What is Transpilation (Babel)?
docs.text: Converting modern JS (ES6+) code into older JS (ES5) to ensure compatibility with older browsers.

docs.title: 99. What are Worker Threads (Web Workers)?
docs.text: Allow running scripts in background threads, separate from the main execution thread. Prevents UI blocking during heavy computations. They don't have access to DOM.

docs.title: 100. What is Server-Side Rendering (SSR) vs Client-Side Rendering (CSR)?
docs.text:
• CSR: Browser downloads minimal HTML and a JS bundle. JS fetches data and builds the UI. (Slower initial load, faster interaction).
  • SSR: Server renders HTML with data and sends it. (Faster initial load, SEO friendly).

End of Interview Questions

docs.title: Kotlin Interview Questions & Answers (100+)
docs.text: This guide contains 100+ Kotlin interview questions, ranging from basic syntax to advanced concurrency and coroutines. Each question includes a model answer, code examples, and potential follow-up paths based on the candidate's response.

docs.title: 1. What is the difference between val and var?
docs.text:
• val: Immutable reference. Once assigned, it cannot be reassigned. (Similar to final in Java).
  • var: Mutable reference. Can be reassigned.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions 'Immutable'.

    • Follow-up: "Does val mean the object itself is immutable?"
    • Answer: No, val only guarantees the reference is immutable. If the object is a MutableList, you can still add items to it.

  • Path B: Candidate compares to Java.

    • Follow-up: "When would you prefer val over var?"
    • Answer: Always prefer val for thread safety and predictability, unless mutation is strictly required.

docs.title: 2. How does Kotlin handle Null Safety?
docs.text:
Kotlin's type system distinguishes between references that can hold null (nullable references) and those that cannot (non-null references).

Syntax Name Description String Non-nullable Cannot hold null. Compiler error if assigned null. String? Nullable Can hold null.

Key Operators: * ?. (Safe Call) * !! (Not-null Assertion) * ?: (Elvis Operator)

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions !!.
    • Follow-up: "When is it acceptable to use !!?"
    • Answer: Rarely. Only when you are 100% sure the value is not null and the compiler can't deduce it, or in quick prototypes/tests. It throws a NullPointerException if null.

docs.title: 3. What is the Elvis Operator ?:?
docs.text:
It returns the expression on its left if it is not null, otherwise it returns the expression on its right.

val length = text?.length ?: -1

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Control flow.
    • Follow-up: "Can you use return or throw on the right side of ?:?"
    • Answer: Yes, because return and throw are expressions in Kotlin. 
      val name = user.name ?: throw IllegalArgumentException("Name required")

docs.title: 4. What is Type Inference?
docs.text:
The compiler can automatically identify the data type of a variable from the context or the assigned value.

val name = "Kotlin" // Compiler knows this is String

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Limitations.
    • Follow-up: "When must you explicitly specify the type?"
    • Answer: When declaring a variable without initializing it immediately, or when the inferred type is not the desired one (e.g., Long vs Int).

docs.title: 5. What is the difference between const val and val?
docs.text:
• val: Read-only variable, determined at runtime.
  • const val: Compile-time constant. Must be a top-level property or a member of an object (or companion object). Only primitives and String.

docs.title: 6. What are String Templates?
docs.text:
Strings that contain expressions beginning with $.

val i = 10
println("i = $i")
println("i + 1 = ${i + 1}")

docs.title: 7. Explain lateinit vs lazy.
docs.text:
Feature lateinit lazy Mutability var (Mutable) val (Read-only) Type Non-primitive types only Any type Initialization Later in code On first access Thread Safety Not thread-safe by default Thread-safe (synchronized) by default

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Use cases.
    • Follow-up: "Why use lateinit in Android?"
    • Answer: For dependency injection or View initialization in onCreate where you can't initialize at declaration but know it won't be null when used.

docs.title: 8. What are Data Classes?
docs.text:
Classes whose main purpose is to hold data. The compiler automatically derives the following members: * equals() / hashCode() * toString() * componentN() functions (for destructuring) * copy()

data class User(val name: String, val age: Int)

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Inheritance.
    • Follow-up: "Can a Data Class be open or abstract?"
    • Answer: No, data classes are final by default and cannot be open or abstract.

docs.title: 9. What is the difference between == and ===?
docs.text:
• ==: Structural equality. Checks if contents are equal (calls equals()).
  • ===: Referential equality. Checks if variables point to the same object in memory.

docs.title: 10. How does the when expression work?
docs.text:
It replaces the switch operator of C-like languages but is more powerful. It can be used as a statement or an expression.

val result = when (x) {
    1 -> "One"
    in 2..10 -> "Between 2 and 10"
    is String -> "It's a string"
    else -> "Unknown"
}

docs.title: 11. How do loops work in Kotlin?
docs.text:
• For: Iterates over anything that provides an iterator. 
    for (item in collection) print(item)
  • While / Do-While: Standard conditional loops.

docs.title: 12. What are Range Expressions?
docs.text:
Tools to define a range of values.

val r1 = 1..10        // 1 to 10 inclusive
val r2 = 1 until 10   // 1 to 9
val r3 = 10 downTo 1  // 10 to 1
val r4 = 1..10 step 2 // 1, 3, 5, 7, 9

docs.title: 13. How do you define a function?
docs.text:
fun sum(a: Int, b: Int): Int {
    return a + b
}
// Single-expression syntax
fun sum(a: Int, b: Int) = a + b

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Default Arguments.
    • Follow-up: "How do default arguments help compared to Java?"
    • Answer: They reduce the need for method overloading.

docs.title: 14. What are Extension Functions?
docs.text:
They allow you to add new functionality to a class without inheriting from it or using design patterns like Decorator.

fun String.removeFirstLastChar(): String =  this.substring(1, this.length - 1)

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Under the hood.
    • Follow-up: "Does it actually modify the class?"
    • Answer: No, it resolves statically. It's syntactic sugar for a static method that takes the instance as the first parameter.

docs.title: 15. What are Infix Functions?
docs.text:
Functions marked with infix keyword can be called using infix notation (omitting the dot and the parentheses). * Must be member functions or extension functions. * Must have a single parameter.

infix fun Int.plus(x: Int): Int = this + x
// Usage
1 plus 2

docs.title: 16. Explain Classes and Objects in Kotlin.
docs.text: Classes are declared using class. Objects can be: * Object Declaration: Singleton. * Object Expression: Anonymous class.

docs.title: 17. What are the Visibility Modifiers?
docs.text:
• public (Default): Visible everywhere.
  • private: Visible inside file (top-level) or class.
  • protected: Visible in class and subclasses.
  • internal: Visible within the same module.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Internal.
    • Follow-up: "What constitutes a 'module'?"
    • Answer: A Maven/Gradle module, or an IntelliJ IDEA module.

docs.title: 18. Primary vs Secondary Constructors.
docs.text:
• Primary: Part of the class header.
  • Secondary: Prefixed with constructor. Must delegate to the primary constructor (directly or indirectly) using this().

docs.title: 19. How does Inheritance work?
docs.text:
All classes inherit from Any. Classes are final by default. To allow inheritance, mark the class with open.

open class Base(p: Int)
class Derived(p: Int) : Base(p)

docs.title: 20. How are Interfaces different in Kotlin compared to Java 7?
docs.text:
Kotlin interfaces can contain properties and functions with default implementations. They cannot store state.

interface MyInterface {
    val prop: Int // abstract
    fun foo() { print("Default impl") }
}

docs.title: 21. What is the difference between an Abstract Class and an Interface?
docs.text: Feature Abstract Class Interface State Can hold state (fields). Cannot hold state (only properties without backing fields). Constructor Can have constructors. Cannot have constructors. Inheritance Single inheritance. Multiple implementation. Use Case Is-A relationship, sharing state. Can-Do relationship, behavior contract.

docs.title: 22. What are Sealed Classes?
docs.text:
sealed classes represent restricted class hierarchies. All direct subclasses must be known at compile time and declared in the same package (and same module).

Use Case: Perfect for when expressions, ensuring all cases are covered without an else branch.

sealed class Result
data class Success(val data: String) : Result()
data class Error(val exception: Exception) : Result()
object Loading : Result()

docs.title: 23. What is an Object Declaration?
docs.text:
It is Kotlin's way of defining a Singleton.

object DatabaseConfig {
    val url = "jdbc:..."
}
The initialization is thread-safe and lazy (on first access).

docs.title: 24. What is a Companion Object?
docs.text:
An object declared inside a class using the companion keyword. * It is tied to the class, not instances. * Similar to static members in Java. * Can implement interfaces.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Access.
    • Follow-up: "How do you access members of a companion object?"
    • Answer: Simply by using the class name: MyClass.create().

docs.title: 25. What are the requirements for a Data Class?
docs.text:
1. Primary constructor must have at least one parameter.
  2. All primary constructor parameters must be marked as val or var.
  3. Cannot be abstract, open, sealed, or inner.

docs.title: 26. Explain Class Delegation (by keyword).
docs.text:
Kotlin supports the "composition over inheritance" pattern natively. A class can implement an interface by delegating all of its public members to a specified object.

interface Base { fun print() }
class BaseImpl(val x: Int) : Base {
    override fun print() = print(x)
}
class Derived(b: Base) : Base by b

docs.title: 27. What are Higher-Order Functions?
docs.text:
A function that takes another function as a parameter and/or returns a function.

fun calculate(x: Int, y: Int, operation: (Int, Int) -> Int): Int {
    return operation(x, y)
}

docs.title: 28. What is a Lambda Expression?
docs.text:
An anonymous function that can be treated as a value. Syntax: { variable(s) -> body }

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: 'it' keyword.
    • Follow-up: "When can you use it?"
    • Answer: When a lambda has exactly one parameter, you can omit the parameter declaration and refer to it as it.

docs.title: 29. What are Inline Functions?
docs.text:
Using higher-order functions imposes runtime penalties (object allocation for lambdas). The inline modifier tells the compiler to copy the function's code (and the lambda) directly into the call site.

Pros: Performance boost for loop-heavy high-order functions. Cons: Code size increases.

docs.title: 30. What is noinline and crossinline?
docs.text:
• noinline: Used in an inline function to prevent a specific lambda parameter from being inlined.
  • crossinline: Used when a lambda is passed to an inline function but executed in a different context (e.g., inside a nested object or local function), disallowing non-local returns.

docs.title: 31. What are Reified Type Parameters?
docs.text:
In Java, generics are erased at runtime (Type Erasure). In Kotlin, you can use inline functions with reified type parameters to access the type at runtime.

inline fun <reified T> isType(value: Any) = value is T

docs.title: 32. Explain Scope Functions (let, run, with, apply, also).
docs.text:
They execute a block of code within the context of an object.

Function Object Reference Return Value Use Case let it Lambda result Null checks, temporary scope. run this Lambda result Object configuration + computation. with this Lambda result Grouping calls on an object. apply this Object itself Object configuration (builder). also it Object itself Side effects (logging, validation). 
graph TD
    A[Start] --> B{Returns Object?}
    B -- Yes --> C{Ref is 'this'?}
    B -- No --> D{Ref is 'this'?}
    C -- Yes --> E[apply]
    C -- No --> F[also]
    D -- Yes --> G[run / with]
    D -- No --> H[let]

docs.title: 33. What are Destructuring Declarations?
docs.text:
A way to unpack a single composite value into multiple variables.

val (name, age) = user // user must be data class or have componentN functions

docs.title: 34. What is Operator Overloading?
docs.text:
Kotlin allows providing custom implementations for a predefined set of operators (+, -, *, ++, etc.) on user-defined types. You must use the operator modifier.

data class Point(val x: Int, val y: Int) {
    operator fun plus(p: Point) = Point(x + p.x, y + p.y)
}

docs.title: 35. What are Type Aliases?
docs.text:
Provide alternative names for existing types. Useful for shortening long generic types.

typealias NodeSet = Set<Network.Node>
typealias MyHandler = (Int, String, Any) -> Unit

docs.title: 36. Nested vs Inner Classes.
docs.text:
• Nested Class: By default, a class inside another class does not have access to the members of the outer class. (Static nested in Java).
  • Inner Class: Marked with inner. Has reference to the outer class object. Can access members.

docs.title: 37. What are Anonymous Inner Classes?
docs.text:
Created using object expressions.

window.addMouseListener(object : MouseAdapter() {
    override fun mouseClicked(e: MouseEvent) { ... }
})

docs.title: 38. What is SAM Conversion?
docs.text:
Single Abstract Method. Kotlin allows passing a lambda for a Java interface that has only one abstract method. Example: Runnable, Callable, OnClickListener.

button.setOnClickListener { view -> ... } // Lambda instead of object implementation

docs.title: 39. What is a Tail Recursive Function?
docs.text: A recursive function where the recursive call is the last operation performed. Marked with tailrec. The compiler optimizes this into a loop, preventing StackOverflowError.

docs.title: 40. What is a Functional Interface?
docs.text:
An interface with exactly one abstract method. Marked with fun interface.

fun interface IntPredicate {
    fun accept(i: Int): Boolean
}
val isEven = IntPredicate { it % 2 == 0 }

docs.title: 41. What are Coroutines?
docs.text: Coroutines are light-weight threads. They allow writing asynchronous code in a sequential manner. They are suspendable computations: they can suspend their execution without blocking the underlying thread.

docs.title: 42. Difference between launch and async.
docs.text: Feature launch async Return Returns a Job. Returns a Deferred<T>. Result Fire and forget. No result. Promise of a result later. Exception Crashes application if unhandled. Stored inside Deferred, thrown on .await().

docs.title: 43. What is runBlocking?
docs.text: It runs a new coroutine and blocks the current thread interruptibly until its completion. Use Case: Mainly for main functions and tests. Avoid in production UI code.

docs.title: 44. What is a Suspend Function?
docs.text: A function marked with suspend modifier. It can suspend the execution of a coroutine without blocking the thread. * Can only be called from a coroutine or another suspend function.

docs.title: 45. CoroutineScope vs CoroutineContext.
docs.text:
• CoroutineScope: Defines the scope for new coroutines. It manages the lifecycle (cancellation) of coroutines.
  • CoroutineContext: A set of elements that define the behavior of a coroutine (Job, Dispatcher, Name, ExceptionHandler).

docs.title: 46. Explain Dispatchers.
docs.text:
They determine which thread(s) the coroutine runs on.

  • Dispatchers.Main: UI thread (Android).
  • Dispatchers.IO: Optimized for disk/network IO (Thread pool).
  • Dispatchers.Default: Optimized for CPU-intensive work (Thread pool size = CPU cores).
  • Dispatchers.Unconfined: Starts in current thread, resumes in whatever thread called resume.

docs.title: 47. What is Job vs Deferred?
docs.text:
• Job: A handle to a background task with a lifecycle (Active, Cancelled, Completed).
  • Deferred: A generic subclass of Job that holds a result. It adds await() to retrieve the value.

docs.title: 48. What is Structured Concurrency?
docs.text: A paradigm where new coroutines can only be launched in a specific CoroutineScope. This ensures: 1. Children inherit context from parents. 2. Parent waits for all children to complete. 3. If parent is cancelled, all children are cancelled. 4. If a child fails, the parent (and other children) are cancelled.

docs.title: 49. How do you handle exceptions in Coroutines?
docs.text:
• try-catch: Inside the coroutine body.
  • CoroutineExceptionHandler: Context element to handle uncaught exceptions (only works on root coroutines launched with launch).
  • SupervisorJob / supervisorScope: Prevents failure propagation to the parent.

docs.title: 50. supervisorScope vs coroutineScope.
docs.text:
• coroutineScope: If one child fails, the scope fails and cancels all other children.
  • supervisorScope: If one child fails, it does not affect other children or the scope itself.

Diagram: Failure Propagation

graph TD
    A[Parent] --> B[Child 1 (Fails)]
    A --> C[Child 2]
    B -- "With coroutineScope" --> A
    A -- "Cancels" --> C
    B -- "With supervisorScope" --> X[Handled locally]
    A -. "Unaffected" .- C

docs.title: 51. What are Channels?
docs.text: Primitives for communication between coroutines. They provide a way to transfer a stream of values. * Logically similar to BlockingQueue. * Support send (suspend) and receive (suspend).

docs.title: 52. Explain Flow (Cold Stream) vs Channel (Hot Stream).
docs.text:
• Flow: Cold. Code inside flow { ... } does not run until collect() is called. Each collector gets its own execution.
  • Channel: Hot. Values are produced even if no one is listening.

docs.title: 53. StateFlow vs SharedFlow.
docs.text:
• StateFlow: A hot flow that holds state. Always has an initial value. Only emits the last known value to new collectors. (Replacement for LiveData).
  • SharedFlow: Highly configurable hot flow. Can emit events without state (no initial value). Can replay n values to new collectors.

docs.title: 54. What are buffer, conflate, and collectLatest?
docs.text:
• buffer(): Buffers emissions if collector is slow.
  • conflate(): Skips intermediate values if collector is slow, only processing the latest.
  • collectLatest(): Cancels the current block if a new value arrives.

docs.title: 55. How to handle Backpressure in Flows?
docs.text: Flows support backpressure by default because they use suspending functions. If the collector is slow, the emitter suspends.

docs.title: 56. Thread vs Coroutine?
docs.text:
• Thread: OS-managed resource. Expensive (~1MB stack). Context switching is costly.
  • Coroutine: User-space managed. Cheap (Objects). Thousands can run on one thread.

docs.title: 57. What is a Mutex?
docs.text: Mutual Exclusion. A locking primitive for coroutines. Unlike synchronized (which blocks the thread), Mutex.withLock suspends the coroutine.

docs.title: 58. What is an Actor?
docs.text: An entity made up of a coroutine, the state that is confined and encapsulated into this coroutine, and a channel to communicate with other coroutines. Note: The actor builder is currently obsolete in Kotlin Coroutines API favor of complex channels or other primitives, but the concept remains.

docs.title: 59. What is the select expression?
docs.text:
It waits for the result of multiple suspending functions simultaneously and selects the first one that becomes available.

select<Unit> {
    channelA.onReceive { ... }
    channelB.onReceive { ... }
}

docs.title: 60. How do you test Coroutines?
docs.text: Using kotlinx-coroutines-test library. * runTest: Replaces runBlocking for tests. Skips delays (virtual time). * StandardTestDispatcher: default for runTest. * UnconfinedTestDispatcher.

docs.title: 61. List vs MutableList.
docs.text:
• List<T>: Read-only interface. No add, remove, set.
  • MutableList<T>: Modifiable interface. Extends List.

docs.title: 62. map, filter, and reduce.
docs.text:
• map: Transforms each element.
  • filter: Returns elements matching a predicate.
  • reduce: Accumulates value starting with the first element.

docs.title: 63. What is flatMap?
docs.text:
Transforms each element into an Iterable and then flattens these iterables into a single list.

val list = listOf("abc", "def")
list.flatMap { it.toList() } // ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e', 'f']

docs.title: 64. What does zip do?
docs.text:
Combines two collections into a list of pairs.

val a = listOf(1, 2)
val b = listOf("A", "B")
a.zip(b) // [(1, "A"), (2, "B")]

docs.title: 65. Difference between fold and reduce.
docs.text:
• reduce: Uses the first element as the initial accumulator value. Throws exception on empty collection.
  • fold: Takes an explicit initial value. Works on empty collections.

docs.title: 66. Sequence vs Iterable (List).
docs.text:
• Iterable (List): Eager evaluation. Each step (map, filter) creates a new intermediate list.
  • Sequence: Lazy evaluation. Operations are vertical (element by element) rather than horizontal (step by step). No intermediate collections. Better for huge data sets.

docs.title: 67. How does groupBy work?
docs.text:
Returns a Map where keys are the grouping criteria and values are lists of original elements.

val words = listOf("a", "abc", "ab", "def", "abcd")
val byLength = words.groupBy { it.length }
// {1=[a], 3=[abc, def], 2=[ab], 4=[abcd]}

docs.title: 68. What is partition?
docs.text: Splits the collection into a pair of lists based on a predicate. * First list: Elements that match. * Second list: Elements that don't match.

docs.title: 69. any, all, and none.
docs.text:
• any: True if at least one matches.
  • all: True if all match.
  • none: True if no elements match.

docs.title: 70. What is associateBy?
docs.text: Creates a Map using elements as values and a key derived from the element. Risk: If keys are duplicates, the last one wins.

docs.title: 71. distinct vs toSet.
docs.text: Both return unique elements. * toSet(): Converts to a Set. * distinct(): Returns a List containing only distinct elements.

docs.title: 72. Arrays: IntArray vs Array<Int>.
docs.text:
• IntArray: Primitive int[] in JVM. Unboxed. Efficient.
  • Array<Int>: Object Integer[] in JVM. Boxed. More memory overhead.

docs.title: 73. String Manipulation.
docs.text: Strings are immutable. * trimMargin(): Removes whitespace. * split(): Returns List. * replace(): Returns new String.

docs.title: 74. Comparable vs Comparator.
docs.text:
• Comparable: Interface implemented by the class itself (compareTo). Defines natural order.
  • Comparator: External object that defines specific ordering (compare).

docs.title: 75. Why use the copy method in Data Classes?
docs.text: To create a new instance with some properties modified, while keeping others the same. Essential for immutability patterns.

docs.title: 76. Range iterators: until vs downTo.
docs.text:
• until: Excludes the end value. 1 until 10 (1..9).
  • downTo: Descending order. 10 downTo 1.

docs.title: 77. What is coerceIn?
docs.text:
Ensures a value is within a specific range.

val x = 15.coerceIn(0, 10) // Returns 10

docs.title: 78. How to measure execution time?
docs.text: measureTimeMillis { ... } or measureTime { ... } (requires kotlin.time).

docs.title: 79. How to generate Random numbers?
docs.text: Since Kotlin 1.3: Random.nextInt(from, until). Avoid java.util.Random in pure Kotlin code for multiplatform support.

docs.title: 80. Regular Expressions in Kotlin.
docs.text: Create using Regex("pattern"). * matchEntire() * find() * replace()

docs.title: 81. Explain JvmStatic, JvmOverloads, JvmField.
docs.text: Interoperability annotations. * @JvmStatic: Generates a real static method in the bytecode. * @JvmOverloads: Generates overloads for functions with default arguments. * @JvmField: Exposes a property as a public field (no getters/setters).

docs.title: 82. What is Kotlin Multiplatform (KMP)?
docs.text: A way to share code between platforms (Android, iOS, Web, Desktop). * Common code: Business logic. * Platform code: UI, Hardware access.

docs.title: 83. What is expect / actual mechanism?
docs.text: Used in KMP. * expect: Defined in common module. Declares "I need this functionality". * actual: Defined in platform modules (Android, iOS). Provides implementation.

docs.title: 84. Reflection in Kotlin.
docs.text: Inspects classes, properties, and functions at runtime. Requires kotlin-reflect.jar. Syntax: MyClass::class, ::myFunction.

docs.title: 85. KAPT vs KSP.
docs.text:
• KAPT: Kotlin Annotation Processing Tool. Runs Java annotation processors. Slow (generates Java stubs).
  • KSP: Kotlin Symbol Processing. Native to Kotlin. Faster.

docs.title: 86. Dependency Injection (Concept).
docs.text:
• Koin: Service Locator pattern (DSL). Pure Kotlin. No code generation. Runtime check.
  • Dagger/Hilt: Dependency Injection pattern. Compile-time generation. Strict.

docs.title: 87. What is ViewBinding?
