docs.text: Generates a binding class for each XML layout file. Replaces findViewById. Null-safe and Type-safe.

docs.title: 88. What is Jetpack Compose?
docs.text: Modern toolkit for building native UI in Android using Kotlin. * Declarative: You describe the UI state, framework updates the view. * Functions: UI components are functions annotated with @Composable.

docs.title: 89. Memory Management (JVM).
docs.text: Kotlin on JVM uses the JVM Garbage Collector. * Heap: Objects. * Stack: Primitives, references.

docs.title: 90. What is a value class (Inline Class)?
docs.text:
Wraps a single value. At runtime, instances are represented by the underlying value (unboxed) where possible, avoiding object allocation.

@JvmInline
value class Password(val s: String)

docs.title: 91. What is Type Erasure?
docs.text: Generics are checked at compile time but removed (erased) at runtime. List<String> becomes just List (or raw List). Solution: Reified type parameters (inline functions).

docs.title: 92. Covariance and Contravariance (in vs out).
docs.text:
• out T (Covariant): Producer. Can only read T. Equivalent to ? extends T in Java. List<out Number> can hold List<Int>.
  • in T (Contravariant): Consumer. Can only write T. Equivalent to ? super T in Java. Comparable<in Number> can accept Double.

docs.title: 93. What is Star Projection *?
docs.text: Generic type with unknown argument. * MutableList<*>: Safe to read as Any?, but unsafe to write (except Nothing).

docs.title: 94. What is the Nothing type?
docs.text: A type that has no values. Represents "a value that never exists". * Used as return type for functions that always throw exceptions. * Subtype of all types.

docs.title: 95. What is the Unit type?
docs.text: Corresponds to void in Java. It is a real object (singleton).

docs.title: 96. What are Contracts?
docs.text: Let you describe the relationship between function parameters and return values/effects to the compiler. * Example: require(x != null) tells the compiler x is non-null afterwards.

docs.title: 97. What are Context Receivers?
docs.text:
(Experimental) Allows a function to have multiple receivers.

context(LoggingContext, DatabaseContext)
fun storeUser(user: User) { ... }

docs.title: 98. Kotlin Scripting (.kts).
docs.text: Kotlin code that can run as a script without compilation to a .jar. Used in Gradle Kotlin DSL.

docs.title: 99. Gradle Kotlin DSL.
docs.text: Writing build.gradle.kts using Kotlin instead of Groovy. * Pros: Autocomplete, Refactoring, Type safety. * Cons: Slower initial build (compilation).

docs.title: 100. What is the K2 Compiler?
docs.text:
The new Kotlin compiler frontend. * Faster compilation. * Better type inference. * Foundation for future language features.

End of Interview Questions

docs.title: Protocol Buffers Interview Questions & Answers (100+)
docs.text: This guide contains 100+ Protocol Buffers (Protobuf) interview questions, ranging from core concepts to advanced wire format encoding and gRPC integration. Each question includes a model answer and potential follow-up paths based on the candidate's response.

docs.title: 1. What is Protocol Buffers (Protobuf)?
docs.text:
Protocol Buffers is a language-neutral, platform-neutral, extensible mechanism for serializing structured data. It was developed by Google. You define how you want your data to be structured once (in .proto files), and then you can use generated source code to easily write and read your structured data to and from a variety of data streams and using a variety of languages.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Comparison with XML/JSON.
    • Follow-up: "Why would you choose it over JSON for a public REST API?"
    • Answer: You might not. JSON is better for human readability and browser consumption. Protobuf is better for internal microservices or performance-critical mobile clients.

docs.title: 2. Compare Protobuf vs. XML vs. JSON.
docs.text: Feature Protobuf JSON XML Format Binary Text (Human Readable) Text (Human Readable) Size Smallest Medium Largest Speed Fastest (Parsing/Serialization) Medium Slow Schema Required (.proto) Optional (JSON Schema) Optional (XSD) Typing Strong Loose Loose/Strong (with XSD)

docs.title: 3. What are the key benefits of using Protocol Buffers?
docs.text:
1. Performance: Smaller message size and faster processing (parsing/serialization) compared to text-based formats.
  2. Language Interoperability: Supports C++, Java, Python, Go, Ruby, C#, etc.
  3. Backward/Forward Compatibility: Fields can be added or removed without breaking old binaries.
  4. Schema Enforcement: The structure is defined and enforced by the compiler.

docs.title: 4. What is a .proto file?
docs.text:
It is a text file that contains the schema definition for the data structures (messages) and services. It uses the Protocol Buffers Interface Description Language (IDL).

syntax = "proto3";

message Person {
  string name = 1;
  int32 id = 2;
  string email = 3;
}

docs.title: 5. What are the main differences between proto2 and proto3?
docs.text:
• Field Presence: proto2 has required, optional, and repeated. proto3 removed required and optional (fields are optional by default and have default values).
  • Default Values: proto2 allows explicit default values (default = 5). proto3 uses zero values (0, empty string, false).
  • Enums: proto3 enums must start with a zero value (usually UNKNOWN).
  • Extensions: proto2 supports extensions. proto3 mostly replaced them with Any.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate complains about missing required.
    • Follow-up: "Why did Google remove required fields?"
    • Answer: Required fields harm backward compatibility. If a field stops being required in the logic but the schema says required, old consumers will crash if it's missing.

docs.title: 6. Why should you avoid required fields in proto2?
docs.text: If you ever wish to stop sending a required field, or if you want to rename it or effectively remove it, it becomes a breaking change. Any client reading the message that expects the field will fail to parse the message if it is missing. This makes evolving the schema extremely difficult.

docs.title: 7. What are "Tags" (Field Numbers) in Protobuf?
docs.text: Each field in the message definition has a unique numbered tag (e.g., string name = 1;). * These numbers are used to identify fields in the binary message wire format. * They must not change once your message type is in use.

docs.title: 8. Why are field numbers 1 through 15 more efficient?
docs.text: Field numbers 1-15 take one byte to encode (including the field number and wire type). Field numbers 16-2047 take two bytes. * Optimization Tip: Use 1-15 for very frequently occurring fields.

docs.title: 9. What basic data types are supported in Protobuf?
docs.text:
• Integers: int32, int64, uint32, uint64, sint32, sint64 (signed), fixed32, fixed64.
  • Floating Point: float, double.
  • Boolean: bool.
  • Strings: string (UTF-8), bytes (arbitrary byte arrays).

docs.title: 10. How does Protobuf handle Backward Compatibility?
docs.text:
• New Fields: Old code reads new data -> It ignores (or stores as unknown) the new fields.
  • Deleted Fields: Old code reads data missing the deleted field -> It sees the default value.
  • Rule: Never reuse a field tag number.

docs.title: 11. What is the generated code?
docs.text: The protoc compiler generates classes for your specific language (e.g., Person.java, person_pb2.py). * These classes provide builders, accessors (getters/setters), and methods to serialize/parse (toByteArray(), parseFrom()).

docs.title: 12. Can you modify a field's type without breaking compatibility?
docs.text: Generally No, with exceptions: * int32, uint32, int64, uint64, and bool are compatible (can be changed to each other, though values might be truncated). * string and bytes are compatible if the bytes are valid UTF-8. * Changing int32 to string will break parsing.

docs.title: 13. What is the repeated keyword?
docs.text:
It indicates that the field can be repeated any number of times (including zero). It is dynamically sized, similar to a List or Array. 

repeated string phone_numbers = 4;

docs.title: 14. What are "Unknown Fields"?
docs.text: Fields present in the parsed data that the parser does not recognize (e.g., from a newer version of the schema). * Proto2: Preserved in the message and re-serialized. * Proto3 (Early): Discarded. * Proto3 (Modern): Preserved (since version 3.5+).

docs.title: 15. Is Protobuf self-describing?
docs.text: No. Unlike XML or JSON, a Protobuf binary message does not contain field names, only tag numbers. You must have the .proto definition (schema) to decode the data meaningfully.

docs.title: 16. What is the default value for an int32 field in Proto3?
docs.text: 0. * There is no distinction between "0 was explicitly set" and "the field was missing" in the wire format (for scalar types in Proto3).

docs.title: 17. How do you distinguish between missing field and default value in Proto3?
docs.text: For scalar types (int, bool), you cannot by default. * Solution: Use wrapper types (e.g., google.protobuf.Int32Value) or the optional keyword (available in newer Proto3) which generates a presence bit.

docs.title: 18. What is the syntax statement?
docs.text: The first non-empty, non-comment line of the .proto file. * syntax = "proto3"; * If omitted, the compiler assumes proto2.

docs.title: 19. Can you comment in .proto files?
docs.text: Yes. * // Single line comment * /* Multi-line comment */

docs.title: 20. How are bytes different from string?
docs.text:
• string: Must contain valid UTF-8 text.
  • bytes: Can contain arbitrary binary data (e.g., an image, an encrypted payload).

docs.title: 21. How do you define a package?
docs.text:
package tutorial;
* Helps prevent name clashes between different projects. * In Java, creates a package directory structure (unless java_package option is used). * In C++, generates a namespace.

docs.title: 22. What are imports in Protobuf?
docs.text:
Used to use definitions from other .proto files. 

import "google/protobuf/timestamp.proto";

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Public Imports.
    • Follow-up: "What does import public do?"
    • Answer: It forwards the import. Any file importing the current file also gets the transitive public imports.

docs.title: 23. Explain "Nested Types".
docs.text:
You can define a message inside another message. 

message SearchResponse {
  message Result {
    string url = 1;
  }
  repeated Result results = 1;
}
* Referenced outside as SearchResponse.Result.

docs.title: 24. How do you define an Enum?
docs.text:
enum Corpus {
  CORPUS_UNSPECIFIED = 0; // Proto3 requires 0 value
  CORPUS_UNIVERSAL = 1;
  CORPUS_WEB = 2;
}

docs.title: 25. Can Enums share values (Aliases)?
docs.text:
Yes, if you set the allow_alias option. 

enum EnumAllowingAlias {
  option allow_alias = true;
  UNKNOWN = 0;
  STARTED = 1;
  RUNNING = 1; // Alias to STARTED
}

docs.title: 26. What is a map in Protobuf?
docs.text:
Associative arrays (key-value pairs). 

map<string, Project> projects = 3;
* Keys: integers, bools, strings. (No floats, no enums). * Values: Any type except another map. * On the wire, maps are equivalent to a repeated message containing key and value fields.

docs.title: 27. What is oneof?
docs.text:
A set of fields where only one can be set at a time. Setting one field clears the others. Saves memory. 

message Profile {
  oneof avatar {
    string image_url = 1;
    bytes image_data = 2;
  }
}

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Repeated in oneof.
    • Follow-up: "Can you have repeated fields inside a oneof?"
    • Answer: No.

docs.title: 28. What are reserved fields?
docs.text:
If you delete a field, you should reserve its tag number (and name) to prevent future users from accidentally reusing it and causing corruption with old data. 

message Foo {
  reserved 2, 15, 9 to 11;
  reserved "foo", "bar";
}

docs.title: 29. What happens if you define two fields with the same tag number?
docs.text: The protoc compiler will throw an error and fail to generate code. Tags must be unique within a message.

docs.title: 30. What is java_multiple_files option?
docs.text:
option java_multiple_files = true;
* False (Default): Generates a single outer class containing all messages as inner static classes. * True: Generates separate .java files for each message/enum. Better for large projects.

docs.title: 31. What is the deprecated option?
docs.text:
int32 old_field = 1 [deprecated = true];
* Marks the field as deprecated. Generated code will often have annotations (like @Deprecated in Java) to warn developers.

docs.title: 32. How do you handle Date and Time in Protobuf?
docs.text:
Do not use string (e.g., ISO-8601) or int64 (seconds) directly if you want standard interoperability. Use Well Known Types: 

import "google/protobuf/timestamp.proto";
// ...
google.protobuf.Timestamp last_updated = 1;

docs.title: 33. What is the Any type?
docs.text:
Allows you to embed a message without having its .proto definition at compile time. 

import "google/protobuf/any.proto";
message ErrorStatus {
  string message = 1;
  repeated google.protobuf.Any details = 2;
}
* Internally stores the byte data and a Type URL string.

docs.title: 34. How do you define a Service in Protobuf?
docs.text:
Used for RPC (Remote Procedure Call) systems like gRPC. 

service SearchService {
  rpc Search (SearchRequest) returns (SearchResponse);
}

docs.title: 35. Can a field be both repeated and optional?
docs.text: In proto3, repeated implies a list (0 to N). optional implies presence tracking (0 or 1). They are mutually exclusive.

docs.title: 36. What is the best practice for naming fields?
docs.text:
• Field Names: snake_case (e.g., song_name).
  • Message Names: CamelCase (e.g., SongRequest).
  • Enums: CAPS_WITH_UNDERSCORES.
  • Reason: The generated code converts these to the language-specific standard (e.g., getSongName() in Java, SongName property in C#).

docs.title: 37. Can you default a map field?
docs.text: No. Map fields cannot have default values explicitly defined, and they are never null (an empty map is the default).

docs.title: 38. How to update an Enum?
docs.text:
• You can add new values.
  • Be careful: If an old client receives a new enum value it doesn't know, it treats it as an unknown integer value (in Proto3) or discards it (in older Proto2).
  • Always preserve the numeric values.

docs.title: 39. What is a "wrapper type"?
docs.text: Types in google/protobuf/wrappers.proto (e.g., StringValue, Int32Value). * They wrap primitives in a Message. * Allows distinction between "null" (message not present) and default value (0 or "").

docs.title: 40. Can you inherit from other messages?
docs.text: No. Protobuf does not support inheritance. You must use Composition (nesting messages).

docs.title: 41. Explain Base 128 Varints.
docs.text: Variable-length integers. * Uses 1 byte for small numbers, more bytes for large numbers. * The MSB (Most Significant Bit) of each byte indicates if there are more bytes to follow (1 = yes, 0 = last byte). * Example: The number 1 is 0000 0001. The number 300 takes two bytes.

docs.title: 42. How is a field encoded (Key-Value)?
docs.text: A field in the stream is a Key followed by a Value. * Key = (field_number << 3) | wire_type. * The last 3 bits store the wire type.

docs.title: 43. What are the Wire Types?
docs.text: Type Name Meaning Used For 0 Varint Variable length int32, int64, bool, enum 1 64-bit Fixed 8 bytes fixed64, double 2 Length-delimited Length + Bytes string, bytes, messages, packed repeated 3 Start Group (Deprecated) Groups (Proto2) 4 End Group (Deprecated) Groups (Proto2) 5 32-bit Fixed 4 bytes fixed32, float

docs.title: 44. Why does int32 encode negative numbers inefficiently?
docs.text: In standard Varint encoding, negative numbers are sign-extended to 64 bits (even for int32), resulting in 10 bytes on the wire.

docs.title: 45. What is ZigZag Encoding?
docs.text: Used by sint32 and sint64 types. * It maps signed integers to unsigned integers so that small absolute values (like -1, -2) become small unsigned values. * -1 -> 1, 1 -> 2, -2 -> 3. * Makes encoding negative numbers efficient.

docs.title: 46. What is the difference between int32 and sint32?
docs.text:
• int32: Uses standard Varint. Good for positive numbers. Bad for negative (always 10 bytes).
  • sint32: Uses ZigZag Varint. Good for mixed positive/negative numbers.

docs.title: 47. How are Strings encoded?
docs.text: Wire Type 2 (Length-delimited). Format: [Tag] [Length Varint] [UTF-8 Bytes].

docs.title: 48. How are nested messages encoded?
docs.text: Also Wire Type 2. * The value is simply the serialized byte stream of the inner message. * Allows "lazy parsing" (decoding the outer message without parsing the inner one immediately).

docs.title: 49. What is "Packed Encoding"?
docs.text: Used for repeated fields of scalar numeric types (proto3 default). * Unpacked: [Tag][Value] [Tag][Value] [Tag][Value] (Repeats Tag overhead). * Packed: [Tag][Length][Value][Value][Value] (Tag appears once). Saves space.

docs.title: 50. How does a decoder know when a message ends?
docs.text:
It doesn't. * Protobuf messages are not self-delimiting. * If you write multiple messages to a single file/stream, you must implement a framing protocol (e.g., write the length of the message before the message itself).

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Use writeDelimitedTo.
    • Follow-up: "Is that standard across languages?"
    • Answer: Most Java/C++ libs support it, but it's not strictly part of the wire format spec, just a common utility.

docs.title: 51. Is the wire format order deterministic?
docs.text: No. * Fields can appear in any order. * Unknown fields might be interspersed. * Maps have no defined order. * Implication: You cannot compare two binary blobs for equality to check if messages are equal. You must parse and compare.

docs.title: 52. What is Canonical Encoding?
docs.text: A deterministic serialization approach (e.g., sorting map keys, sorting field tags) sometimes used for hashing signatures, but standard Protobuf libraries do not guarantee this by default.

docs.title: 53. How much space does a boolean take?
docs.text:
• 1 Byte for the tag (if field number < 16).
  • 1 Byte for the value (0 or 1).
  • Total: 2 Bytes.

docs.title: 54. Can you decode a proto3 message using a proto2 schema?
docs.text: Partially. The wire format is mostly compatible. * Proto3 specific types (like Map or Packed repeated fields) might cause issues if the Proto2 schema doesn't define them correctly (though packed=true exists in proto2). * Missing required fields in the input (from proto3 source) will cause proto2 parsers to fail.

docs.title: 55. What happens if the wire type doesn't match the schema?
docs.text: The parser generally throws an exception or marks it as a parse error. * Example: Expecting Varint (Type 0) but finding Length-delimited (Type 2).

docs.title: 56. How is fixed32 different from int32 on the wire?
docs.text:
• int32: Varint encoded (1-5 bytes typically).
  • fixed32: Always 4 bytes.
  • Use Case: fixed32 is better if values are usually very large (random IDs, hashes) where Varint would take 5 bytes.

docs.title: 57. How do Maps look on the wire?
docs.text:
A map map<K, V> field = N is serialized as a repeated message of a virtual entry message: 

message MapEntry {
  K key = 1;
  V value = 2;
}
repeated MapEntry field = N;

docs.title: 58. What is the limit on message size?
docs.text:
• Theoretical: 2GB (due to signed 32-bit integer limits in many implementations like Java/C++).
  • Practical: Default limits are often set to 64MB to prevent DOS attacks (OOM). Can be increased via API.

docs.title: 59. Does Protobuf compress data?
docs.text: No. It uses efficient binary encoding (removing whitespace, using varints), which results in small sizes, but it does not use compression algorithms like GZIP or LZW. * Tip: You can GZIP the resulting binary protobuf for further reduction.

docs.title: 60. How does field reordering affect the wire format?
docs.text: It doesn't. * If you change the order of fields in the .proto file (e.g., move id = 1 below name = 2), the wire format depends only on the Tag Number, not the line number in the file.

docs.title: 61. What is protoc?
docs.text: The Protocol Buffer Compiler. * Input: .proto files. * Output: Generated code (C++, Java, Python, etc.).

docs.title: 62. How do you compile a python file?
docs.text: protoc --python_out=. my_proto.proto

docs.title: 63. What is a "Builder" in Java generated code?
docs.text:
Protobuf messages in Java are Immutable. * To create or modify a message, you must use the generated Builder class. 

Person p = Person.newBuilder().setName("Jules").build();

docs.title: 64. How do you merge two messages?
docs.text:
Builders support merging. 

builder.mergeFrom(otherMessage);
* Singular fields: Overwritten by otherMessage. * Repeated fields: Concatenated.

docs.title: 65. Does Protobuf support inheritance in generated code?
docs.text: No. * Generated classes extend GeneratedMessageV3. * They do not support extending your own custom classes to add logic. * Reason: Preserves the "Data Object" nature and serialization guarantees.

docs.title: 66. How to print a message for debugging?
docs.text:
• toString(): Returns a human-readable text format representation.
  • Do not use this for parsing/serialization logic, only for logging.

docs.title: 67. Can you convert Protobuf to JSON?
docs.text: Yes. JsonFormat (Java) or MessageToJson (Python) util classes are provided by the library. * It converts field names to JSON keys. * It handles Enums as strings.

docs.title: 68. What is protoc-gen-go?
docs.text: The plugin for Go language support. protoc itself doesn't support Go natively out of the box in the main binary; it delegates to this plugin.

docs.title: 69. How does Python dynamic nature affect Protobuf?
docs.text: Python code generated by protoc is often just descriptors. The actual message classes are created dynamically at runtime (metaclasses) in newer versions, using C++ extensions for speed.

docs.title: 70. What is the option optimize_for?
docs.text:
option optimize_for = CODE_SIZE;
* SPEED (Default): Generates optimized code for serializing/parsing. Larger class files. * CODE_SIZE: Generates minimal classes that rely on shared reflection-based code. Slower, but smaller binary. * LITE_RUNTIME: Generates classes that only depend on the "Lite" library (no descriptors/reflection). Good for mobile.

docs.title: 71. How do you check if a field is set in Proto3 (Java)?
docs.text:
• Message fields: hasField().
  • Scalar fields: You can't (unless using optional keyword). You only check if value != 0.

docs.title: 72. What are "Well Known Types"?
docs.text: A set of .proto definitions provided by Google that cover common use cases. * Timestamp, Duration * StringValue, BoolValue (Wrappers) * FieldMask * Struct (JSON Object)

docs.title: 73. What is FieldMask?
docs.text: Used in Update/Patch RPCs. * Lists which fields the client wants to update. * Allows distinct updates (e.g., update only 'email', leave 'name' alone) even if the object has both.

docs.title: 74. How does reflection work in Protobuf?
docs.text: You can traverse a message without knowing its type at compile time. * Descriptors: Describe the schema (MessageDescriptor, FieldDescriptor). * Reflection Interface: Get value by FieldDescriptor.

docs.title: 75. How to write a custom protoc plugin?
docs.text: A plugin is an executable that accepts a CodeGeneratorRequest (protobuf message) from standard input and writes a CodeGeneratorResponse to standard output. * Can be written in any language (Python/Go are popular).

docs.title: 76. What is Struct type?
docs.text: google.protobuf.Struct. * Represents a dynamic JSON object. * Maps strings to Value (which can be number, string, list, struct, etc.). * Useful when data structure is not known at compile time (loss of type safety).

docs.title: 77. Handling Polymorphism?
docs.text: Since there is no inheritance, use: 1. Oneof: If types are known. 2. Any: If types are open-ended.

docs.title: 78. What is DescriptorSet?
docs.text: A file containing the parsed schema information (descriptors) of .proto files. * Generated via protoc --descriptor_set_out=file.pb. * Used by tools (like grpcurl) to understand messages without source code.

docs.title: 79. How to handle huge messages?
docs.text: Protobuf loads the entire message into memory. * Solution: Don't use a single huge message. Use a stream of smaller messages or split data into chunks.

docs.title: 80. Dependency Management?
docs.text: protoc needs import paths (-I or --proto_path). * Complex projects use tools like Buf to manage dependencies and linting.

docs.title: 81. How does gRPC relate to Protobuf?
docs.text: gRPC is an RPC framework. Protobuf is the default: 1. IDL: Defines the service and messages. 2. Serialization: Encodes the payload on the wire.

docs.title: 82. Can gRPC use JSON?
docs.text: Yes, but it's not the default. You can use gRPC-Web or custom codecs, but you lose the performance benefits of Protobuf.

docs.title: 83. What are the 4 types of gRPC methods?
docs.text:
1. Unary: Simple Request -> Response.
  2. Server Streaming: Request -> Stream of Responses.
  3. Client Streaming: Stream of Requests -> Response.
  4. Bidirectional Streaming: Stream -> Stream (Async).

docs.title: 84. Why is Protobuf faster than JSON?
docs.text:
1. Size: Binary is compact (Varints, no field names). Less bandwidth.
  2. Parsing: CPU efficient. No text scanning/tokenizing. It's mostly reading bytes and jumping pointers.

docs.title: 85. What is "Zero-Copy" parsing?
docs.text: Some C++ implementations (like StringPiece or Cord) allow the protobuf parser to point directly to the raw byte buffer for string/byte fields instead of copying memory.

docs.title: 86. How to validate Protobuf messages?
docs.text:
Protobuf ensures type safety, not value validity (e.g., email format, age > 0). * Solution: Use PGV (Protoc Gen Validate). Annotate fields in .proto: 

string email = 1 [(validate.rules).string.email = true];

docs.title: 87. What is Schema Registry?
docs.text: In systems like Kafka, a Schema Registry stores the .proto definitions (versioned). * Producers send ID + Binary Data. * Consumers fetch Schema by ID to decode. * Decouples producers and consumers.

docs.title: 88. Protobuf Text Format vs JSON?
docs.text: Protobuf has its own text format (looks like the .proto default values). * name: "Jules" id: 42 * Used for config files or debugging. Not valid JSON.

docs.title: 89. How to handle breaking changes safely?
docs.text:
1. Create a new field string name_v2 = 5;.
  2. Deprecate old field name.
  3. Dual-write to both in application logic.
  4. Migrate readers to name_v2.
  5. Stop writing name.

docs.title: 90. What is Arena Allocation (C++)?
docs.text: A memory management optimization. * Allocates a large block of memory (Arena) upfront. * All message objects are allocated from this block. * Freeing the Arena frees everything at once. * Reduces malloc/free overhead and improves cache locality.

docs.title: 91. Explain "Unknown Fields" attack vector.
docs.text: If a server acts as a proxy (Read -> Modify -> Write), and it preserves unknown fields: * Attacker sends a malicious payload in an "unknown field". * Server verifies known fields (checks pass). * Server forwards message to a vulnerable internal service that does understand the field.

docs.title: 92. Deterministic Serialization options.
docs.text: Required for things like hashing a message to sign it. * Proto3 C++ has MessageDifferencer and serialization options to force map sorting. * Generally, don't rely on binary equality.

docs.title: 93. Is Protobuf encrypted?
docs.text: No. It is just an encoding format. If you need security, you must encrypt the transport (TLS/SSL) or the payload field (bytes encrypted_data = 1).

docs.title: 94. Comparison with FlatBuffers?
docs.text: Feature Protobuf FlatBuffers Parsing Decoding step required (unpack to object). No parsing (Zero-copy access). Memory Allocates objects. Reads directly from buffer. Use Case Microservices, Storage. Games, Real-time (no GC/alloc overhead).

docs.title: 95. Comparison with Apache Avro?
docs.text: Feature Protobuf Avro Schema Explicitly generated code. Schema stored with data (usually). Ecosystem Google/Microservices/gRPC. Hadoop/Big Data/Kafka. Evolution Tag numbers. Schema resolution rules.

docs.title: 96. What is the files field in FileDescriptorSet?
docs.text: It contains a list of FileDescriptorProto messages, representing the parsed content of each .proto file (including dependencies).

docs.title: 97. How to exclude a field from JSON output?
docs.text: Use json_name option? No, usually fields are included. * Some JSON Printers have options to printingDefaultValues or ignoringUnknownFields. * To hide it, you might need a separate "DTO" proto.

docs.title: 98. Custom Options?
docs.text:
You can define your own options to annotate files, messages, or fields. 

extend google.protobuf.FieldOptions {
  bool my_option = 50000;
}
string name = 1 [(my_option) = true];
* Access these via Reflection at runtime.

docs.title: 99. Performance: String vs Bytes?
docs.text:
• string requires UTF-8 validation during parsing and serialization.
  • bytes is raw copy.
  • If you have ASCII data or don't care about encoding validation, bytes is slightly faster.

docs.title: 100. Naming convention for repeated fields?
docs.text:
Usually plural. * repeated string phone_numbers = 1; * Generated Java: getPhoneNumbersList(), getPhoneNumbers(index).

End of Interview Questions

docs.title: Python Interview Questions & Answers (100+)
docs.text: This guide contains 100+ Python interview questions, ranging from basic to advanced. Each question includes a model answer, code snippets, and potential follow-up paths based on the candidate's response.

docs.title: 1. What is the difference between list and tuple?
docs.text:
Feature List Tuple Mutability Mutable (can change) Immutable (cannot change) Syntax [] () Performance Slower (overhead for resizing) Faster (fixed size) Use Case Collections of items that change Constant data, Dictionary keys

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions Mutability.

    • Follow-up: "Can a tuple contain a mutable object (like a list) and can that object be modified?"
    • Answer: Yes. t = (1, [2, 3]). You can modify t[1] because the tuple only stores the reference to the list, which doesn't change, even if the list content does.

  • Path B: Candidate focuses on Syntax.

    • Follow-up: "How do you create a tuple with a single element?"
    • Answer: You must use a trailing comma: t = (1,). Without it, Python interprets it as an integer in parentheses (1).

docs.title: 2. How is memory managed in Python?
docs.text:
Python uses a private heap containing all Python objects and data structures. The management of this private heap is ensured internally by the Python Memory Manager.

Key mechanisms: 1. Reference Counting: Objects are deallocated when their reference count drops to zero. 2. Garbage Collection: Handles cyclic references that reference counting cannot catch.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions Garbage Collection (GC).
    • Follow-up: "When does the Garbage Collector run?"
    • Answer: It runs periodically based on thresholds (generations 0, 1, 2). It can also be triggered manually using gc.collect().

docs.title: 3. What is PEP 8?
docs.text:
PEP 8 is the style guide for Python code. It ensures consistency and readability. Key rules: * Indentation: 4 spaces. * Line Length: 79 characters. * Variable Names: snake_case for functions/variables, CamelCase for classes.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate is familiar.
    • Follow-up: "How do you check your code against PEP 8 automatically?"
    • Answer: Using linters like flake8, pylint, or formatters like black (which is opinionated but compliant).

docs.title: 4. What are the key features of Python?
docs.text:
• Interpreted: Executed line by line.
  • Dynamically Typed: Type checks happen at runtime.
  • Object-Oriented: Everything is an object.
  • High-level: Abstraction from memory details.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions 'Dynamically Typed'.
    • Follow-up: "What is the difference between dynamic typing and strong typing? Is Python strongly typed?"
    • Answer: Yes, Python is strongly typed. You cannot add "1" (string) and 1 (int) without explicit conversion, unlike JavaScript (weakly typed).

docs.title: 5. Explain is vs ==.
docs.text:
• ==: Checks for Value Equality (do they hold the same data?).
  • is: Checks for Reference Equality (do they point to the exact same memory address?).
a = [1, 2, 3]
b = [1, 2, 3]
print(a == b) # True
print(a is b) # False (different objects)

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate understands the difference.
    • Follow-up: "Why is None usually compared using is?"
    • Answer: Because None is a singleton. There is only one instance of None in the system, so is is faster and safer (prevents custom __eq__ methods from fooling the check).

docs.title: 6. What acts as a placeholder for an empty block?
docs.text: The pass statement. It is a null operation; nothing happens when it executes. Useful for empty function definitions or loops during development.

docs.title: 7. What is a Dictionary?
docs.text:
A collection of Key-Value pairs. It is unordered (before Python 3.7), mutable, and indexed. Keys must be immutable (hashable).

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions Hashable keys.
    • Follow-up: "Can I use a list as a dictionary key?"
    • Answer: No, lists are mutable and thus not hashable. You can use a tuple as a key if it contains only immutable elements.

docs.title: 8. How do you copy an object in Python?
docs.text:
• Assignment (=): Creates a new reference to the same object.
  • Shallow Copy (copy.copy() or [:]): Creates a new object, but inserts references into it to the objects found in the original.
  • Deep Copy (copy.deepcopy()): Creates a new object and recursively copies everything.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate explains Shallow Copy.
    • Follow-up: "If I change a nested list in a shallow copy, does it affect the original?"
    • Answer: Yes, because the inner list reference is shared.

docs.title: 9. What is a set?
docs.text: Unordered collection of unique elements. Useful for: * Removing duplicates. * Set operations (Union |, Intersection &, Difference -).

docs.title: 10. How do you manage packages in Python?
docs.text:
Using pip (Python Installer Package). Files usually listed in requirements.txt or pyproject.toml.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions Virtual Environments.
    • Follow-up: "Why are virtual environments important?"
    • Answer: To isolate dependencies per project, avoiding version conflicts between projects or with the system Python.

docs.title: 11. What is the difference between .py and .pyc files?
docs.text:
• .py: Source code.
  • .pyc: Bytecode (compiled version). Python compiles .py to .pyc to speed up loading. Stored in __pycache__.

docs.title: 12. Explain String Interpolation methods.
docs.text:
1. % formatting (Old): "Hello %s" % name
  2. .format() (Newer): "Hello {}".format(name)
  3. f-Strings (Modern, Python 3.6+): f"Hello {name}" (Fastest and most readable).

docs.title: 13. What is the Global Interpreter Lock (GIL)?
docs.text:
A mutex that protects access to Python objects, preventing multiple native threads from executing Python bytecodes at once. This means Python threads are not truly parallel on multi-core CPUs for CPU-bound tasks.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate says 'Python cannot do parallelism'.
    • Follow-up: "How do we achieve parallelism then?"
    • Answer: Use multiprocessing (separate processes have their own memory/GIL) or use libraries like NumPy that release the GIL for heavy computations.

docs.title: 14. What are negative indexes?
docs.text: Python allows accessing elements from the end of a sequence using negative numbers. -1 is the last item, -2 is the second to last.

docs.title: 15. What is slicing?
docs.text:
Extracting a part of a sequence. Syntax: object[start:stop:step]

a = [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
print(a[::-1]) # [5, 4, 3, 2, 1, 0] (Reverses list)

docs.title: 16. What is the difference between range and xrange?
docs.text:
• Python 2: range returned a list, xrange returned an iterator (memory efficient).
  • Python 3: xrange is gone. range now behaves like the old xrange (returns a range object/iterator).

docs.title: 17. How do you handle errors in Python?
docs.text:
Using try, except, else, and finally.

try:
    x = 1 / 0
except ZeroDivisionError:
    print("Error")
else:
    print("Success") # Runs if no exception
finally:
    print("Cleanup") # Always runs

docs.title: 18. What is a Docstring?
docs.text:
A string literal that occurs as the first statement in a module, function, class, or method definition. Accessed via __doc__.

Style: Triple quotes """Description""".

docs.title: 19. What is __init__?
docs.text: The constructor method for a class. It is automatically called when a new instance of the class is created. Used to initialize attributes.

docs.title: 20. What is self?
docs.text: It represents the instance of the class. By using self, we can access the attributes and methods of the class in Python. It is an explicit first argument (unlike this in Java/C++ which is implicit).

docs.title: 21. What is the difference between break, continue, and pass?
docs.text: Statement Effect break Terminates the loop immediately. continue Skips the current iteration and jumps to the next. pass Does nothing (placeholder).

docs.title: 22. Can you have an else clause with a loop?
docs.text:
Yes, else in a loop executes when the loop completes normally (without encountering a break statement).

for i in range(3):
    print(i)
else:
    print("Done") # Prints "Done"

for i in range(3):
    if i == 1:
        break
else:
    print("Done") # Does NOT print

docs.title: 23. What are iterators and iterables?
docs.text:
• Iterable: An object capable of returning its members one at a time (e.g., list, string). Has __iter__().
  • Iterator: An object representing a stream of data. Has __next__() and __iter__().

docs.title: 24. What is List Comprehension?
docs.text:
A concise way to create lists. Syntax: [expression for item in iterable if condition]

squares = [x**2 for x in range(10) if x % 2 == 0]

docs.title: 25. What is the ternary operator in Python?
docs.text:
[on_true] if [expression] else [on_false]

x = 10
status = "Even" if x % 2 == 0 else "Odd"

docs.title: 26. How does enumerate() work?
docs.text:
It adds a counter to an iterable and returns it as an enumerate object (iterator of tuples).

names = ["Alice", "Bob"]
for index, name in enumerate(names, start=1):
    print(f"{index}: {name}")
# Output:
# 1: Alice
# 2: Bob

docs.title: 27. What is zip()?
docs.text:
Aggregates elements from two or more iterables. Returns an iterator of tuples.

names = ["Alice", "Bob"]
ages = [25, 30]
print(list(zip(names, ages))) # [('Alice', 25), ('Bob', 30)]

docs.title: 28. What happens if zipped lists are different lengths?
docs.text: zip() stops at the shortest list. To fill missing values, use itertools.zip_longest().

docs.title: 29. How do you swap two variables in one line?
docs.text: a, b = b, a

docs.title: 30. What is the with statement?
docs.text:
It is used for Context Management. It ensures that resources (like file streams) are properly cleaned up (closed) even if exceptions occur.

with open('file.txt', 'r') as f:
    content = f.read()
# f is automatically closed here

docs.title: 31. Explain the if __name__ == "__main__": block.
docs.text: It checks if the script is being run directly (not imported as a module). If imported, __name__ is the module name; if run directly, __name__ is "__main__".

docs.title: 32. What is dict.get() vs dict[]?
docs.text:
• dict[key]: Raises KeyError if key is missing.
  • dict.get(key, default): Returns None (or specified default) if key is missing. Safer.

docs.title: 33. How to check if a key exists in a dictionary?
docs.text:
Use the in operator. 

if "key" in my_dict:
    print("Exists")

docs.title: 34. What is the difference between for loop and while loop?
docs.text:
• for: Iterates over a sequence (known number of times).
  • while: Repeats as long as a condition is true (unknown number of times).

docs.title: 35. How to flatten a list of lists?
docs.text:
Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: List Comprehension. 
    flat = [item for sublist in l for item in sublist]
  • Path B: itertools.chain. 
    import itertools
flat = list(itertools.chain(*l))

docs.title: 36. What is the difference between *args and **kwargs?
docs.text:
• *args: Allows passing a variable number of positional arguments (tuple).
  • **kwargs: Allows passing a variable number of keyword arguments (dictionary).
def func(*args, **kwargs):
    print(args)   # (1, 2)
    print(kwargs) # {'a': 3}

func(1, 2, a=3)

docs.title: 37. What are lambda functions?
docs.text:
Anonymous, small functions defined with the lambda keyword. They can have any number of arguments but only one expression.

add = lambda x, y: x + y
print(add(2, 3)) # 5

docs.title: 38. Explain map(), filter(), and reduce().
docs.text:
• map(func, iter): Applies func to all items in iter.
  • filter(func, iter): Creates a list of elements for which func returns true.
  • reduce(func, iter): Applies a rolling computation to sequential pairs of values (requires functools).

docs.title: 39. What is a "First Class Function"?
docs.text: Functions are treated like any other variable. They can be: 1. Passed as arguments to other functions. 2. Returned from other functions. 3. Assigned to variables.

docs.title: 40. What is Scope Resolution (LEGB Rule)?
docs.text: Python searches for variables in this order: 1. Local (Inside function) 2. Enclosing (Nested function globals) 3. Global (Module level) 4. Built-in (Python keywords)

docs.title: 41. What is a Closure?
docs.text:
A function object that remembers values in enclosing scopes even if they are not present in memory.

def outer(x):
    def inner(y):
        return x + y # Remembers x
    return inner

add5 = outer(5)
print(add5(10)) # 15

docs.title: 42. What is the global keyword?
docs.text:
Allows you to modify a global variable inside a local scope (function).

x = 10
def change():
    global x
    x = 20

docs.title: 43. What is the nonlocal keyword?
docs.text: Allows you to modify a variable in the nearest enclosing scope (not global). Used in nested functions.

docs.title: 44. Default Argument Values Gotcha.
docs.text:
Question: What is the output? 

def extend_list(val, list=[]):
    list.append(val)
    return list

list1 = extend_list(10)
list2 = extend_list(123, [])
list3 = extend_list('a')
print(list1)
print(list3)
Answer: [10, 'a'] and [10, 'a']. Default arguments are evaluated once at function definition time, so the list is shared across calls.

docs.title: 45. What is Currying?
docs.text: Decomposing a function that takes multiple arguments into a sequence of functions that each take a single argument. (Not native to Python syntax but achievable with closures or functools.partial).

docs.title: 46. What is a Higher-Order Function?
docs.text: A function that takes another function as an argument or returns a function. (e.g., map, decorator).

docs.title: 47. Difference between parameters and arguments?
docs.text:
• Parameters: Variables listed in the function definition.
  • Arguments: Actual values passed to the function when called.

docs.title: 48. Can you force Keyword-Only arguments?
docs.text:
Yes, by placing a * in the parameter list.

def func(a, *, b):
    pass

func(1, b=2) # OK
func(1, 2)   # Error

docs.title: 49. What is introspection (or reflection)?
docs.text: The ability of a program to examine the type or properties of an object at runtime. Examples: type(), id(), dir(), getattr(), hasattr().

docs.title: 50. How to create a function generator?
docs.text:
Use the yield keyword instead of return.

def count_up_to(n):
    count = 1
    while count <= n:
        yield count
        count += 1

docs.title: 51. What is the time complexity of looking up a key in a Dictionary?
docs.text: O(1) on average (Constant time) because it uses a Hash Table. O(n) in worst case (Hash collisions, though rare).

docs.title: 52. How does a Hash Table work?
docs.text:
It uses a hash function to compute an index into an array of buckets or slots, from which the desired value can be found.

Diagram: Hash Table 

graph LR
    Key["Key: 'Apple'"] --> HashFunc[Hash Function]
    HashFunc --> Index["Index: 3"]
    Index --> Bucket[Bucket 3: Value]

docs.title: 53. What is the difference between append() and extend()?
docs.text:
• append(x): Adds x as a single element to the end of the list.
  • extend(iterable): Appends all items from the iterable to the end.
x = [1, 2]
x.append([3, 4]) # [1, 2, [3, 4]]
x.extend([3, 4]) # [1, 2, [3, 4], 3, 4]

docs.title: 54. What is collections.defaultdict?
docs.text:
A dictionary subclass that calls a factory function to supply missing values, avoiding KeyError.

from collections import defaultdict
d = defaultdict(int)
d['a'] += 1 # 'a' is initialized to 0, then incremented

docs.title: 55. What is collections.Counter?
docs.text:
A dict subclass for counting hashable objects.

from collections import Counter
c = Counter('gallahad')
# {'a': 3, 'l': 2, 'g': 1, 'h': 1, 'd': 1}

docs.title: 56. What is collections.namedtuple?
docs.text:
Factory function for creating tuple subclasses with named fields. Makes code more readable than accessing tuples by index.

from collections import namedtuple
Point = namedtuple('Point', ['x', 'y'])
p = Point(11, 22)
print(p.x) # 11

docs.title: 57. What is a Deque?
docs.text: collections.deque (Double-Ended Queue). Thread-safe, memory efficient appends and pops from either side of the deque with approx O(1) performance. Lists are O(n) for pop(0).

docs.title: 58. How are Lists implemented in Python?
docs.text: Dynamic Arrays. They store pointers to objects. When the array is full, it doubles in size (over-allocation) to achieve amortized O(1) appends.

docs.title: 59. How are Sets implemented?
docs.text: Hash Tables (similar to Dictionaries, but with dummy values). This is why set elements must be hashable.

docs.title: 60. What is heapq?
docs.text: The heapq module provides an implementation of the Heap queue algorithm (Priority Queue). It maintains the smallest element at index 0 (Min Heap).

docs.title: 61. How to merge two dictionaries?
docs.text:
Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Old method. z = x.copy(); z.update(y)
  • Path B: Python 3.5+. z = {**x, **y}
  • Path C: Python 3.9+. z = x | y (Union operator).

docs.title: 62. How to remove duplicates from a list while preserving order?
docs.text:
list(set(l)) destroys order. Solution: 

seen = set()
result = [x for x in l if not (x in seen or seen.add(x))]
(Note: seen.add(x) returns None, which is Falsy).

docs.title: 63. What is frozenset?
docs.text: An immutable version of a Python set. Because it is immutable, it is hashable and can be used as a dictionary key or an element of another set.

docs.title: 64. What is a Weak Reference?
docs.text: weakref module allows the programmer to create references to objects that do not increase the reference count. Useful for caching/caches to avoid memory leaks (holding objects in cache preventing GC).

docs.title: 65. Difference between sort() and sorted()?
docs.text:
• list.sort(): Sorts the list in-place. Returns None.
  • sorted(iterable): Returns a new sorted list. Original is unchanged.

docs.title: 66. How do you create a Class?
docs.text:
class Dog:
    species = "Canis familiaris" # Class Attribute

    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name # Instance Attribute

    def bark(self):
        return f"{self.name} says Woof!"

docs.title: 67. Explain Inheritance.
docs.text:
Allows a class (Child) to derive attributes and methods from another class (Parent).

class Puppy(Dog):
    def bark(self):
        return "Yap!"

docs.title: 68. What is super()?
docs.text:
A built-in function that returns a proxy object (temporary object of the superclass) that allows you to access methods of the base class.

class Puppy(Dog):
    def __init__(self, name, age):
        super().__init__(name)
        self.age = age

docs.title: 69. Multiple Inheritance in Python?
docs.text:
Yes, Python supports it. class C(A, B): pass

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions Diamond Problem.
    • Follow-up: "How does Python resolve method resolution order in the Diamond Problem?"
    • Answer: It uses the C3 Linearization algorithm (MRO).

docs.title: 70. What is MRO (Method Resolution Order)?
docs.text: The order in which Python looks for a method in a hierarchy of classes. Viewable via ClassName.__mro__ or ClassName.mro().

docs.title: 71. What are Magic Methods (Dunder Methods)?
docs.text: Special methods surrounded by double underscores. They allow instances of your classes to interact with built-in operators and functions. * __init__: Constructor. * __str__: Readable string representation (for users). * __repr__: Unambiguous string representation (for devs). * __len__: for len(). * __add__: for +.

docs.title: 72. Difference between __str__ and __repr__?
docs.text:
• __str__: Called by str(object) and print. Intended to be readable.
  • __repr__: Called by repr(object). Intended to be unambiguous. Ideally eval(repr(obj)) == obj.

docs.title: 73. What are Class Methods and Static Methods?
docs.text:
• @classmethod: Takes cls as first argument. Can access class state. Factory methods.
  • @staticmethod: No implicit first argument. Just a function inside a class namespace.
class MyClass:
    @classmethod
    def from_string(cls, s):
        return cls(...)

    @staticmethod
    def is_valid(x):
        return x > 0

docs.title: 74. What is Encapsulation?
docs.text: Restricting access to methods and variables. In Python, we use _single_leading_underscore (convention: protected) and __double_leading_underscore (name mangling: private).

docs.title: 75. What is Name Mangling?
docs.text: When using __var inside a class, Python changes the name to _ClassName__var to prevent subclasses from accidentally overriding it.

docs.title: 76. What is Polymorphism?
docs.text: The ability to present the same interface for different underlying forms (data types). Example: len() works on strings, lists, and dicts. + adds numbers but concatenates strings.

docs.title: 77. What is an Abstract Base Class (ABC)?
docs.text:
A class that cannot be instantiated and requires subclasses to implement specific methods. Used to define interfaces.

from abc import ABC, abstractmethod

class Shape(ABC):
    @abstractmethod
    def area(self):
        pass

docs.title: 78. What is __slots__?
docs.text:
A mechanism to optimize memory usage by telling Python not to use a __dict__ for instances, but instead allocate space for a fixed set of attributes.

class Point:
    __slots__ = ['x', 'y']

docs.title: 79. What is Duck Typing?
docs.text: "If it looks like a duck and quacks like a duck, it's a duck." Python doesn't check types; it checks for the presence of methods/attributes at runtime.

docs.title: 80. What is a Metaclass?
docs.text: A class of a class. A class defines how an instance behaves; a metaclass defines how a class behaves. Everything in Python is an object, including classes. The default metaclass is type. Used for: Frameworks, API registration, singleton patterns.

docs.title: 81. What is a Decorator?
docs.text:
A design pattern that allows a user to add new functionality to an existing object without modifying its structure. In Python, it is a function that takes another function as an argument.

def my_decorator(func):
    def wrapper():
        print("Before")
        func()
        print("After")
    return wrapper

@my_decorator
def say_hello():
    print("Hello!")

docs.title: 82. How do you create a decorator with arguments?
docs.text:
You need three levels of nested functions.

def repeat(num_times):
    def decorator_repeat(func):
        def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
            for _ in range(num_times):
                func(*args, **kwargs)
        return wrapper
    return decorator_repeat

@repeat(3)
def greet(name):
    print(f"Hello {name}")

docs.title: 83. What is functools.wraps?
docs.text: A decorator used when defining a decorator. It copies the metadata (name, docstring) of the original function to the wrapper function. Without it, debugging is hard (function name becomes wrapper).

docs.title: 84. What is a Generator?
docs.text: A function that returns an iterator. It looks like a normal function except that it contains yield expressions. It generates a series of values over time, pausing execution and saving state between each yield.

docs.title: 85. Generator vs Iterator?
docs.text:
• Every generator is an iterator, but not vice versa.
  • Generators are easier to write (auto __iter__ and __next__).

docs.title: 86. What is a Context Manager?
docs.text:
An object that defines the runtime context to be established when executing a with statement. Must implement __enter__ and __exit__.

class FileManager:
    def __init__(self, name, mode):
        self.file = open(name, mode)
    def __enter__(self):
        return self.file
    def __exit__(self, type, value, traceback):
        self.file.close()

docs.title: 87. What is the contextlib module?
docs.text: Utilities for creating context managers. @contextlib.contextmanager decorator allows creating a context manager using a generator function (yield separates enter and exit logic).

docs.title: 88. Explain async and await (Asyncio).
docs.text:
• async def: Defines a coroutine.
  • await: Pauses execution of the coroutine until the awaitable (IO operation) completes. Used for concurrency (single-threaded cooperative multitasking), best for IO-bound tasks.

docs.title: 89. Threading vs Multiprocessing?
docs.text: Feature Threading Multiprocessing Memory Shared Separate GIL Yes (limits CPU parallelism) No (Bypasses GIL) Use Case I/O Bound (Network, Disk) CPU Bound (Calculations) Overhead Low High (Process creation)

docs.title: 90. What is a descriptor?
docs.text: An object attribute with "binding behavior", one whose attribute access has been overridden by methods in the descriptor protocol: __get__, __set__, and __delete__. Underlies properties, methods, static methods, class methods, and super().

docs.title: 91. What is the property decorator?
docs.text:
A built-in descriptor that turns a method into a read-only attribute (getter), and allows defining setters and deleters.

class C:
    def __init__(self):
        self._x = None
    @property
    def x(self):
        return self._x
    @x.setter
    def x(self, value):
        self._x = value

docs.title: 92. How does Python handle circular imports?
docs.text: If module A imports B, and B imports A, it can cause an ImportError. Solutions: 1. Import inside the function/method (defer import). 2. Restructure code to remove circular dependency.

docs.title: 93. What is the __call__ method?
docs.text:
Allows an instance of a class to be called as a function.

class Adder:
    def __call__(self, x, y):
        return x + y

add = Adder()
print(add(2, 3)) # 5

docs.title: 94. What is Pickling and Unpickling?
docs.text:
• Pickling: Serializing a Python object structure into a byte stream.
  • Unpickling: Deserializing the byte stream back into an object.
  • Security Risk: Never unpickle data received from an untrusted source (can execute arbitrary code).

docs.title: 95. What is the difference between __new__ and __init__?
docs.text:
• __new__: Static method. Creates the instance. Returns the instance.
  • __init__: Instance method. Initializes the instance. Returns None. Use __new__ when subclassing immutable types like tuple or str.

docs.title: 96. What is Monkey Patching?
docs.text: Dynamically changing a piece of code (class or module) at runtime. Useful for testing (mocking), but dangerous in production code.

docs.title: 97. What is the purpose of __future__ module?
docs.text: To allow using features from future Python versions in the current version. e.g., from __future__ import print_function in Python 2.

docs.title: 98. How do you profile Python code?
docs.text:
• cProfile: Deterministic profiling of Python programs.
  • timeit: Measure execution time of small code snippets.

docs.title: 99. What are Type Hints?
docs.text:
Introduced in Python 3.5 (PEP 484). Syntax to declare the type of a variable/parameter. Python runtime ignores them, but static analysis tools (mypy) use them.

def greeting(name: str) -> str:
    return 'Hello ' + name

docs.title: 100. What is the Walrus Operator :=?
docs.text:
Introduced in Python 3.8. Assignment expressions. Allows you to assign a value to a variable as part of an expression.

if (n := len(a)) > 10:
    print(f"List is too long ({n} elements)")

End of Interview Questions

docs.title: Software Engineering Interview Questions & Answers (100+)
docs.text: This guide contains 100+ Software Engineering interview questions, covering Algorithms, System Design, OS, Networking, and Soft Skills. Each question includes a model answer and potential follow-up paths.

docs.title: 1. Explain Big O Notation.
docs.text:
Big O notation describes the worst-case performance or complexity of an algorithm. It characterizes the execution time or space used as the input size ($n$) grows.

Notation Name Example Algorithm $O(1)$ Constant Accessing array index $O(\log n)$ Logarithmic Binary Search $O(n)$ Linear Linear Search $O(n \log n)$ Linearithmic Merge Sort $O(n^2)$ Quadratic Bubble Sort

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions Space Complexity.
    • Follow-up: "What is the space complexity of a recursive Fibonacci function without memoization?"
    • Answer: $O(n)$ (stack depth).

docs.title: 2. Array vs. Linked List?
docs.text:
• Array: Contiguous memory. $O(1)$ access. $O(n)$ insertion/deletion (shifting). Fixed size (usually).
  • Linked List: Non-contiguous. $O(n)$ access. $O(1)$ insertion/deletion (if pointer known). Dynamic size.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Cache Locality.
    • Follow-up: "Why are Arrays generally faster for iteration than Linked Lists?"
    • Answer: Spatial locality / CPU caching. Arrays are contiguous blocks.

docs.title: 3. What is a Hash Table?
docs.text:
A data structure that implements an associative array abstract data type, a structure that can map keys to values. It uses a hash function to compute an index into an array of buckets or slots.

graph LR
    Key --> HashFunction
    HashFunction --> Index
    Index --> Bucket[Bucket / Storage]

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Collisions.
    • Follow-up: "How do you handle collisions?"
    • Answer: Chaining (Linked Lists in buckets) or Open Addressing (Probing).

docs.title: 4. Stack vs. Queue?
docs.text:
• Stack: LIFO (Last In, First Out). Operations: push, pop. Used in recursion, undo mechanisms.
  • Queue: FIFO (First In, First Out). Operations: enqueue, dequeue. Used in job scheduling, BFS.

docs.title: 5. Explain Binary Search.
docs.text:
An efficient algorithm for finding an item from a sorted list of items. It works by repeatedly dividing in half the portion of the list that could contain the item.

Time Complexity: $O(\log n)$

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Pre-requisites.
    • Follow-up: "What happens if the array is not sorted?"
    • Answer: Binary search fails. You must sort first ($O(n \log n)$) or use Linear Search ($O(n)$).

docs.title: 6. What is a Binary Search Tree (BST)?
docs.text:
A node-based binary tree data structure which has the following properties: * The left subtree of a node contains only nodes with keys lesser than the node’s key. * The right subtree of a node contains only nodes with keys greater than the node’s key.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Balancing.
    • Follow-up: "What is the worst-case search time in a BST?"
    • Answer: $O(n)$ if the tree becomes a skewed line. Balanced trees (AVL, Red-Black) guarantee $O(\log n)$.

docs.title: 7. BFS vs. DFS?
docs.text:
• BFS (Breadth-First Search): Explores neighbor nodes first. Uses a Queue. Good for finding shortest path in unweighted graphs.
  • DFS (Depth-First Search): Explores as far as possible along each branch before backtracking. Uses a Stack (recursion). Good for puzzles, topological sort.

docs.title: 8. Explain QuickSort.
docs.text:
A divide-and-conquer algorithm. It picks an element as a pivot and partitions the given array around the picked pivot.

  • Best/Avg: $O(n \log n)$
  • Worst: $O(n^2)$ (if pivot is always smallest/largest)

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Pivot Selection.
    • Follow-up: "How can you avoid the worst-case scenario?"
    • Answer: Pick a random pivot or median-of-three.

docs.title: 9. Explain Merge Sort.
docs.text:
A divide-and-conquer algorithm that divides the input array into two halves, calls itself for the two halves, and then merges the two sorted halves.

  • Complexity: Always $O(n \log n)$.
  • Stability: Stable sort (maintains relative order of equal elements).

docs.title: 10. What is Dynamic Programming?
docs.text:
A method for solving complex problems by breaking them down into simpler subproblems. It is applicable to problems exhibiting overlapping subproblems and optimal substructure.

Two approaches: 1. Memoization (Top-Down): Cache results of recursive calls. 2. Tabulation (Bottom-Up): Fill a table iteratively.

docs.title: 11. What is a Priority Queue?
docs.text: A generic data structure where each element has a "priority" associated with it. Elements with high priority are served before elements with low priority. Usually implemented with a Heap.

docs.title: 12. Min-Heap vs. Max-Heap?
docs.text:
• Min-Heap: The key at the root must be minimum among all keys present in the Binary Heap. This property must be recursively true for all nodes.
  • Max-Heap: The key at the root must be maximum.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Complexity.
    • Follow-up: "Time complexity to insert or extract min/max?"
    • Answer: $O(\log n)$ to maintain the heap property.

docs.title: 13. What is Recursion?
docs.text: A process where a function calls itself as a subroutine. Must have: 1. Base Case: To stop the recursion. 2. Recursive Step: To move closer to the base case.

docs.title: 14. Invert a Binary Tree.
docs.text:
Swap the left and right children of every node.

def invertTree(root):
    if not root: return None
    root.left, root.right = invertTree(root.right), invertTree(root.left)
    return root

docs.title: 15. Detect a cycle in a Linked List.
docs.text: Floyd’s Cycle-Finding Algorithm (Tortoise and Hare): Use two pointers. One moves 1 step, the other moves 2 steps. If they meet, there is a cycle.

docs.title: 16. What is the difference between a Graph and a Tree?
docs.text: A Tree is a special kind of Graph that is: 1. Connected. 2. Acyclic (No cycles). 3. Has $N$ nodes and $N-1$ edges.

docs.title: 17. Explain 'Greedy' Algorithms.
docs.text: An algorithmic paradigm that follows the problem-solving heuristic of making the locally optimal choice at each stage with the hope of finding a global optimum. Example: Dijkstra's Algorithm, Huffman Coding.

docs.title: 18. How to find duplicates in an array in $O(n)$ time?
docs.text: Use a HashSet or a Frequency Map. Iterate through the array; if the element is already in the set, it's a duplicate.

docs.title: 19. What is a Trie (Prefix Tree)?
docs.text: A tree-like data structure used to store a dynamic set of strings where the keys are usually strings. Use Case: Autocomplete systems.

docs.title: 20. String Immutability.
docs.text: In many languages (Java, Python, C#), strings are immutable. You cannot change characters in place; you create a new string. Reason: Security, Thread-safety, String Pool optimization.

docs.title: 21. Vertical vs. Horizontal Scaling?
docs.text: Feature Vertical (Scale Up) Horizontal (Scale Out) Definition Add more power (CPU, RAM) to existing machine. Add more machines to the pool. Downtime Usually requires downtime to upgrade. No downtime (add nodes dynamically). Limit Hard hardware limits. Infinite (theoretical). Cost Exponentially expensive for high-end hardware. Linear cost (commodity hardware).

docs.title: 22. What is a Load Balancer?
docs.text: A device that acts as a reverse proxy and distributes network or application traffic across a number of servers. * Layer 4 (Transport): Based on IP/Port. * Layer 7 (Application): Based on URL, Cookies, Headers.

docs.title: 23. Explain CAP Theorem.
docs.text:
In a distributed data store, you can only guarantee 2 out of 3: 1. Consistency: Every read receives the most recent write or an error. 2. Availability: Every request receives a (non-error) response, without the guarantee that it contains the most recent write. 3. Partition Tolerance: The system continues to operate despite an arbitrary number of messages being dropped or delayed by the network.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Real world.
    • Follow-up: "Can you sacrifice P?"
    • Answer: No, network partitions are inevitable. You must choose between CP (Mongo, Redis) and AP (Cassandra, Dynamo).

docs.title: 24. Monolithic vs. Microservices Architecture?
docs.text:
• Monolith: Single codebase, single build, single deployment. Simple to start, hard to scale teams.
  • Microservices: Collection of loosely coupled services. Independent deployment, scalable, complex to manage (network latency, consistency).

docs.title: 25. What is Database Sharding?
docs.text: A type of database partitioning that separates very large databases the into smaller, faster, more easily managed parts called data shards. * Key: Shard Key selection is critical to avoid "hot shards".

docs.title: 26. What is Caching?
docs.text: Storing copies of data in a temporary storage location (cache) so that future requests for that data can be served faster. * Types: Browser, CDN, API Gateway, Application (Memcached/Redis), Database.

docs.title: 27. Cache Eviction Policies?
docs.text:
• LRU (Least Recently Used): Discard items not used for the longest time.
  • LFU (Least Frequently Used): Discard items used least often.
  • FIFO (First In, First Out).

docs.title: 28. What is a CDN (Content Delivery Network)?
docs.text: A geographically distributed group of servers which work together to provide fast delivery of Internet content. It caches static assets (images, CSS, JS) closer to the user.

docs.title: 29. SQL vs. NoSQL?
docs.text:
• SQL (Relational): Structured, Schema-based, ACID, Vertical Scaling. (MySQL, Postgres).
  • NoSQL (Non-Relational): Unstructured/Semi-structured, Schema-less, BASE, Horizontal Scaling. (MongoDB, Cassandra).

docs.title: 30. What is Consistent Hashing?
docs.text: A distributed hashing scheme that operates independently of the number of servers or objects in a distributed hash table. It minimizes reorganization of keys when a server is added or removed.

docs.title: 31. What is a Reverse Proxy?
docs.text: A server that sits in front of web servers and forwards client (e.g. browser) requests to those web servers. Benefits: Load Balancing, Security, Caching, SSL Termination.

docs.title: 32. Rate Limiting algorithms.
docs.text:
• Token Bucket: Tokens are added at a fixed rate. Request consumes a token.
  • Leaky Bucket: Requests enter a queue and are processed at a constant rate.
  • Fixed Window: Count requests per minute.
  • Sliding Window: More smooth than fixed window.

docs.title: 33. What is a Message Queue?
docs.text: A form of asynchronous service-to-service communication used in serverless and microservices architectures. (RabbitMQ, Kafka, SQS). Benefit: Decoupling, Buffering, Reliability.

docs.title: 34. Throughput vs. Latency?
docs.text:
• Latency: Time taken to process a single request (Speed).
  • Throughput: Number of requests processed per second (Capacity).

docs.title: 35. Explain "Backpressure".
docs.text: When a system is overwhelmed by data/requests, it pushes back against the producer to slow down, preventing the system from crashing.

docs.title: 36. Polling vs. WebSockets vs. Server-Sent Events (SSE)?
docs.text:
• Polling: Client asks server "New data?" periodically. (Inefficient).
  • Long Polling: Client asks, server holds connection open until data is available.
  • WebSockets: Full-duplex (two-way) communication over single TCP connection.
  • SSE: One-way (Server to Client) streaming.

docs.title: 37. What is Database Replication?
docs.text: Copying data from one database server (primary) to others (replicas). * Master-Slave: Write to Master, Read from Slaves. * Master-Master: Write to any node (Complex conflict resolution).

docs.title: 38. Single Point of Failure (SPOF).
docs.text: A part of a system that, if it fails, will stop the entire system from working. Solution: Redundancy (Backup servers, Clusters).

docs.title: 39. Idempotency.
docs.text: An operation is idempotent if applying it multiple times has the same effect as applying it once. * GET/PUT/DELETE are idempotent. * POST is generally not.

docs.title: 40. Design a URL Shortener (TinyURL).
docs.text: Key Components: 1. API: create(long_url) -> short_url, get(short_url) -> long_url (redirect). 2. Algorithm: Base62 encoding of a unique ID. 3. Storage: Key-Value store (fast lookups).

docs.title: 41. Process vs. Thread?
docs.text: Feature Process Thread Definition An instance of a program in execution. A sequence of instructions within a process. Memory Isolated memory space. Shared memory (Heap) within process. Overhead High (Context switch is slow). Low (Lightweight context switch). Communication IPC (Pipes, Sockets). Direct memory access.

docs.title: 42. What is Concurrency vs. Parallelism?
docs.text:
• Concurrency: Handling multiple tasks at once (interleaving execution). Structure of the program.
  • Parallelism: Doing multiple tasks at once (simultaneous execution). Hardware execution.

docs.title: 43. What is a Deadlock?
docs.text:
A situation where a set of processes are blocked because each process is holding a resource and waiting for another resource acquired by some other process.

Necessary Conditions (Coffman Conditions): 1. Mutual Exclusion. 2. Hold and Wait. 3. No Preemption. 4. Circular Wait.

docs.title: 44. What is a Semaphore?
docs.text: A variable or abstract data type used to control access to a common resource by multiple processes in a concurrent system such as a multitasking operating system. * Binary Semaphore (Mutex): 0 or 1. * Counting Semaphore: Allow $N$ accessors.

docs.title: 45. Explain Virtual Memory.
docs.text:
A memory management technique that provides an "idealized abstraction" of the storage resources that are actually available on a given machine. It maps memory addresses used by a program, called virtual addresses, into physical addresses in computer memory.

Benefit: Process isolation, ability to use more memory than physically available (Paging/Swapping).

docs.title: 46. Stack vs. Heap Memory?
docs.text:
• Stack: Static memory allocation. Stores local variables, function calls. Fast access. Automatic deallocation when function returns.
  • Heap: Dynamic memory allocation. Stores objects. Slower access. Manual (C++) or Garbage Collected (Java/Python) deallocation.

docs.title: 47. What is a Context Switch?
docs.text: The process of storing the state of a process or thread, so that it can be restored and resume execution later. This allows multiple processes to share a single CPU. It is computationally expensive.

docs.title: 48. What is a Race Condition?
docs.text: A condition where the system's substantive behavior is dependent on the sequence or timing of other uncontrollable events. Occurs when two threads access shared data and try to change it at the same time.

docs.title: 49. Static vs. Dynamic Linking?
docs.text:
• Static: Libraries are copied into the executable at compile time. Larger binary, no dependency issues.
  • Dynamic: Libraries are loaded at runtime. Smaller binary, shared memory efficiency, "DLL Hell" potential.

docs.title: 50. What is a System Call?
docs.text: The programmatic way in which a computer program requests a service from the kernel of the operating system (e.g., File I/O, process creation).

docs.title: 51. Compiler vs. Interpreter?
docs.text:
• Compiler: Translates entire source code into machine code before execution. (C++, Go). Faster execution.
  • Interpreter: Translates source code line-by-line during execution. (Python, Ruby). Faster development cycle.

docs.title: 52. What is Garbage Collection?
docs.text:
A form of automatic memory management. The garbage collector attempts to reclaim memory which was allocated by the program, but is no longer referenced.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: How it works.
    • Follow-up: "What is 'Stop the World'?"
    • Answer: A pause in application execution while the GC runs.

docs.title: 53. Big Endian vs. Little Endian?
docs.text: Order of bytes. * Big Endian: Most significant byte first (at lowest address). (Networking protocols). * Little Endian: Least significant byte first. (x86 architecture).

docs.title: 54. What is Thrashing?
docs.text: When the computer's virtual memory subsystem is in a constant state of paging (swapping data between RAM and Disk), rapidly exchanging data for data on disk, to the exclusion of most application-level processing.

docs.title: 55. What is an Inode?
docs.text: A data structure in a Unix-style file system that describes a file-system object like a file or a directory. It stores attributes (permissions, owner, size) and disk block locations, but not the filename.

docs.title: 56. What happens when you type a URL in the browser?
docs.text:
1. DNS Lookup (Domain -> IP).
  2. TCP Handshake (SYN, SYN-ACK, ACK).
  3. SSL/TLS Handshake (if HTTPS).
  4. HTTP GET Request.
  5. Server processes and sends HTTP Response.
  6. Browser renders content.

docs.title: 57. TCP vs. UDP?
docs.text:
• TCP (Transmission Control Protocol): Connection-oriented, reliable, ordered, flow control. (Web, Email).
  • UDP (User Datagram Protocol): Connectionless, unreliable, no ordering, fast. (Streaming, Gaming).

docs.title: 58. Explain the OSI Model.
docs.text:
1. Physical (Cables)
  2. Data Link (MAC, Switches)
  3. Network (IP, Routers)
  4. Transport (TCP/UDP)
  5. Session
  6. Presentation (Encryption)
  7. Application (HTTP, FTP)

docs.title: 59. What is a Zombie Process?
docs.text: A process that has completed execution but still has an entry in the process table. This occurs for child processes that have stayed alive but their parent has not yet waited for them (called wait()).

docs.title: 60. Hard Link vs. Soft Link?
docs.text:
• Hard Link: Direct pointer to the inode. Deleting original file doesn't affect hard link. Cannot cross file systems.
  • Soft (Symbolic) Link: Pointer to the file name/path. If original is deleted, link is broken. Can cross file systems.

docs.title: 61. HTTP Methods.
docs.text:
• GET: Retrieve data.
  • POST: Submit data (create).
  • PUT: Update data (replace entirely).
  • PATCH: Partial update.
  • DELETE: Remove data.

docs.title: 62. HTTP Status Codes.
docs.text:
• 2xx: Success (200 OK, 201 Created).
  • 3xx: Redirection (301 Moved Permanently, 304 Not Modified).
  • 4xx: Client Error (400 Bad Request, 401 Unauthorized, 403 Forbidden, 404 Not Found).
  • 5xx: Server Error (500 Internal Server Error, 502 Bad Gateway).

docs.title: 63. HTTPS vs. HTTP.
docs.text: HTTPS is HTTP over SSL/TLS. It encrypts communication using Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) to ensure confidentiality, integrity, and authentication.

docs.title: 64. REST vs. GraphQL?
docs.text:
• REST: Resource-based. Multiple endpoints (/users, /posts). Over-fetching/Under-fetching common.
  • GraphQL: Query language. Single endpoint. Client asks for exactly what it needs.

docs.title: 65. What is a Cookie?
docs.text: Small piece of data sent from a website and stored on the user's computer by the user's web browser while the user is browsing. Used for Session management, Personalization, Tracking.

docs.title: 66. Session vs. Token (JWT) Authentication?
docs.text:
• Session: Server stores session data in memory/DB. Client sends SessionID cookie. Stateful.
  • Token (JWT): Server signs a token with data. Client stores token. Server validates signature. Stateless.

docs.title: 67. What is CORS?
docs.text: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing. A security feature where a browser blocks a web page from making requests to a different domain than the one that served the web page, unless the server explicitly allows it (via Headers like Access-Control-Allow-Origin).

docs.title: 68. LocalStorage vs. SessionStorage vs. Cookies?
docs.text: Feature Cookie LocalStorage SessionStorage Capacity 4KB 5-10MB 5-10MB Expiry Manual Never On Tab Close Sent to Server Yes (Every Request) No No

docs.title: 69. What is DNS?
docs.text: Domain Name System. The phonebook of the internet. Translates human-readable domain names (google.com) to IP addresses (142.250.190.46).

docs.title: 70. What is SQL Injection?
docs.text: A code injection technique where an attacker executes malicious SQL statements that control a web application's database server. Prevention: Prepared Statements (Parameterized Queries).

docs.title: 71. What is XSS (Cross-Site Scripting)?
docs.text: A vulnerability where an attacker injects malicious scripts into content from otherwise trusted websites. Prevention: Content Security Policy (CSP), Escaping/Sanitizing inputs.

docs.title: 72. What is CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery)?
docs.text: An attack that forces an end user to execute unwanted actions on a web application in which they're currently authenticated. Prevention: Anti-CSRF Tokens.

docs.title: 73. What is a Webhook?
docs.text: A way for an app to provide other applications with real-time information. A "user-defined HTTP callback".

docs.title: 74. TCP 3-Way Handshake.
docs.text:
1. SYN: Client sends SYN to Server ("I want to connect").
  2. SYN-ACK: Server replies with SYN-ACK ("I acknowledge, let's connect").
  3. ACK: Client sends ACK ("Connection established").

docs.title: 75. Explain 'Keep-Alive'.
docs.text: An instruction that allows a single TCP connection to remain open for multiple HTTP requests/responses, reducing latency (avoiding repeated handshakes).

docs.title: 76. Forward Proxy vs. Reverse Proxy?
docs.text:
• Forward: Sits before the client. Hides client identity. (e.g., VPN, bypassing firewalls).
  • Reverse: Sits before the server. Hides server identity. (e.g., Load Balancer).

docs.title: 77. What is a Subnet Mask?
docs.text: A 32-bit number that masks an IP address, and divides the IP address into network address and host address.

docs.title: 78. What is 'localhost' and 127.0.0.1?
docs.text: The loopback address. It points back to the computer you are currently using.

docs.title: 79. What is dependency injection?
docs.text: A design pattern in which a class requests dependencies from external sources rather than creating them. Benefit: Decoupling, easier testing (mocking).

docs.title: 80. Explain 'Stateless' protocol.
docs.text: A protocol where each request is treated as an independent transaction that is unrelated to any previous request. HTTP is stateless.

docs.title: 81. Explain CI/CD.
docs.text:
