• CI (Continuous Integration): Developers merge their changes back to the main branch as often as possible. Automated builds and tests run.
  • CD (Continuous Delivery/Deployment): Automatically releasing code changes to a repository or production.

docs.title: 82. What is Git?
docs.text:
A distributed version control system for tracking changes in source code during software development.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Git vs SVN.
    • Follow-up: "What does 'distributed' mean?"
    • Answer: Every developer has a full copy of the repository history.

docs.title: 83. Merge vs. Rebase?
docs.text:
• Merge: Creates a new commit, preserves history structure. Non-destructive.
  • Rebase: Moves the entire feature branch to begin on the tip of the master branch. Cleaner history (linear), but destructive (rewrites history).

docs.title: 84. What is Agile?
docs.text: A project management methodology characterized by the division of tasks into short phases of work and frequent reassessment and adaptation of plans.

docs.title: 85. Scrum vs. Kanban?
docs.text:
• Scrum: Fixed sprints (e.g., 2 weeks). Roles (Scrum Master, PO). Ceremonies.
  • Kanban: Continuous flow. Visualize work. Limit WIP (Work In Progress). No fixed sprints.

docs.title: 86. What is TDD (Test Driven Development)?
docs.text: Process: 1. Write a failing test. 2. Write just enough code to pass the test. 3. Refactor.

docs.title: 87. Docker vs. Virtual Machine?
docs.text:
• VM: Virtualizes hardware. Heavy. Includes full OS.
  • Docker (Container): Virtualizes OS. Lightweight. Shares Host OS kernel.

docs.title: 88. What is Kubernetes (K8s)?
docs.text: An open-source system for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications (Orchestration).

docs.title: 89. Explain SOLID principles.
docs.text:
• S: Single Responsibility Principle.
  • O: Open/Closed Principle.
  • L: Liskov Substitution Principle.
  • I: Interface Segregation Principle.
  • D: Dependency Inversion Principle.

docs.title: 90. What is Technical Debt?
docs.text: The implied cost of additional rework caused by choosing an easy (limited) solution now instead of using a better approach that would take longer.

docs.title: 91. How do you handle a disagreement with a team member?
docs.text: STAR Method: * S/T: Situation/Task (Disagreement on API design). * A: Action (Listened, understood their view, proposed compromise or data-driven decision). * R: Result (Reached consensus, improved relationship).

docs.title: 92. Describe a challenging bug you fixed.
docs.text: Look for: Process of debugging. Logging, reproducing, isolating, fixing, adding regression test.

docs.title: 93. What is Code Review?
docs.text: A systematic examination of computer source code. Goals: Find bugs, improve quality, knowledge sharing, consistency.

docs.title: 94. What is "Blue/Green Deployment"?
docs.text: A technique that reduces downtime and risk by running two identical production environments called Blue and Green. At any time, one is live (Blue). You deploy to Green. Once tested, you switch the router to Green.

docs.title: 95. What is "Canary Deployment"?
docs.text: Rolling out a new version to a small subset of users (canaries) before rolling it out to the entire infrastructure.

docs.title: 96. What is Infrastructure as Code (IaC)?
docs.text: Managing and provisioning computer data centers through machine-readable definition files, rather than physical hardware configuration or interactive configuration tools. (Terraform, CloudFormation).

docs.title: 97. Pair Programming pros/cons?
docs.text:
• Pros: Fewer bugs, knowledge sharing, focus.
  • Cons: Exhausting, personality clashes, short-term velocity drop.

docs.title: 98. How do you stay updated with technology?
docs.text: Blogs (HackerNews), Conferences, Side Projects, Reading Docs, Twitter/X.

docs.title: 99. Explain the "Bus Factor".
docs.text: The minimum number of team members that have to disappear from a project before the project stalls due to lack of knowledgeable or competent personnel. Goal: Increase Bus Factor (Knowledge Sharing).

docs.title: 100. What happens when you type ls -l in a shell?
docs.text:
1. Shell reads input.
  2. Parses tokens.
  3. Checks aliases/functions.
  4. Checks PATH for executable.
  5. fork() to create child process.
  6. exec() to run ls.
  7. ls reads directory entries and prints formatted output.
  8. Parent process wait()s for child to finish.
  9. Shell prints prompt.

End of Questions

docs.title: SQL Interview Questions & Answers (100+)
docs.text: This guide contains 100+ SQL interview questions, ranging from basic to advanced. Each question includes a model answer and potential follow-up paths based on the candidate's response.

docs.title: 1. What is the difference between DELETE, TRUNCATE, and DROP?
docs.text:
Command Type Description Rollback? Performance DELETE DML Removes specific rows based on a WHERE clause. Yes Slower (logs per row) TRUNCATE DDL Removes all rows from a table. Resets identity. No (usually) Faster (minimal logging) DROP DDL Removes the entire table structure and data. No Fast

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions transaction logs.

    • Follow-up: "Why does TRUNCATE generate less log volume than DELETE?"
    • Answer: TRUNCATE logs the deallocation of data pages, while DELETE logs the deletion of individual rows.

  • Path B: Candidate focuses on the WHERE clause.

    • Follow-up: "Can you use TRUNCATE with a WHERE clause?"
    • Answer: No, TRUNCATE is all-or-nothing for the table data.

docs.title: 2. Explain the order of execution in a SQL query.
docs.text:
Most candidates write SQL in the order SELECT -> FROM -> WHERE. However, the engine executes them differently.

graph LR
    A[FROM/JOIN] --> B[WHERE]
    B --> C[GROUP BY]
    C --> D[HAVING]
    D --> E[SELECT]
    E --> F[ORDER BY]
    F --> G[LIMIT]

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate gets it right.

    • Follow-up: "Since SELECT is executed after WHERE, can I use a column alias defined in SELECT inside the WHERE clause?"
    • Answer: No, because the WHERE clause is evaluated before the SELECT clause generates the alias.

  • Path B: Candidate forgets HAVING.

    • Follow-up: "Where does HAVING fit in? Before or after GROUP BY?"
    • Answer: After GROUP BY, as it filters the aggregated groups.

docs.title: 3. What is a Primary Key?
docs.text:
A Primary Key is a column (or set of columns) that uniquely identifies each row in a table. It must contain UNIQUE values and cannot be NULL.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions 'Composite Keys'.
    • Follow-up: "When would you use a composite primary key over a surrogate key (like an auto-incrementing ID)?"
    • Answer: When there is a natural unique combination of data (e.g., StudentId + CourseId in an enrollment table) and you want to enforce that uniqueness strictly without an extra ID column.

docs.title: 4. What is the difference between WHERE and HAVING?
docs.text:
• WHERE: Filters rows before aggregation.
  • HAVING: Filters groups after aggregation.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate is unsure.
    • Follow-up: "Can I use count(*) in a WHERE clause?"
    • Answer: No, aggregate functions cannot be used in WHERE. They must be used in HAVING.

docs.title: 5. What are the different types of Normalization?
docs.text:
Normalization organizes data to reduce redundancy and improve data integrity.

  • 1NF: Atomic values (no repeating groups).
  • 2NF: 1NF + No partial dependency (all non-key attributes depend on the whole primary key).
  • 3NF: 2NF + No transitive dependency (non-key attributes depend only on the primary key).

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions Denormalization.
    • Follow-up: "Why would we ever want to denormalize a database?"
    • Answer: For read performance. Reducing joins by keeping redundant data can speed up complex queries (e.g., in Data Warehousing).

docs.title: 6. What is a Foreign Key?
docs.text:
A Foreign Key is a field (or collection of fields) in one table, that refers to the Primary Key in another table. It enforces Referential Integrity.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions 'Cascading'.
    • Follow-up: "What does ON DELETE CASCADE do?"
    • Answer: If the parent record is deleted, all child records referencing it are automatically deleted.

docs.title: 7. What is UNION vs UNION ALL?
docs.text:
• UNION: Combines result sets of two or more SELECT statements and removes duplicates.
  • UNION ALL: Combines result sets and keeps duplicates.

Chart: Performance Comparison

Operation Sorts Data? Removes Duplicates? Speed UNION Yes Yes Slower UNION ALL No No Faster

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate focuses on performance.
    • Follow-up: "If you know your datasets have no overlapping data, which one should you use?"
    • Answer: UNION ALL, to save the cost of the duplicate check/sort.

docs.title: 8. Explain NULL values in SQL.
docs.text:
NULL represents missing or undefined data. It is not equal to 0 or an empty string "".

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Handling NULLs.
    • Follow-up: "What is the result of SELECT * FROM Table WHERE Column <> NULL?"
    • Answer: It returns nothing. Comparison with NULL always results in UNKNOWN. You must use IS NOT NULL.

docs.title: 9. What is a wildcard?
docs.text: Wildcards are special characters used with the LIKE operator to search patterns. * % - Represents zero or more characters. * _ - Represents a single character.

docs.title: 10. What is an Alias in SQL?
docs.text:
An alias is a temporary name given to a table or column for the duration of a specific query.

SELECT first_name AS Name
FROM employees AS e

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Code readability.
    • Follow-up: "Can aliases be used in the WHERE clause?"
    • Answer: No (standard SQL), because WHERE executes before SELECT where the alias is assigned.

docs.title: 11. What is the DISTINCT keyword used for?
docs.text: It is used to return only distinct (different) values.

docs.title: 12. What are SQL Constraints?
docs.text: Rules applied to data columns. * NOT NULL * UNIQUE * PRIMARY KEY * FOREIGN KEY * CHECK * DEFAULT

docs.title: 13. What is a View?
docs.text:
A virtual table based on the result-set of an SQL statement. It contains rows and columns, just like a real table.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions security.
    • Follow-up: "How do Views improve security?"
    • Answer: They can restrict access to specific columns or rows without giving users access to the underlying full tables.

docs.title: 14. What is an Index?
docs.text:
A data structure that improves the speed of data retrieval operations on a database table.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate says 'makes everything faster'.
    • Follow-up: "Does an index make INSERT or UPDATE statements faster?"
    • Answer: No, it usually slows them down because the index must also be updated.

docs.title: 15. What is the difference between CHAR and VARCHAR?
docs.text:
• CHAR(n): Fixed length. Pads with spaces. Faster for fixed-length data.
  • VARCHAR(n): Variable length. Stores only characters used + length info. Space efficient.

docs.title: 16. What is the BETWEEN operator?
docs.text: Selects values within a given range. The values can be numbers, text, or dates. It is inclusive: begin and end values are included.

docs.title: 17. What is the IN operator?
docs.text: Allows you to specify multiple values in a WHERE clause. It is essentially a shorthand for multiple OR conditions.

docs.title: 18. What acts as a placeholder for a missing value?
docs.text: NULL.

docs.title: 19. How do you select all columns from a table named Users?
docs.text: SELECT * FROM Users;

docs.title: 20. How do you return the number of records that have non-null values in the Price column?
docs.text:
SELECT COUNT(Price) FROM Products;

(Note: COUNT(*) counts rows including nulls, COUNT(column) counts non-nulls).

docs.title: 21. Explain the different types of JOINs.
docs.text:
Join Type Description Diagram Representation INNER JOIN Returns records that have matching values in both tables. Intersection (A ∩ B) LEFT JOIN Returns all records from the left table, and the matched records from the right table. Left Circle (A) RIGHT JOIN Returns all records from the right table, and the matched records from the left table. Right Circle (B) FULL JOIN Returns all records when there is a match in either left or right table. Union (A ∪ B)

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions Cross Join.
    • Follow-up: "What is a CROSS JOIN and when is it dangerous?"
    • Answer: Cartesian product. It matches every row of A with every row of B. Dangerous on large tables as it returns N*M rows.

docs.title: 22. What is a Self-Join?
docs.text:
A self-join is a regular join, but the table is joined with itself. It requires using table aliases to distinguish the two instances.

Example Scenario: Finding employees and their managers in a single Employees table.

docs.title: 23. What is a Cross Join?
docs.text:
Produces a Cartesian product of the two tables.

SELECT * FROM TableA CROSS JOIN TableB;

If TableA has 5 rows and TableB has 10 rows, the result has 50 rows.

docs.title: 24. How do you find records in Table A that are NOT in Table B?
docs.text:
Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Using LEFT JOIN.
    • Answer: 
      SELECT A.id FROM A
LEFT JOIN B ON A.id = B.id
WHERE B.id IS NULL;
  • Path B: Using NOT IN.
    • Follow-up: "What is the risk of using NOT IN if Table B contains NULLs?"
    • Answer: If the subquery returns ANY NULL, NOT IN will return an empty set. LEFT JOIN or NOT EXISTS is safer.

docs.title: 25. What is the difference between JOIN and UNION?
docs.text:
• JOIN: Combines columns from two tables based on a related column. (Horizontal growth)
  • UNION: Combines rows from two queries. (Vertical growth)

docs.title: 26. Can you join a table to itself without using a Self-Join syntax?
docs.text: Technically, no. A "Self-Join" isn't a unique keyword, it is a concept. You use standard INNER or LEFT join syntax but reference the same table twice with aliases.

docs.title: 27. What happens if you join two tables on a column that has NULL values?
docs.text: NULL values never match other NULL values in standard SQL (unless ANSI_NULLS is off, which is rare). So, rows with NULL in the joining column will typically be excluded from an INNER JOIN.

docs.title: 28. What is a Natural Join?
docs.text: A NATURAL JOIN automatically joins tables based on columns with the same name and data types. Risk: If a new column with a matching name is added to one table later, the query logic might silently change or break.

docs.title: 29. Write a query to find the second highest salary.
docs.text:
Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Using LIMIT/OFFSET. 
    SELECT Salary FROM Employees ORDER BY Salary DESC LIMIT 1 OFFSET 1;
  • Path B: Using Subquery MAX. 
    SELECT MAX(Salary) FROM Employees WHERE Salary < (SELECT MAX(Salary) FROM Employees);

docs.title: 30. How do you perform a "Running Total"?
docs.text:
Using a Window Function (best practice) or a Self-Join (legacy).

Best Practice: 

SELECT Date, Amount, SUM(Amount) OVER (ORDER BY Date) as RunningTotal
FROM Sales;

docs.title: 31. What is a "Fan-out" trap in Joins?
docs.text: When joining two tables with a 1-to-many relationship, and then joining a third table with a 1-to-many relationship, the intermediate result explodes, causing incorrect aggregate calculations (e.g., SUM counts rows multiple times).

docs.title: 32. What is a SEMI JOIN?
docs.text: Returns rows from the first table where one or more matches exist in the second table. Often implemented with EXISTS. Unlike a join, it doesn't duplicate rows from the first table if multiple matches exist in the second.

docs.title: 33. What is an ANTI JOIN?
docs.text: Returns rows from the first table where NO matches exist in the second table. Often implemented with NOT EXISTS.

docs.title: 34. Explain the difference between INNER JOIN and WHERE clause for filtering.
docs.text: Functionally similar for Inner Joins. However, for LEFT JOIN, placing a condition in the ON clause vs the WHERE clause is critical. * ON: Filters the join before it happens (preserves left rows). * WHERE: Filters the result after the join (turns a Left Join into an Inner Join if filtering on the right table).

docs.title: 35. What is a composite key join?
docs.text:
Joining on multiple columns. 

FROM TableA a
JOIN TableB b ON a.col1 = b.col1 AND a.col2 = b.col2

docs.title: 36. How to select random rows from a table?
docs.text:
Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: MySQL. ORDER BY RAND() LIMIT 1 (Slow on large tables).
  • Path B: SQL Server. ORDER BY NEWID().
  • Path C: PostgreSQL. ORDER BY RANDOM().

docs.title: 37. Difference between INTERSECT and MINUS (or EXCEPT)?
docs.text:
• INTERSECT: Returns rows common to both query results.
  • MINUS/EXCEPT: Returns rows in the first result but not the second.

docs.title: 38. How to find duplicate records in a table?
docs.text:
SELECT ColumnA, COUNT(*)
FROM Table
GROUP BY ColumnA
HAVING COUNT(*) > 1;

docs.title: 39. How do you delete duplicate rows but keep one?
docs.text:
Using CTE (Common Table Expressions) and ROW_NUMBER(): 

WITH CTE AS (
    SELECT *, ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY ID ORDER BY ID) as rn
    FROM Table
)
DELETE FROM CTE WHERE rn > 1;

docs.title: 40. What is a recursive CTE?
docs.text:
A CTE that references itself. Useful for hierarchical data (e.g., Organization Charts, Bill of Materials).

graph TD
    A[Root] --> B[Child 1]
    A --> C[Child 2]
    B --> D[Grandchild 1]

docs.title: 41. What is the difference between COUNT(*) and COUNT(column_name)?
docs.text:
• COUNT(*): Counts all rows in the result set, including those with NULL values.
  • COUNT(column_name): Counts only rows where column_name is NOT NULL.

docs.title: 42. Can you group by a column that is not selected?
docs.text: Yes, standard SQL allows grouping by a column that is not in the SELECT list. However, you cannot select a non-aggregated column that is not in the GROUP BY list (unless using MySQL with specific settings or functional dependencies).

docs.title: 43. How does GROUP BY interact with NULL values?
docs.text: SQL considers all NULLs to be equal for grouping purposes. Therefore, all NULL values are grouped into a single bucket.

docs.title: 44. Write a query to find the department with the highest average salary.
docs.text:
SELECT DepartmentID, AVG(Salary) as AvgSalary
FROM Employees
GROUP BY DepartmentID
ORDER BY AvgSalary DESC
LIMIT 1;

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Using CTE.
    • Follow-up: "If there is a tie, how do you return both?"
    • Answer: Use RANK() or DENSE_RANK() in a CTE/Subquery and filter where rank = 1.

docs.title: 45. What is the HAVING clause?
docs.text: (Already covered briefly in #4, but deeper dive) It filters records that summarize the group. Example: SELECT Dept, SUM(Sal) FROM Emp GROUP BY Dept HAVING SUM(Sal) > 10000.

docs.title: 46. Can you use an alias in the HAVING clause?
docs.text: It depends on the SQL dialect. * MySQL: Yes. * SQL Server/Standard SQL: Generally No (because HAVING is evaluated before SELECT). You must repeat the aggregate function.

docs.title: 47. What is ROLLUP?
docs.text:
ROLLUP is an extension of the GROUP BY clause that produces sub-totals and a grand total.

SELECT Region, Country, SUM(Sales)
FROM Orders
GROUP BY ROLLUP (Region, Country);

docs.title: 48. What is CUBE?
docs.text:
CUBE generates sub-totals for all possible combinations of the grouping columns. It produces more rows than ROLLUP.

Table: ROLLUP vs CUBE

Group By (A, B) Resulting Groupings ROLLUP(A, B) (A, B), (A), () CUBE(A, B) (A, B), (A), (B), ()

docs.title: 49. What is GROUPING SETS?
docs.text: It allows you to specify exactly which groupings you want to compute, rather than all combinations (CUBE) or hierarchical ones (ROLLUP). It is more efficient if you only need specific aggregates.

docs.title: 50. How do you pivot data in SQL?
docs.text:
Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: CASE WHEN. (Universal standard) 
    SELECT
  SUM(CASE WHEN Year = 2020 THEN Revenue END) as Rev2020,
  SUM(CASE WHEN Year = 2021 THEN Revenue END) as Rev2021
FROM Sales;
  • Path B: PIVOT operator. (SQL Server / Oracle)

docs.title: 51. How do you unpivot data?
docs.text: Converting columns back into rows. * Use UNION ALL. * Use UNPIVOT operator (SQL Server/Oracle). * Use CROSS APPLY with VALUES (SQL Server).

docs.title: 52. What is the difference between WHERE and ON in a specific aggregation context?
docs.text: If filtering before aggregation, use WHERE. If filtering the joined rows before aggregation, use ON. Important: Filtering in WHERE on a LEFT JOINed table turns it into an INNER JOIN.

docs.title: 53. How to find the top 3 categories by sales?
docs.text:
SELECT Category, SUM(Sales)
FROM Orders
GROUP BY Category
ORDER BY SUM(Sales) DESC
LIMIT 3;

docs.title: 54. How to count distinct items in a group?
docs.text:
SELECT Department, COUNT(DISTINCT EmployeeID)
FROM Employees
GROUP BY Department;

docs.title: 55. What aggregate functions return a different data type than the input?
docs.text:
• COUNT() always returns an Integer (or BigInt).
  • AVG() usually returns a Float/Decimal, even if input is Integer.

docs.title: 56. Can you nest aggregate functions?
docs.text: No, you cannot do MAX(SUM(Salary)). You must use a subquery or CTE. Step 1: Calculate SUM(Salary) per group. Step 2: Calculate MAX() from that result.

docs.title: 57. What is the impact of indexing on aggregation?
docs.text: Indexes can significantly speed up MIN(), MAX(), and COUNT() operations, especially if the index covers the column being aggregated. A "Covering Index" avoids accessing the table rows entirely.

docs.title: 58. Calculate the percentage contribution of each row to the total sum.
docs.text:
Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Using Window Function. 
    SELECT Item, Amount,
       Amount * 100.0 / SUM(Amount) OVER() as Pct
FROM Sales;
  • Path B: Using Subquery. 
    SELECT Item, Amount,
       Amount * 100.0 / (SELECT SUM(Amount) FROM Sales)
FROM Sales;

docs.title: 59. How to find groups that have at least two specific items?
docs.text:
SELECT OrderID
FROM OrderDetails
WHERE ProductID IN ('A', 'B')
GROUP BY OrderID
HAVING COUNT(DISTINCT ProductID) = 2;

docs.title: 60. What is string_agg or group_concat?
docs.text: It concatenates values from multiple rows into a single string per group. * MySQL: GROUP_CONCAT(col) * PostgreSQL: STRING_AGG(col, ',') * SQL Server: STRING_AGG(col, ',')

docs.title: 61. What is a Window Function?
docs.text: Window functions perform calculations across a set of table rows that are somehow related to the current row. Unlike aggregate functions, they do not cause rows to become grouped into a single output row.

docs.title: 62. Difference between RANK(), DENSE_RANK(), and ROW_NUMBER()?
docs.text:
Consider data: 10, 20, 20, 30

Value ROW_NUMBER() RANK() DENSE_RANK() 10 1 1 1 20 2 2 2 20 3 2 2 30 4 4 3
  • ROW_NUMBER: Unique sequential number.
  • RANK: Skips numbers after ties (1, 2, 2, 4).
  • DENSE_RANK: No gaps after ties (1, 2, 2, 3).

docs.title: 63. What is the PARTITION BY clause?
docs.text: It divides the result set into partitions (groups) to which the window function is applied. Example: ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY Department ORDER BY Salary DESC) resets the counter for each Department.

docs.title: 64. What is LEAD and LAG?
docs.text:
• LAG(col, n): Accesses data from a previous row (n rows back).
  • LEAD(col, n): Accesses data from a following row (n rows forward).

Use Case: Calculating Year-Over-Year growth.

docs.title: 65. Calculate the difference between current and previous row's value.
docs.text:
SELECT Date, Value,
       Value - LAG(Value) OVER (ORDER BY Date) as Diff
FROM Metrics;

docs.title: 66. What is NTILE(n)?
docs.text: Distributes rows of an ordered partition into a specified number of approximately equal groups (buckets). Example: NTILE(4) divides data into Quartiles.

docs.title: 67. Explain the Frame clause (ROWS BETWEEN ...).
docs.text:
It defines the subset of rows within the partition to be considered for the calculation.

  • UNBOUNDED PRECEDING: Start at the first row of partition.
  • CURRENT ROW: Stop at current row.
  • n PRECEDING / FOLLOWING.

Example: Rolling 3-day Average 

AVG(Val) OVER (ORDER BY Date ROWS BETWEEN 2 PRECEDING AND CURRENT ROW)

docs.title: 68. What are Common Table Expressions (CTEs)?
docs.text: A temporary result set that you can reference within a SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE statement. Pros: Readability, recursion. Cons: Not indexed (usually), exists only for query duration.

docs.title: 69. CTE vs Subquery vs Temp Table?
docs.text: Feature CTE Subquery Temp Table Scope Single Query Single Query Session Recursive? Yes No No Indexed? No No Yes Performance Optimized by engine Optimized by engine Overhead to create

docs.title: 70. How to update a table based on values from another table?
docs.text:
UPDATE A
SET A.Value = B.Value
FROM TableA A
JOIN TableB B ON A.ID = B.ID;
(Syntax varies by dialect: MySQL uses JOIN in update, SQL Server uses FROM).

docs.title: 71. What is MERGE (or UPSERT)?
docs.text:
A single statement that performs UPDATE if a row exists, and INSERT if it does not.

MERGE INTO Target T
USING Source S ON T.id = S.id
WHEN MATCHED THEN UPDATE SET ...
WHEN NOT MATCHED THEN INSERT ...;

docs.title: 72. Explain JSON handling in modern SQL.
docs.text: Most modern DBs (Postgres, MySQL, SQL Server) support JSON types. * Extract: json_col ->> 'key' (Postgres). * Query: WHERE json_col ->> 'tags' LIKE '%urgent%'.

docs.title: 73. What is a Stored Procedure?
docs.text:
A prepared SQL code that you can save, so the code can be reused over and over again. It can accept parameters.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Pros/Cons.
    • Follow-up: "Why are they considered bad for version control?"
    • Answer: Logic is hidden in the DB, harder to diff/review than application code.

docs.title: 74. Function vs Stored Procedure?
docs.text:
• Function: Must return a value. Cannot modify DB state (usually). Can be used in SELECT statements.
  • Procedure: Can return zero or n values. Can modify DB state. Cannot be used in SELECT statements.

docs.title: 75. What is a Trigger?
docs.text: A special type of stored procedure that automatically runs when an event occurs in the database server (INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE). Risk: Can create invisible logic chains ("Magic") that are hard to debug.

docs.title: 76. How to find gaps in sequential IDs?
docs.text:
Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Using LEAD. 
    SELECT id + 1 as StartGap, next_id - 1 as EndGap
FROM (
    SELECT id, LEAD(id) OVER (ORDER BY id) as next_id
    FROM Table
) T
WHERE next_id - id > 1;

docs.title: 77. What is first_value() and last_value()?
docs.text: Returns the first or last value in an ordered set of values. Note: last_value default frame is RANGE BETWEEN UNBOUNDED PRECEDING AND CURRENT ROW, so it often just returns the current row value unless you change the frame to UNBOUNDED FOLLOWING.

docs.title: 78. What is the QUALIFY clause?
docs.text: (Used in Snowflake/Teradata) Filters the results of window functions, similar to how HAVING filters GROUP BY. Avoids the need for a subquery to filter by RANK().

docs.title: 79. How do you handle Time Zones in SQL?
docs.text: Always store in UTC (TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE in Postgres). Convert to local time only at the presentation layer or reporting query.

docs.title: 80. Identify overlapping date ranges.
docs.text:
SELECT *
FROM Bookings A
JOIN Bookings B ON A.Room = B.Room AND A.ID <> B.ID
WHERE A.Start < B.End AND A.End > B.Start;

docs.title: 81. Explain ACID properties.
docs.text:
• A - Atomicity: All or nothing. Transaction is a single unit.
  • C - Consistency: Database remains in a valid state before and after transaction.
  • I - Isolation: Transactions occur independently without interference.
  • D - Durability: Once committed, changes are permanent (survive power loss).

docs.title: 82. What are the Isolation Levels?
docs.text:
(Ordered from lowest isolation/highest concurrency to highest isolation/lowest concurrency)

  1. Read Uncommitted: Dirty reads allowed.
  2. Read Committed: No dirty reads. Phantom reads possible. (Default in many DBs).
  3. Repeatable Read: No non-repeatable reads. Phantom reads possible (prevented in some DBs like Postgres).
  4. Serializable: Strict sequential execution.

docs.title: 83. What is a "Dirty Read"?
docs.text: Reading uncommitted data from another transaction. If that transaction rolls back, you read invalid data.

docs.title: 84. What is a "Phantom Read"?
docs.text: A transaction executes a query returning a set of rows. Another transaction inserts a new row that matches the query. If the first transaction runs the query again, it sees the "phantom" row.

docs.title: 85. What is the N+1 problem?
docs.text: A performance issue where the application executes 1 initial query (N=1) and then executes N additional queries to fetch related data for each row. Fix: Use JOINs or batch fetching.

docs.title: 86. How does a B-Tree Index work?
docs.text:
It is a balanced tree structure that keeps data sorted and allows searches, sequential access, insertions, and deletions in logarithmic time.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Clustered vs Non-Clustered.
    • Follow-up: "How many clustered indexes can a table have?"
    • Answer: Only one, because it dictates the physical order of data storage.

docs.title: 87. What is Database Sharding?
docs.text: Horizontal partitioning of data across multiple databases/servers (shards) to spread load. Key Challenge: Cross-shard joins are expensive or impossible.

docs.title: 88. What is Partitioning?
docs.text: Splitting a large table into smaller, more manageable pieces (e.g., by Year). The DB engine can skip scanning partitions that don't match the query (Partition Pruning).

docs.title: 89. Explain "Explain Plan".
docs.text: A visualization of how the SQL engine intends to execute a query. Look for: Table Scans (bad), Index Seek/Scan (good), Sort operations (expensive).

docs.title: 90. What is a "Deadlock"?
docs.text: Two transactions are waiting for each other to give up a lock. The DB engine usually kills one to save the other.

docs.title: 91. Difference between OLTP and OLAP?
docs.text:
• OLTP (Online Transaction Processing): Fast, short transactions (INSERT, UPDATE). Normalized (3NF).
  • OLAP (Online Analytical Processing): Complex queries, historical data. Denormalized (Star Schema).

docs.title: 92. What is a Star Schema?
docs.text:
A data warehousing modeling technique with a central Fact Table (metrics) connected to multiple Dimension Tables (attributes).

graph TD
    Fact[Fact Sales]
    D1[Dim Date]
    D2[Dim Product]
    D3[Dim Customer]
    Fact --- D1
    Fact --- D2
    Fact --- D3

docs.title: 93. What is a Snowflake Schema?
docs.text: A variation of Star Schema where dimension tables are normalized (split into sub-dimensions). * Pros: Less space. * Cons: More joins.

docs.title: 94. How to optimize a slow query?
docs.text:
1. Check EXPLAIN plan.
  2. Add missing Indexes.
  3. Remove unnecessary columns (SELECT *).
  4. Check for Functions on columns in WHERE clause (sargability).
  5. Update Statistics.

docs.title: 95. What is "SARGable"?
docs.text: Search ARGument ABLE. A query is sargable if it can take advantage of an index. * Bad: WHERE YEAR(date_col) = 2023 (Function on column blocks index). * Good: WHERE date_col >= '2023-01-01' AND date_col < '2024-01-01'.

docs.title: 96. What is a Materialized View?
docs.text: A view whose result is physically stored (cached) on disk and refreshed periodically. Good for expensive aggregations.

docs.title: 97. What is optimistic vs pessimistic locking?
docs.text:
• Pessimistic: Lock the record as soon as you select it for update.
  • Optimistic: Don't lock. Check version/timestamp on update. If changed by someone else, fail.

docs.title: 98. What is Vertical Scaling vs Horizontal Scaling?
docs.text:
• Vertical: Bigger machine (more RAM/CPU). Easiest for SQL DBs.
  • Horizontal: More machines (Read Replicas, Sharding). Harder for SQL DBs.

docs.title: 99. What is CAP Theorem?
docs.text: In a distributed system, you can only pick 2: * Consistency. * Availability. * Partition Tolerance. * Traditional SQL DBs usually choose CA (single node) or CP (distributed).

docs.title: 100. Write a query to find the 3rd highest salary without using LIMIT/TOP.
docs.text:
SELECT Salary
FROM Employees e1
WHERE 2 = (
    SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT Salary)
    FROM Employees e2
    WHERE e2.Salary > e1.Salary
);

End of Interview Questions

docs.title: System Design Interview Questions & Answers (100+)
docs.text: This guide contains 100+ System Design interview questions, ranging from core concepts to complex distributed system scenarios. Each question includes a model answer and potential follow-up paths based on the candidate's response.

docs.title: 1. What is the difference between Vertical Scaling and Horizontal Scaling?
docs.text:
Feature Vertical Scaling (Scale Up) Horizontal Scaling (Scale Out) Definition Adding more power (CPU, RAM) to an existing machine. Adding more machines to the resource pool. Limit Hard limit based on hardware capacity. Theoretically infinite (constrained by software/network). Downtime Usually requires downtime to upgrade. No downtime (add nodes dynamically). Complexity Low (no distributed logic). High (requires load balancing, consistency mgmt).

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions Cost.
    • Follow-up: "At what point does vertical scaling become more expensive than horizontal?"
    • Answer: Specialized high-end hardware follows a non-linear price curve. Two medium servers are often cheaper than one super-server.
  • Path B: Candidate focuses on Databases.
    • Follow-up: "Why is it harder to horizontally scale a traditional SQL database?"
    • Answer: ACID compliance and JOINS are difficult to maintain across distributed nodes.

docs.title: 2. Explain Load Balancing (L4 vs L7).
docs.text:
A Load Balancer distributes incoming network traffic across a group of backend servers.

  • Layer 4 (Transport Layer): Routes traffic based on IP address and Port (TCP/UDP). It is packet-level load balancing.
  • Layer 7 (Application Layer): Routes traffic based on content (URL, Cookies, Headers). It is request-level load balancing.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Performance.
    • Follow-up: "Which is faster, L4 or L7?"
    • Answer: L4 is faster because it doesn't need to decrypt/inspect the payload.
  • Path B: Security.
    • Follow-up: "Why is L7 better for security?"
    • Answer: It can inspect traffic for SQL injection, terminate SSL, and implement smarter rate limiting.

docs.title: 3. What is the CAP Theorem?
docs.text:
In a distributed data store, you can strictly provide only two of the three guarantees:

  1. Consistency: Every read receives the most recent write or an error.
  2. Availability: Every request receives a (non-error) response, without the guarantee that it contains the most recent write.
  3. Partition Tolerance: The system continues to operate despite an arbitrary number of messages being dropped or delayed by the network.
graph TD
    C[Consistency] --- A[Availability]
    A --- P[Partition Tolerance]
    P --- C
    style C fill:#f9f,stroke:#333
    style A fill:#ff9,stroke:#333
    style P fill:#9ff,stroke:#333

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: "I choose CA".
    • Follow-up: "Can a distributed system actually be CA?"
    • Answer: No. In a distributed system, network partitions will happen. You effectively choose between CP (stop serving requests) or AP (serve stale data) when a partition occurs.

docs.title: 4. Compare ACID vs BASE models.
docs.text:
• ACID (Relational DBs): Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability. Focuses on strict data integrity.
  • BASE (NoSQL DBs):
    • Basically Available: System guarantees availability.
    • Soft state: State may change over time, even without input.
    • Eventual consistency: System will become consistent over time.

docs.title: 5. What are the common Caching Strategies?
docs.text:
1. Cache Aside (Lazy Loading): App checks cache. If miss, reads DB, writes to cache.
  2. Read-Through: App asks cache. Cache fetches from DB if miss.
  3. Write-Through: App writes to cache and DB synchronously.
  4. Write-Back (Write-Behind): App writes to cache. Cache writes to DB asynchronously.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Write-Back.
    • Follow-up: "What is the major risk of Write-Back?"
    • Answer: Data loss if the cache crashes before flushing data to the persistent DB.

docs.title: 6. What is a CDN (Content Delivery Network)?
docs.text:
A network of geographically distributed servers that deliver static content (images, CSS, JS, videos) to users based on their location.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Push vs Pull.
    • Follow-up: "How does the CDN get the content?"
    • Answer: Push: You upload to CDN. Pull: CDN fetches from Origin on first request (cache miss).

docs.title: 7. Stateless vs Stateful Architecture?
docs.text:
• Stateless: Server retains no client information between requests. Every request must contain all necessary info (e.g., JWT). Scales easily.
  • Stateful: Server remembers client data (Session ID) from previous requests. Harder to scale horizontally (requires Sticky Sessions).

docs.title: 8. Latency vs Throughput?
docs.text:
• Latency: Time taken to process a single request (Speed).
  • Throughput: Number of requests processed per unit time (Capacity).

Analogy: * Latency: How fast a car drives. * Throughput: How many cars pass a point per hour.

docs.title: 9. What are common Availability Patterns?
docs.text:
1. Fail-over:
    • Active-Passive: Heartbeat sends signal. If Active dies, Passive takes over.
    • Active-Active: Both handle traffic.
  2. Replication: Master-Slave, Master-Master.

docs.title: 10. How does DNS Resolution work?
docs.text:
1. Browser checks local cache.
  2. OS checks hosts file.
  3. Query sent to Recursive Resolver (ISP).
  4. Resolver queries Root Server (.) -> TLD Server (.com) -> Authoritative Name Server (example.com).
  5. IP returned to browser.

docs.title: 11. What is Consistent Hashing?
docs.text:
A technique to distribute data across nodes in a way that minimizes reorganization when nodes are added or removed. Instead of hash(key) % N, it maps keys and nodes to a "Ring" (0 to 2^32).

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Hotspots.
    • Follow-up: "What if one node is very powerful or gets too much data?"
    • Answer: Use "Virtual Nodes" (vnodes). Map one physical node to multiple points on the ring.

docs.title: 12. Forward Proxy vs Reverse Proxy?
docs.text:
• Forward Proxy: Sit before the Client. Masks the Client ID. (e.g., VPN, Corporate Filter).
  • Reverse Proxy: Sit before the Server. Masks the Server ID. (e.g., Nginx, Load Balancer).

docs.title: 13. Polling vs WebSockets vs Server-Sent Events (SSE).
docs.text: Feature Polling (Short/Long) WebSockets SSE Direction Client -> Server Bidirectional Server -> Client Connection New connection per request (Short) Persistent TCP Persistent HTTP Use Case Dashboards, low frequency Chat, Gaming News feeds, Stock Tickers

docs.title: 14. LSM Tree vs B-Tree (Database Indexing).
docs.text:
• B-Tree: (Used in SQL) Optimized for Reads. Data stored in sorted pages. Update in-place.
  • LSM (Log-Structured Merge): (Used in Cassandra, Kafka) Optimized for Writes. Appends to log, merges in background.

docs.title: 15. What are common Rate Limiting Algorithms?
docs.text:
1. Token Bucket: Tokens added at rate r. Request consumes token. (Allows Bursts).
  2. Leaky Bucket: Requests enter queue, processed at constant rate. (Smooths traffic).
  3. Fixed Window Counter: Counter resets every minute. (Edge case: double bursts at boundary).
  4. Sliding Window Log: Precise, stores timestamps. (High memory).
  5. Sliding Window Counter: Hybrid approach.

docs.title: 16. Strong vs Eventual Consistency?
docs.text:
• Strong: After a write, any subsequent read returns the new value. (High Latency).
  • Eventual: After a write, reads may return old value for a "window of inconsistency". (Low Latency).

docs.title: 17. What is a Heartbeat?
docs.text: A periodic signal sent by a component to indicate it is alive and functioning. Used in Fail-over mechanisms.

docs.title: 18. What is a Checksum?
docs.text: A small-sized datum derived from a block of digital data for the purpose of detecting errors that may have been introduced during its transmission or storage.

docs.title: 19. What is a Bloom Filter?
docs.text: A probabilistic data structure used to test whether an element is a member of a set. * Returns either "Possibly in set" or "Definitely not in set". * Never returns False Negative. Can return False Positive. * Use Case: Checking if a username is taken before hitting the DB.

docs.title: 20. What is Quorum?
docs.text: The minimum number of votes that a distributed transaction has to obtain to be allowed to perform an operation in a distributed system. * R + W > N (Read nodes + Write nodes > Total nodes) guarantees strong consistency.

docs.title: 21. How does Leader Election work?
docs.text: Process of designating a single process as the organizer of some task among several computers (nodes). * Algorithms: Paxos, Raft, Zookeeper (ZAB).

docs.title: 22. What is Idempotency?
docs.text: An operation is idempotent if applying it multiple times has the same effect as applying it once. * POST is generally NOT idempotent. * PUT and DELETE ARE idempotent. * Implementation: Use a unique "Idempotency Key" in request headers.

docs.title: 23. What is Long-Polling?
docs.text:
1. Client sends request.
  2. Server holds request open until data is available.
  3. Server sends response.
  4. Client immediately sends new request.

docs.title: 24. Peer-to-Peer (P2P) Networks?
docs.text: Decentralized network where each node acts as both client and server (peer). * Pros: High availability, no single point of failure. * Cons: Security, slower discovery (Gossip protocol).

docs.title: 25. What is Service Discovery?
docs.text: How microservices locate each other on a network (IP + Port). * Client-Side: Client queries Service Registry (Netflix Eureka), then calls service. * Server-Side: Client calls Load Balancer (AWS ELB), LB queries Registry.

docs.title: 26. What is Database Partitioning (Sharding)?
docs.text:
Breaking up a large database into smaller, more manageable parts called shards.

Methods: 1. Horizontal Sharding: Rows split by key (e.g., UserID 1-1000 in DB1). 2. Vertical Sharding: Columns split by feature (e.g., User Profile in DB1, User Photos in DB2). 3. Directory Based: Lookup table knows where data is.

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Cross-shard joins.
    • Follow-up: "How do you handle a query that needs data from multiple shards?"
    • Answer: Perform application-level joins or de-normalize data to avoid the join.

docs.title: 27. Master-Slave vs Master-Master Replication?
docs.text:
• Master-Slave: Writes go to Master. Reads go to Slaves.
    • Pros: Simple. Strong consistency on Master.
    • Cons: Master is SPOF for writes. Replication lag.
  • Master-Master: Writes go to any Master.
    • Pros: High availability for writes.
    • Cons: Write conflicts (Split Brain). Complexity.

docs.title: 28. What is the Two-Phase Commit (2PC)?
docs.text:
A distributed algorithm that coordinates all the processes that participate in a distributed atomic transaction on whether to commit or abort (roll back) the transaction.

  1. Prepare Phase: Coordinator asks "Can you commit?". Nodes lock resources and say "Yes".

  2. Commit Phase: If all "Yes", Coordinator says "Commit". Else "Rollback".

  3. Downside: Blocking protocol. Slow.

docs.title: 29. What is Saga Pattern?
docs.text: A sequence of local transactions. Each local transaction updates the database and publishes an event or message to trigger the next local transaction in the saga. * Compensation: If a step fails, execute compensating transactions to undo changes.

docs.title: 30. Explain "Split Brain" in distributed systems.
docs.text: A condition where the network partitions, and two nodes both believe they are the Master/Leader. They both accept writes, leading to data corruption/divergence. * Solution: Quorum (Majority vote).

docs.title: 31. Row-Oriented vs Column-Oriented Databases?
docs.text:
• Row-Oriented (Postgres, MySQL): Stores data by row. Efficient for writing/reading whole records (OLTP).
  • Column-Oriented (Redshift, Cassandra): Stores data by column. Efficient for aggregating specific columns over many rows (OLAP).

docs.title: 32. What is NoSQL? Types of NoSQL databases?
docs.text:
Non-relational databases. Scalable, flexible schemas.

  1. Key-Value: Redis, DynamoDB. (Fast, simple).
  2. Document: MongoDB, CouchDB. (JSON-like, flexible).
  3. Column-Family: Cassandra, HBase. (Write heavy, massive scale).
  4. Graph: Neo4j. (Relations, Friends).

docs.title: 33. When to use Cassandra?
docs.text:
• Heavy Write throughput.
  • Need linear horizontal scalability.
  • Can tolerate eventual consistency.
  • Don't need complex JOINS.

docs.title: 34. How does Redis persist data?
docs.text:
1. RDB (Snapshotting): Saves point-in-time snapshots of dataset at intervals. (Fast restart, data loss possible).
  2. AOF (Append Only File): Logs every write operation. (Slower restart, higher durability).

docs.title: 35. What is a "Thundering Herd" problem?
docs.text: A large number of processes/users waiting for an event occur simultaneously when the event happens (e.g., Cache Expiry). They all hit the database at once, crashing it. * Solution: Stagger expiration times (Jitter) or use a "Mutex" to let only one populate the cache.

docs.title: 36. What is "Backpressure"?
docs.text: A feedback mechanism in data flow. If the consumer cannot keep up with the producer, it signals the producer to slow down. * Without Backpressure: Consumer runs out of memory (OOM) buffering incoming data.

docs.title: 37. What is the difference between PUT and PATCH?
docs.text:
• PUT: Replaces the entire resource. (Idempotent).
  • PATCH: Applies a partial update to the resource. (Not necessarily idempotent).

docs.title: 38. What is "Database Federation"?
docs.text: Splitting data by function across multiple distinct databases (e.g., Forum DB, User DB, Product DB). * Pros: Less coupling. * Cons: No cross-DB joins.

docs.title: 39. Explain "Gossip Protocol".
docs.text: A peer-to-peer communication protocol where nodes periodically exchange state information with random other nodes. Info spreads like a virus (epidemic). * Used in Cassandra/Dynamo for cluster state management.

docs.title: 40. What is a "Dead Letter Queue" (DLQ)?
docs.text: A service implementation to store messages that meet one or more of the following criteria: 1. Message that cannot be delivered. 2. Message processing failed N times. * Allows debugging of bad messages without blocking the main queue.

docs.title: 41. What is "Geohashing"?
docs.text: A system for encoding a geographic location into a short string of letters and digits. * Grid-based. * Shared prefix indicates proximity. * Use Case: Yelp, Uber (Find nearby).

docs.title: 42. What is QuadTree?
docs.text: A tree data structure where each internal node has exactly four children. Used to partition a two-dimensional space. * Use Case: Spatial indexing. Better than Geohash for non-uniform distribution of points.

docs.title: 43. Pull vs Push models in Monitoring/Metrics?
docs.text:
• Push (StatsD, Telegraf): App sends metrics to collector.
    • Pros: App controls frequency. Short-lived jobs supported.
  • Pull (Prometheus): Collector scrapes metrics endpoint on App.
    • Pros: Central control. App doesn't need to know destination.

docs.title: 44. What is a "Circuit Breaker"?
docs.text: A design pattern used to detect failures and encapsulate the logic of preventing a failure from constantly recurring. * Closed: Requests pass through. * Open: Requests fail immediately (after threshold of errors). * Half-Open: Allow test request. If success, Close.

docs.title: 45. What is "Message Acknowledgment"?
docs.text: Ensures delivery. * At-most-once: Fire and forget. * At-least-once: Retry until Ack received. (Consumer must handle duplicates). * Exactly-once: Hardest to achieve (Kafka transactions).

docs.title: 46. What is "Compensating Transaction"?
docs.text: In a distributed transaction (Saga), a transaction that undoes the effect of a previous transaction that had committed. (e.g., Refund money if Order fails).

docs.title: 47. Explain "Isolation Levels" in context of Distributed Systems.
docs.text:
• Read Uncommitted
  • Read Committed
  • Repeatable Read
  • Serializable
  • Snapshot Isolation: Reads see a consistent snapshot of the DB from start of transaction.

docs.title: 48. What is "HyperLogLog"?
docs.text: A probabilistic data structure used for estimating the cardinality (count of unique items) of a set. * Uses very little memory compared to storing all unique IDs. * Use Case: Count unique daily visitors (100M+).

docs.title: 49. What is "Tombstone" in deletion?
docs.text: In systems like Cassandra (LSM), you cannot physically delete a row immediately (immutable files). Instead, you write a "Tombstone" marker. The data is actually removed during Compaction.

docs.title: 50. File Storage vs Block Storage vs Object Storage?
docs.text: Type Access Example Use Case Block Low-level blocks via OS (Fast) AWS EBS, HDD Databases, OS Boot File Hierarchical files (Shared) AWS EFS, NAS Shared directories Object API (HTTP), Metadata heavy AWS S3 Images, Backups, Static Web

docs.title: 51. Microservices vs Monolith?
docs.text:
• Monolith: Single codebase, single build, single deployment.
    • Pros: Simple to develop/test/deploy initially. Fast internal calls.
    • Cons: Tight coupling. Hard to scale specific parts. Long build times.
  • Microservices: Collection of small, independent services communicating via APIs.
    • Pros: Loose coupling. Scale independently. Technology agnostic.
    • Cons: Complexity of distributed system. Network latency. Data consistency.

docs.title: 52. REST vs GraphQL vs gRPC?
docs.text: Feature REST GraphQL gRPC Protocol HTTP/1.1 HTTP/1.1 or 2 HTTP/2 Data Format JSON (usually) JSON Protobuf (Binary) Fetching Over-fetching / Under-fetching Exact fetching - Use Case Public APIs, Simple Complex Client Data Needs Internal Microservices

docs.title: 53. What is an API Gateway?
docs.text: A server that acts as an entry point for a system, sitting between clients and microservices. * Responsibilities: Routing, Authentication, Rate Limiting, SSL Termination, Caching.

docs.title: 54. What is "Service Mesh"?
docs.text: A dedicated infrastructure layer for handling service-to-service communication. (e.g., Istio, Linkerd). * Sidecar Pattern: A proxy container sits next to every service instance to handle network logic.

docs.title: 55. What is the Sidecar Pattern?
docs.text: Attaching a secondary component (sidecar) to the primary application to provide support features (logging, proxying, monitoring) without changing the app code.

docs.title: 56. What is "Event Sourcing"?
docs.text: Storing the state of a system as a sequence of events (e.g., "AccountCreated", "MoneyDeposited") rather than just the current state (Balance=100). * Pros: Audit trail, ability to replay history. * Cons: Complexity, Event schema evolution.

docs.title: 57. CQRS (Command Query Responsibility Segregation)?
docs.text: Separating the Read (Query) and Write (Command) models. * Write Model: Optimized for updates (Normalized). * Read Model: Optimized for reading (Denormalized/Views). * Often paired with Event Sourcing.

docs.title: 58. What is "Strangler Fig Pattern"?
docs.text: A migration pattern to modernize a Monolith. 1. Put a Proxy/Gateway in front of Monolith. 2. Route specific traffic to new Microservices. 3. Slowly "strangle" the Monolith until it's gone.

docs.title: 59. Explain OAuth 2.0.
docs.text: An authorization framework. * Roles: Resource Owner (User), Client (App), Authorization Server, Resource Server (API). * Flows: Authorization Code (Servers), Implicit (Browser/Mobile - deprecated), Client Credentials (Machine-to-Machine).

docs.title: 60. What is JWT (JSON Web Token)?
docs.text: A compact, URL-safe means of representing claims to be transferred between two parties. * Structure: Header . Payload . Signature * Stateless: Server verifies signature, doesn't need to look up session in DB.

docs.title: 61. Symmetric vs Asymmetric Encryption?
docs.text:
• Symmetric: Same key for encryption and decryption. (Fast).
  • Asymmetric: Public Key encrypts, Private Key decrypts. (Secure exchange, slower).
  • HTTPS: Uses Asymmetric to exchange a Symmetric key, then uses Symmetric for data.

docs.title: 62. What is SSL/TLS Handshake?
docs.text:
1. Client Hello (I support TLS 1.2, Cipher Suites).
  2. Server Hello (Let's use TLS 1.2).
  3. Server sends Certificate (Public Key).
  4. Client verifies Certificate with CA.
  5. Client generates Session Key, encrypts with Server's Public Key, sends to Server.
  6. Server decrypts with Private Key. Secure channel established.

docs.title: 63. What is "Dependency Injection"?
docs.text: A design pattern where an object receives other objects that it depends on (dependencies) from an external source rather than creating them itself. * Decouples code. Makes testing easier (mocking).

docs.title: 64. What is Docker vs Kubernetes?
docs.text:
• Docker: Containerization platform. Packages app + libs into a portable container.
  • Kubernetes (K8s): Container Orchestration. Manages deployment, scaling, and networking of containers.

docs.title: 65. What is "Blue/Green Deployment"?
docs.text: Run two identical environments. * Blue: Live. * Green: New version (Idle). * Switch Router from Blue to Green. * Pros: Instant rollback.

docs.title: 66. What is "Canary Deployment"?
docs.text: Roll out the update to a small subset of users (Canaries) first. Monitor for errors. If safe, roll out to the rest.

docs.title: 67. What is "Serverless" (FaaS)?
docs.text: Cloud computing model where the cloud provider dynamically manages the allocation of machine resources. (AWS Lambda). * Pros: Pay per execution. No server management. * Cons: Cold starts. Vendor lock-in.

docs.title: 68. What is "Publisher/Subscriber" (Pub/Sub) pattern?
docs.text: Messaging pattern where Senders (Publishers) do not program the messages to be sent directly to specific Receivers (Subscribers). Instead, messages are categorized. * Decouples components.

docs.title: 69. RabbitMQ vs Kafka?
docs.text:
• RabbitMQ: Traditional Message Broker. Smart Broker / Dumb Consumer. Good for complex routing logic. Messages removed after ack.
  • Kafka: Distributed Event Streaming. Dumb Broker / Smart Consumer. High throughput. Messages persisted on disk for retention period.

docs.title: 70. What is "Batch Processing" vs "Stream Processing"?
docs.text:
• Batch: Process a large volume of data all at once (e.g., Daily Hadoop job). High Latency.
  • Stream: Process data item by item as it arrives (e.g., Flink, Spark Streaming). Real-time.

docs.title: 71. What is a "Reverse Index" (Inverted Index)?
docs.text: Maps content (words) to its location (documents). * Use Case: Search Engines (Elasticsearch). "Apple" -> [Doc1, Doc3].

docs.title: 72. Explain "MapReduce".
docs.text: Programming model for processing large data sets. 1. Map: Filter and sort data. 2. Reduce: Aggregate the data.

docs.title: 73. What is "Data Lake" vs "Data Warehouse"?
docs.text:
• Data Lake (S3): Stores raw, unstructured data. Low cost. Schema-on-Read.
  • Data Warehouse (Snowflake): Stores processed, structured data. High cost. Schema-on-Write.

docs.title: 74. What is "ETL"?
docs.text: Extract, Transform, Load. * Process of moving data from source systems to a Data Warehouse.

docs.title: 75. What is "Distributed Tracing"?
docs.text: A method used to profile and monitor applications, especially those built using a microservices architecture. * Assigns a unique Request ID (Trace ID) at ingress and propagates it through all services. (Jaeger, Zipkin).

docs.title: 76. Design a URL Shortener (TinyURL).
docs.text:
• Core Req: Shorten long URL, Redirect short to long. High Read/Write ratio (100:1).
  • Capacity: 1B new URLs/month. Storage: 500 bytes per URL = 500GB/month. 5 Years = 30TB.
  • Key Idea: Base62 Encoding. 7 chars = $62^7$ = 3.5 Trillion combinations.
  • DB: K-V Store (DynamoDB).
  • Collision: Pre-generate keys (Key Generation Service) to avoid DB lock.

docs.title: 77. Design a Chat System (WhatsApp).
docs.text:
• Core Req: 1-on-1 chat, Group chat, Online status.
  • Protocol: WebSockets or XMPP (legacy).
  • Storage: HBase or Cassandra (Write heavy).
  • Flow: User A -> Gateway -> Chat Server -> User B.
  • Unread: If User B offline, store in Push Notification Queue.

docs.title: 78. Design Instagram (News Feed).
docs.text:
• Core Req: Upload photos, Follow users, Generate Feed.
  • Feed Generation:
    • Pull Model: Query DB for all followings on load. (Slow).
    • Push Model (Fan-out on Write): When User A posts, push ID to all followers' pre-computed feed cache. (Fast reads).
  • Storage: S3 for Images. SQL/NoSQL for Metadata.

docs.title: 79. Design Rate Limiter.
docs.text:
• Placement: API Gateway or Sidecar.
  • Storage: Redis (Sorted Sets or Counters) because it's fast.
  • Algorithm: Token Bucket or Sliding Window.
  • Distributed: Use Lua scripts in Redis for atomicity.

docs.title: 80. Design YouTube (Video Streaming).
docs.text:
• Core Req: Upload, Transcode, Stream.
  • Upload: Split video into chunks. Upload to S3.
  • Processing: Lambda/Worker Queue to Transcode into multiple formats (720p, 1080p) and codecs (H.264, VP9).
  • Streaming: DASH or HLS protocols. Adaptive Bitrate Streaming (switch quality based on bandwidth).
  • CDN: Critical for serving chunks.

docs.title: 81. Design Typeahead Suggestion (Google Search).
docs.text:
• Data Structure: Trie (Prefix Tree).
  • Optimization: Store top 5 popular queries at each Trie node.
  • Storage: In-memory (Redis) or custom implementation.
  • Update: Asynchronously update weights based on logs.

docs.title: 82. Design a Web Crawler.
docs.text:
• Components:
    • Seed URLs: Starting point.
    • URL Frontier: Priority Queue of URLs to visit.
    • Fetcher: Downloads HTML.
    • Parser: Extracts links.
    • Dedup: Checksum/Bloom Filter to avoid cycles/duplicates.
  • Politeness: Respect robots.txt and rate limits.

docs.title: 83. Design Notification System.
docs.text:
• Inputs: Email, SMS, Push.
  • Components:
    • Notification Service: Receives requests.
    • Queue: Buffers requests (RabbitMQ).
    • Workers: Call 3rd party providers (SendGrid, Twilio, APNS).
  • Reliability: Retry mechanism for failed calls.

docs.title: 84. Design Dropbox (File Sync).
docs.text:
• Chunking: Split files into 4MB chunks. Only upload changed chunks (Differential Sync).
  • Hashing: Hash each chunk. Deduplication (if another user has same chunk, just point to it).
  • Client: Watcher process detects FS changes.
  • Metadata DB: Strong consistency (ACID) required for file namespace.

docs.title: 85. Design Twitter Search.
docs.text:
• Challenge: Real-time indexing.
  • Solution: EarlyBird (Twitter's internal).
  • Architecture: Ingest Tweets -> Tokenize -> Write to In-Memory Shards (based on Tweet ID or Time).
  • Query: Scatter-Gather to all shards -> Merge results.

docs.title: 86. Design Uber (Ride Sharing).
docs.text:
• Core Req: Match Rider with nearby Driver.
  • Location: Drivers send GPS every 3s.
  • Geo-Index: Geohash or S2 Geometry. Redis GEO commands.
  • Matching: Search nearby drivers in Redis. Lock driver. Send request.

docs.title: 87. Design Ticketmaster (Booking System).
docs.text:
• Challenge: Concurrency. 10,000 users want the same seat.
  • Locking:
    • Optimistic: User selects seat. On checkout, check if still available.
    • Pessimistic: Lock seat for 10 mins when selected. Release if timeout. (Better UX).
  • Queue: Virtual Waiting Room if traffic > capacity.

docs.title: 88. Design Unique ID Generator (Snowflake).
docs.text:
• Req: Unique, Numerical, Time-sortable, High throughput.
  • Twitter Snowflake: 64-bit Integer.
    • 1 bit: Sign.
    • 41 bits: Timestamp (millis).
    • 10 bits: Machine ID (Datacenter + Worker).
    • 12 bits: Sequence Number (per millisecond).

docs.title: 89. Design Key-Value Store (like DynamoDB).
docs.text:
• Partitioning: Consistent Hashing.
  • Replication: Preference List (Top N nodes in ring).
  • Consistency: Tunable (W + R > N). Vector Clocks for versioning.
  • Gossip: For node membership.

docs.title: 90. Design Metrics Monitoring System (Datadog).
docs.text:
• Write Heavy: Time Series Database (TSDB) like InfluxDB or Prometheus (internally Whisper/TSDB).
  • Data Model: Metric Name, Tags (Host, Region), Timestamp, Value.
  • Downsampling: Keep raw data for 7 days. Roll up to 1-min avg for 30 days. 1-hour avg for 1 year.

docs.title: 91. Design Leaderboard.
docs.text:
• Real-time: Redis Sorted Sets (ZSET).
    • ZADD leaderboard <score> <user>
    • ZREVRANGE leaderboard 0 9 (Top 10).
  • Scale: Shard by range of scores if too big? No, shard by UserID to update score, use Gatherer to merge top lists.

docs.title: 92. Design Payment System.
docs.text:
• Critical: ACID, Idempotency, Audit Logs.
  • Reconciliation: Asynchronous process to compare DB records with Bank Statements.
  • Double Entry Ledger: Every transaction has a Debit and Credit. Sum must be zero.

docs.title: 93. Design a URL Crawler Cache/Proxy.
docs.text:
• Req: Save bandwidth.
  • Hashing: Hash(URL) -> File Path.
  • Expiry: Check HTTP Headers (Cache-Control, ETag).

docs.title: 94. Design Amazon Shopping Cart.
docs.text:
• Availability: Must never fail to add item.
  • Consistency: Eventual.
  • Conflict: Merging carts from different devices (Session vs Logged In). DynamoDB was built for this (Shopping Cart anomaly).

docs.title: 95. Design 'Nearby Friends'.
docs.text:
• Updates: Sparse updates (only when moving significant distance).
  • P2P: Not viable for mobile.
  • Server: Ephemeral location history. Redis Geo.

docs.title: 96. Design Distributed Job Scheduler.
docs.text:
• Coordination: Zookeeper/Etcd to elect Leader.
  • Storage: Tasks in DB.
  • Execution: Workers poll or Leader pushes to Kafka.
  • Ack: Worker acks upon completion. If timeout, re-queue.

docs.title: 97. Design 'Who Viewed Your Profile'.
docs.text:
• Volume: High write volume.
  • Async: Push event to Kafka. Consumer aggregates in batch.
  • Storage: NoSQL (Wide Column). Key: ProfileOwner_Date, Col: ViewerID.

docs.title: 98. Design Collaborative Editor (Google Docs).
docs.text:
• Algorithm: Operational Transformation (OT) or CRDT (Conflict-free Replicated Data Type).
  • Communication: WebSockets for real-time chars.

docs.title: 99. Design API Rate Limiter (Distributed).
docs.text:
• Problem: Syncing counters across nodes is slow.
  • Solution: Sticky Sessions (Local memory) OR Redis (Centralized, but latency penalty). OR "Gossip" limit (approximate).

docs.title: 100. Design a Proximity Service (Yelp).
docs.text:
• Read/Write: High Read (Search), Low Write (Business moves).
  • Index: Static QuadTree. Store in SQL or NoSQL.
  • Search: Find QuadTree node, search it + 8 neighbors.

End of System Design Questions

docs.title: TypeScript Interview Questions & Answers (100+)
docs.text: This guide contains 100+ TypeScript interview questions, ranging from basic to advanced. Each question includes a model answer, code snippets, and potential follow-up paths based on the candidate's response.

docs.title: 1. What is TypeScript?
docs.text:
TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript developed by Microsoft that adds static typing and class-based object-oriented programming to the language. It compiles (transpiles) to plain JavaScript.

Key Features: * Static Typing: Checks types at compile time. * Object-Oriented: Classes, Interfaces, Inheritance. * ES6+ Support: Compiles modern JS down to older versions (ES5, ES3).

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions "Superset".

    • Follow-up: "What does it mean to be a superset? Can I run TypeScript directly in the browser?"
    • Answer: No, browsers cannot execute TS directly. It must be transpiled to JS. "Superset" means any valid JS code is also valid TS code.

  • Path B: Candidate focuses on Types.

    • Follow-up: "Is the typing strong or weak? Static or dynamic?"
    • Answer: TypeScript is statically typed (checked at compile time), but the underlying JS is dynamically typed. It allows for "any" type which effectively opts out of type checking.

docs.title: 2. What are the primitive types in TypeScript?
docs.text:
TypeScript supports the same primitives as JavaScript, plus a few more.

Type Description Example number All numbers (integers, floats) let x: number = 10; string Text data let s: string = "Hi"; boolean True/False let b: boolean = true; null Intentional absence of value let n: null = null; undefined Uninitialized variable let u: undefined = undefined; symbol Unique identifier (ES6) let sym: symbol = Symbol(); bigint Large integers (ES2020) let big: bigint = 100n;

docs.title: 3. What is the any type?
docs.text:
any is a type that disables type checking for a variable. It allows you to assign any value to it and access any property or method on it without errors.

Use Cases: * Migrating a JS project to TS incrementally. * Working with 3rd party libraries without type definitions.

Risk: It defeats the purpose of TypeScript. Overusing it leads to "Anyscript".

docs.title: 4. What is void?
docs.text:
void represents the absence of a value. It is commonly used as the return type of functions that do not return a value.

function logMessage(msg: string): void {
    console.log(msg);
}

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate compares with undefined.
    • Follow-up: "Can you assign undefined to a void variable?"
    • Answer: Yes, because a function returning nothing actually returns undefined in JS.

docs.title: 5. What is unknown type?
docs.text:
unknown is the type-safe counterpart of any. You can assign anything to unknown, but you cannot perform operations on it (like calling methods) without first asserting or narrowing its type.

let value: unknown = "hello";
// value.toUpperCase(); // Error: Object is of type 'unknown'.

if (typeof value === "string") {
    console.log(value.toUpperCase()); // OK
}

docs.title: 6. What is never type?
docs.text:
never represents the type of values that never occur. Used for: * Functions that throw an exception. * Functions that have infinite loops. * Exhaustive type checking in switch statements.

function error(message: string): never {
    throw new Error(message);
}

docs.title: 7. Explain Type Inference.
docs.text:
TypeScript can often infer the type of a variable when there is no explicit type annotation.

let x = 10; // Inferred as number
// x = "hello"; // Error

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions "Best Common Type".
    • Follow-up: "How does inference work for an array with mixed values like [0, 1, null]?"
    • Answer: It tries to find a type that is a supertype of all candidates. (number | null)[].

docs.title: 8. What is the difference between let, const, and var?
docs.text: (Same as JavaScript ES6) * var: Function scoped, hoisted, can be redeclared. * let: Block scoped, not hoisted (TDZ), cannot be redeclared in same scope. * const: Block scoped, cannot be reassigned (immutable binding).

docs.title: 9. How do you define an Array in TypeScript?
docs.text: Two syntaxes: 1. type[]: let list: number[] = [1, 2, 3]; 2. Array<type>: let list: Array<number> = [1, 2, 3]; (Generic syntax)

docs.title: 10. What is a Tuple?
docs.text:
A tuple is an array with a fixed number of elements whose types are known, but need not be the same.

let x: [string, number];
x = ["hello", 10]; // OK
// x = [10, "hello"]; // Error

docs.title: 11. What is an Enum?
docs.text:
Enums allow defining a set of named constants. TypeScript supports both numeric and string-based enums.

enum Direction {
    Up = 1,
    Down,
    Left,
    Right
}

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate mentions Numeric vs String Enums.
    • Follow-up: "What is a const enum?"
    • Answer: Const enums are completely removed during compilation; usage is replaced by the literal values for performance.

docs.title: 12. What is Type Assertion?
docs.text:
Type assertion allows you to tell the compiler "I know more about this type than you do." It's similar to type casting in other languages but performs no special checking or restructuring of data.

Syntax: 1. as syntax: let strLength: number = (someValue as string).length; 2. Angle-bracket syntax: let strLength: number = (<string>someValue).length; (Conflict with JSX).

docs.title: 13. What is the null vs undefined difference in TS?
docs.text:
• undefined: A variable that has been declared but not assigned a value.
  • null: An assignment value that acts as a representation of "no value". By default null and undefined are subtypes of all other types (unless strictNullChecks is on).

docs.title: 14. What is object type?
docs.text: object is a type that represents the non-primitive type (i.e., anything that is not number, string, boolean, symbol, null, or undefined).

docs.title: 15. How do you compile a TypeScript file?
docs.text:
Using the TypeScript Compiler (tsc). Command: tsc filename.ts -> generates filename.js.

Compilation Process Flow:

graph LR
    TS[TypeScript Code .ts] -->|tsc| Compiler[TS Compiler]
    Compiler -->|Type Check| Errors[Errors?]
    Compiler -->|Transpile| JS[JavaScript Code .js]
    JS -->|Run| Browser[Browser / Node.js]

docs.title: 16. Interface vs Type Alias?
docs.text:
Feature Interface Type Alias Definition interface User { ... } type User = { ... } Extensibility Can be merged (Declaration Merging) Cannot be merged Use Case Defining shapes of objects/classes Unions, Primitives, Tuples, Objects Implementation Can be implemented by classes Can be implemented by classes

Candidate Response Paths:

  • Path A: Candidate prefers Interfaces.
    • Follow-up: "When MUST you use a Type Alias?"
    • Answer: When defining Union types (type Status = 'Success' | 'Fail') or Tuple types.

docs.title: 17. How to define optional properties in an Interface?
docs.text:
Use the ? symbol.

interface Car {
    make: string;
    model?: string; // Optional
}

docs.title: 18. What are Readonly properties?
docs.text:
Properties that can only be modified when an object is first created.

interface Point {
    readonly x: number;
    readonly y: number;
}

docs.title: 19. Can interfaces extend each other?
docs.text:
Yes, using the extends keyword. An interface can extend multiple interfaces.

interface Shape { color: string; }
interface Square extends Shape { sideLength: number; }

docs.title: 20. Index Signatures in Interfaces?
docs.text:
Used when you don't know all the names of properties beforehand but you know the shape of the values.

interface StringArray {
    [index: number]: string;
}

docs.title: 21. Function Types in Interfaces?
docs.text:
Interfaces can describe function types.

interface SearchFunc {
    (source: string, subString: string): boolean;
}

docs.title: 22. Hybrid Types?
docs.text:
An object that acts as both a function and an object, with additional properties.

interface Counter {
    (start: number): string;
    interval: number;
    reset(): void;
}

docs.title: 23. Explain "Duck Typing" in TypeScript (Structural Typing).
docs.text: TypeScript uses structural typing. If object A has all the properties of type B, then A is compatible with B, regardless of whether A explicitly implements B.

docs.title: 24. What is Literal Type?
docs.text:
A type that represents a specific value.

type Easing = "ease-in" | "ease-out" | "ease-in-out";

docs.title: 25. What is a Union Type?
docs.text:
A type formed from two or more other types, representing values that may be any one of those types. Operator: |

function padLeft(value: string, padding: string | number) { ... }

docs.title: 26. What is an Intersection Type?
docs.text:
Combines multiple types into one. The new type has all features of the combined types. Operator: &

type Draggable = Drag & Drop;

docs.title: 27. What happens when you extend an interface with conflicting members?
docs.text: It causes a compilation error unless the types are compatible. If they are not (e.g., x: number vs x: string), TS will flag it.

docs.title: 28. How to describe a Class Constructor in an Interface?
docs.text:
You need to define a "new" signature. Note: You cannot implement this interface directly on the class; it describes the static side (constructor).

interface ClockConstructor {
    new (hour: number, minute: number): ClockInterface;
}

docs.title: 29. Can you implement an Interface in a Class?
docs.text:
Yes, using implements.

class Car implements Vehicle { ... }

docs.title: 30. What is Declaration Merging?
docs.text:
If you define two interfaces with the same name, TypeScript automatically merges them into a single interface.

interface Box { height: number; }
interface Box { width: number; }
// Box now has both height and width

docs.title: 31. What are Generics?
docs.text:
Generics provide a way to make components work with any data type and not restrict them to one data type. It creates Reusable Components.

function identity<T>(arg: T): T {
    return arg;
}

docs.title: 32. Generic Constraints?
docs.text:
restricting the types that can be used with a generic by using extends.

interface Lengthwise { length: number; }
function loggingIdentity<T extends Lengthwise>(arg: T): T {
    console.log(arg.length); // OK
    return arg;
}

docs.title: 33. What is keyof operator?
docs.text:
Takes an object type and produces a string or numeric literal union of its keys.

interface Person { name: string; age: number; }
type P = keyof Person; // "name" | "age"

docs.title: 34. Explain Generic Utility Types: Partial<T>.
docs.text:
Constructs a type with all properties of T set to optional.

function updateTodo(todo: Todo, fieldsToUpdate: Partial<Todo>) { ... }

docs.title: 35. Explain Pick<T, K>.
docs.text:
Constructs a type by picking the set of properties K from T.

type TodoPreview = Pick<Todo, "title" | "completed">;

docs.title: 36. Explain Omit<T, K>.
docs.text:
Constructs a type by picking all properties from T and then removing K.

type TodoPreview = Omit<Todo, "description">;

docs.title: 37. Explain Record<K, T>.
docs.text:
Constructs an object type whose property keys are K and whose property values are T.

const x: Record<string, number> = { "a": 10, "b": 20 };

docs.title: 38. Explain ReturnType<T>.
docs.text:
Constructs a type consisting of the return type of function T.

type T0 = ReturnType<() => string>; // string

docs.title: 39. Function Overloading in TypeScript?
docs.text:
You can provide multiple function signatures for the same function name. The implementation signature must be compatible with all overload signatures.

function add(a: string, b: string): string;
function add(a: number, b: number): number;
function add(a: any, b: any): any {
    return a + b;
}

docs.title: 40. Rest Parameters?
docs.text:
Allows a function to accept an indefinite number of arguments as an array.

function buildName(firstName: string, ...restOfName: string[]) { ... }

docs.title: 41. Default Parameters?
docs.text:
Parameters can have default values.

function buildName(firstName: string, lastName = "Smith") { ... }

docs.title: 42. What is this typing in functions?
docs.text:
You can declare the type of this by adding a fake first parameter named this to the function.

function f(this: void) {
    // make sure `this` is unusable in this standalone function
}

docs.title: 43. Why use Generics over any?
docs.text: any loses type safety. Generics preserve the type information. If you pass a string to a generic function, the compiler knows the return type is also string.

docs.title: 44. Generic Classes?
docs.text:
Classes can also be generic.

class GenericNumber<T> {
    zeroValue: T;
    add: (x: T, y: T) => T;
}

docs.title: 45. Using Class Types in Generics?
docs.text:
When creating factories in TypeScript using generics, it is necessary to refer to class types by their constructor functions.

function create<T>(c: { new(): T; }): T {
    return new c();
}

docs.title: 46. Access Modifiers in TypeScript?
docs.text: Modifier Description public Accessible everywhere (Default). private Accessible only within the containing class. protected Accessible within the class and deriving classes.

docs.title: 47. Abstract Classes?
docs.text:
Classes that cannot be instantiated directly. They serve as base classes. Can contain implementation details and abstract methods (must be implemented by subclass).

abstract class Department {
    abstract printMeeting(): void; // Must be implemented
    printName(): void { console.log("Dept"); }
}

docs.title: 48. Parameter Properties?
docs.text:
A shorthand to create and initialize a member in one place.

class Octopus {
    constructor(readonly name: string) {
        // Automatically creates a readonly property 'name' and assigns the arg
    }
}

docs.title: 49. Getters and Setters (Accessors)?
docs.text:
Intercept access to a member of an object.

class Employee {
    private _fullName: string;
    get fullName(): string { return this._fullName; }
    set fullName(newName: string) { this._fullName = newName; }
}

docs.title: 50. Static Properties?
docs.text:
Members that are visible on the class itself rather than on the instances.

class Grid {
    static origin = {x: 0, y: 0};
}
console.log(Grid.origin.x);

docs.title: 51. Readonly Modifier in Classes?
docs.text: Prevents assignment to the field outside of the constructor.

docs.title: 52. Inheritance vs Composition?
docs.text:
• Inheritance: "Is-a" relationship (Dog is an Animal). Good for hierarchy.
  • Composition: "Has-a" relationship (Car has an Engine). flexible, less coupling. TypeScript supports both.

docs.title: 53. How to check if a class implements an interface at runtime?
docs.text: Interfaces do not exist at runtime (they are erased). You cannot check obj instanceof MyInterface. You must use Type Guards.

docs.title: 54. What is a Mixin?
docs.text: A way to build up classes from reusable components by combining simpler partial classes. TypeScript doesn't have a specific mixin keyword but supports the pattern.

docs.title: 55. Method Overriding?
docs.text: A subclass can provide a specific implementation of a method that is already provided by its parent class.

docs.title: 56. super keyword?
docs.text:
• super() calls the constructor of the parent class.
  • super.method() calls a method on the parent class.

docs.title: 57. Can a class implement multiple interfaces?
docs.text: Yes. class C implements A, B { ... }

docs.title: 58. Can a class extend multiple classes?
docs.text: No. TypeScript allows single inheritance only. Use Mixins for multiple inheritance behavior.

docs.title: 59. Difference between private and #private (JS private fields)?
docs.text:
• private: TypeScript compile-time check. At runtime, it's just a normal property.
